webTitle: England squad: Young Cole comes in on Keegan's new wave

fields.headline: Young Cole comes in on Keegan's new wave
fields.standfirst:
Coach calls for young guns as he begins World Cup campaign
Ron Atkinson's viewpoint
fields.trailText: West Ham's 18-year-old midfielder Joe Cole has been named in the squad for the World Cup qualifiers against Germany and Finland, while David Beckham becomes vice-captain. David Lacey reports as Kevin Keegan lays down the youthful foundations for future success.
fields.body:
Joe Cole has been included in a full England squad for the first time as Kevin Keegan seeks to build the foundations of a team for the future, whether or not the present side qualifies for the 2002 World Cup. And if Keegan is unlucky with injuries in the Premier League this weekend the 18-year-old West Ham United midfielder may win his first cap sooner than he expects.

Cole is unlikely to start in either the World Cup encounter with Germany at Wembley tomorrow week or the match against Finland in Helsinki four days later. But from what Keegan said about the player yesterday it is clear that the England coach would have no qualms about picking him if need be.

"Joe Cole can turn a game that's tight," Keegan enthused. "I believe he's ready, willing and able to perform at the very top level. I'm sure that if you're good enough you're old enough."

Having complained about his team's lack of invention in this summer's European Championship, Keegan has at least shown himself ready to do something about it. In fact he was being urged to take Cole to Euro 2000 until the player broke a leg at Derby. By picking Cole as a possible link between midfield and the strikers, when it would have been easy to recall the 34-year-old Teddy Sheringham on his present form for Manchester United, Keegan has surely seen off those who felt he was not giving young talent a chance.

Jamie Carragher, 22, has joined the 20-year-old Steven Gerrard, his equally versatile Liverpool team-mate, in the squad because Sol Campbell is injured. Like Gerrard, Carragher can play in defence or midfield. "You ask him to do a job and he does it," said Keegan. "He's as versatile as they come."

Add in a 19-year-old, Aston Villa's Gareth Barry, a central defender who shone at left-back during last month's 1-1 draw with France, and it is clear that the theoretical international qualities of England's young hopefuls are now being put to a practical test.

What Keegan now has to decide is the extent to which he can rely on youth in two qualifiers from which England will need to take at least four points if they are to make a satisfactory start to the task of reaching the 2002 World Cup.

One of his more serious options involves Gerrard playing in central midfield rather than Paul Ince. First Keegan will need to be sure of Gerrard's fitness after a series of nagging injuries, but he has never forgotten the youngster's contribution as a substitute in England's 1-0 victory over Germany at Euro 2000. Keegan also has Ray Parlour as midfield cover.

The recall to international duty of Graeme le Saux after an absence of 15 months will restore some of the balance on the left that England have recently lacked. Keegan could play the Chelsea man at left-back or retain Barry and use Le Saux on the left side of midfield.

The England coach intimated yesterday that Steve McManaman, short of match practice with Real Madrid, would not start against Germany, which could see Nick Barmby retained on the left, supported by Le Saux's overlaps.

Up front Michael Owen, who came on for the last 11 minutes in Paris, must surely start at Wembley with Andy Cole standing down unless Keegan reverts to twin strikers. Robbie Fowler, fit once more, is back in the squad.

Beckham, whose switch to central midfield was a mixed success in the France game, is likely to return to the right wing. The Manchester United player has taken Campbell's place as vice-captain, a role of questionable significance but proof that Keegan was not merely thinking aloud when he envisaged Beckham as an England skipper.

"Yes, I definitely see him as a future England captain," Keegan confirmed. "I don't worry about his temperament and I wouldn't make him vice-captain if I did. He's a leader. That's what's important."

webTitle: Ron Atkinson: Kevin too quick to throw Teddy out of crib

fields.headline: Kevin too quick to throw Teddy out of crib
fields.standfirst: David Lacey on the England squad
fields.trailText: The omission of Teddy Sheringham from England's squad for the crucial games against Germany and Finland will derprive Kevin Keegan of the striker's experience and sparkling club form.
fields.body:
No doubt there will be a lot of talk this morning of what good news it is to see young Joe Cole in the England squad. For me, though, there is bad news to go with it. And by that I mean the omission of Teddy Sheringham.

Don't get me wrong, including Cole is a positive move. It gives him a chance to see what international football is all about and will whet his appetite. But I think Sheringham's form and know-how would have been of more value in these crucial qualifiers against Germany and Finland. Surely there was room for both in the squad.

I've written here before that I would like the FA to take a long-term approach and plan less for the next World Cup and more for 2004 and 2006. But clearly that's not being done and under those circumstances I'm surprised to find Sheringham left out.

If he were a bit player at Manchester United, as he has been in the past, I wouldn't be saying this. But of late he's been the leading man in their front line. He's on the goals and Sir Alex Ferguson may have ricked against PSV Eindhoven by leaving him out.

Of course Sheringham also has experience Cole lacks. If Cole had played a game or two for England that would be one thing. But for me it would be too much of a gamble to throw him in now.

He's a talent, one for the future, but he's got very few league games under his belt and he hasn't played in big matches for West Ham. You could take a Manchester United kid who had made a similar number of appearances but some would have been massive games like those coming up.

I'm not saying I would start with Sheringham but I would certainly have him on the bench. He's used to these occasions and could come on and play with Andy Cole, whom he's partnered at United to brilliant effect.

If Sheringham is disappointed, David Beckham must be delighted to be vice-captain of his country. I saw him get stupidly booked in Eindhoven but he wants to captain England and this is a nice little carrot.

The debate on where he should play is sure to come up again, and I would keep him in the centre. A lot of the outcome at Wembley could come down to bravery, not just in the physical sense but in terms of who shows the courage to get on the ball and dominate the match. I would tell Beckham to dictate the game.

In any case England have a good right-sided midfielder in Kieron Dyer. I think he'll be a great international because he runs at people and not many defenders are good at dealing with that.

Against Germany those qualities look particularly important because if you make Christian Ziege defend on their left you eliminate the big threat he poses coming forward. That would make life a lot easier for the lads at the back.

In that department Keegan will be keeping just about everything crossed that Tony Adams and Martin Keown stay fit. Against Germany, Adams will not be up against a typical continental striker, full of darting runs and subtle touches; Oliver Bierhoff and Carsten Jancker are not like that and Adams thrives on the sort of physical battle he'll face.

I understand that the former Milan coach Arrigo Sacchi compared him with Franco Baresi after Arsenal's game against Lazio. He's not as sharp as Baresi was at his peak but he looked as good as he ever has.

The return to form and fitness of Graeme le Saux is also good news and he must start. Normally you might worry about the small number of games he has played for Chelsea but there aren't many alternatives and he looked pacy and lively at Old Trafford.

His adrenalin was high and the impetus of this recall should give him that rush again. It's just a shame Teddy Sheringham will not be experiencing the same feelings.

fields.headline: Beckham on the carpet
fields.trailText: Uefa are to investigate David Beckham's conduct during Manchester United's 3-1 defeat at PSV Eindhoven on Tuesday after photographs appeared to show him in the direction of the referee.
fields.body:
David Beckham's elation at being given the England vice-captaincy was tempered last night by the news that Uefa will investigate his conduct during Manchester United's 3-1 defeat at PSV Eindhoven in the Champions League.

He was booked for dissent and photographs seemed to show him spitting in the direction of the referee Markus Merk, which he has denied.

He was also in a row with his team-mate Gary Neville and involved in another incident with Merkat at the end, applauding him off the pitch.

"We have received the referee's report and it refers to an incident involving David Beckham," said a Uefa spokesman. "As a result we have to investigate whether any offence has been committed."

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Leeds have been given renewed hope of signing Monaco's midfielder John Arne Riise for £4m in a deal which has twice come apart at the seams when the French club refused to lower their £6m price for the 20-year-old Norwegian.
fields.body:
Leeds have been given renewed hope of signing Monaco's midfielder John Arne Riise for £4m in a deal which has twice come apart at the seams when the French club refused to lower their £6m price for the 20-year-old Norwegian.

Riise was left out of the squad for Monaco's Champions League match with Sturm Graz after reiterating his desire to move to Elland Road.

"I have had meetings with Monaco and I hope we can come to an agreement," said Berit Riise, his mother and agent. "The distance between the valuations is not that big any more.

Tottenham's Darren Anderton may feature at Leeds tomorrow. The midfielder, who came through 90 minutes for the reserves on Wednesday, was expected to be out for six to eight weeks after a groin problem this month. "Things don't usually happen quickly for me when I get injured," he said. "So this is a nice surprise. I had complete rest for about a week, did nothing, let nature do its thing and that seems to have helped."

Everton's Francis Jeffers will be sidelined for eight weeks after damaging ankle liga ments during the Worthington Cup defeat at Bristol Rovers.

The Merseysiders are expected to announce that they have tied up a deal with the cable television network NTL which is understood to be worth about £22m for a 9.9% stake. NTL, which has stakes in Aston Villa, Leicester, Middlesbrough and Newcastle, would be guaranteed merchandising and broadcasting rights.

Southend have sacked their manager Alan Little. Mick Gooding will take charge while the club look for somebody who will "get us back into the Second Division".

Sheffield Wednesday have signed Steve Harkness, 29, from Blackburn for £200,000. Arthur Cox has left Fulham, where he was director of football, to concentrate on his role as an England coach.

webTitle: Is time running out for the Express?

fields.headline: Is time running out for the Express?
fields.standfirst: The Express may have taken the bull by the horns, but the future of the Taurean newspaper may not be Rosie.
fields.trailText: It may have taken the bull by the horns, but the future of the Taurean Express may not be Rosie, says Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium.
fields.body:
The Express has been on a downward slope since its 1964 sales of four million, and its current low of just over one million puts it on the edge of this key psychological barrier for advertisers. As a Taurus (April 24 1900) with a principled Aquarian Moon suiting its pro-Labour inclinations, the Express has tremendous holding power, but with an older readership, its base is steadily contracting.

Clive Hollick, CEO at United Media, is also a Taurus (May 20 1945) and with his Mercury on the paper's sun, this investment means a lot to him. Cash is always a big issue for Taurus, but Hollick has held back from giving the Express the big investment it needs and it's not hard to see how it has got bogged down through this stick-in-the-mud sign.

Rosie Boycott, another Taurean (May 13 1951), fits in with the Express and Hollick, but with her fiery Jupiter on its Mercury she has begun to stir the dormant fire in the belly of the old beast, attracting a younger readership with more AB readers.

Yet despite the best efforts of her and her staff, bigger financial considerations and the spirit of a new age are outrunning slow Taurus. The current Jupiter-Pluto opposition is shaking up the media and publishing signs of Gemini and Sagittarius and the Express is yet another enterprise marked by this axis. It has been raked by a vicious and undermining Pluto transit since early last year, with no light at the end of the tunnel until late 2002.

It looks from the astrology as if Hollick and the United shareholders won't wait that long, or come up with the cash that is needed to see it through, and we are probably coming to journey's end for the current team.

Late October and early November is a catalyst period which could see a foreign buyer with big pockets and big ideas for innovation and a multi-platform strategy. The overseas Jupiter connection in its horoscope has always been good for it - think back to Beaverbrook. With the right backer, the future for the Express is better than it seems, although it may not look Rosie.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Time for a sex change

fields.headline: Time for a sex change
fields.standfirst:
Women swung the last election. Feminise the party fast - or it will lose the next one
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Women swung the last election. Feminise the party fast - or it will lose the next one.
fields.body:
Who won the last election for Labour? Women who swung to Labour for the first time. But it was shallow and conditional support. Now it is ebbing away, with 5% more women than men turning against Labour. Women caused all the last Conservative governments: Tony Blair won't get his progressive century unless he recaptures their vote. The perfunctory low-profile women's debate yesterday shows Labour doesn't get it - yet. It all happened instead at the women's fringe meeting.

As the election nears, Labour's back-room suits with the psephological calculators are showing an unaccustomed flicker of interest in the potential of women ministers and MPs. Come elections, women are an asset not an irrelevence. Voters prefer women politicians, who get consistently higher recognition and approval ratings even though they are in lesser jobs. Labour is going to need them, lots of them, up front everywhere, on the box and on the soap box pretending to be what they haven't been - key figures at the heart of government.

Behind the scenes, women are flexing their muscles. Senior women ministers have written to Jack Straw demanding something be done to amend the law to allow quotas for women parliamentary candidates. Too late. In Labour-held seats, 27 men have been selected and only two women. More men called John have been selected than women. Buggins after buggins have slid snuggly into local seats, defeating far better women. Harriet Harman and Joan Ruddock saw this coming. Straight after the last election they warned Straw that no more women would be selected without positive action. Straw thought the new "sea" of women MPs quite enough and refused. Now many fear the byelections committee will fly in a host of last-minute candidates to replace elevated old has-beens: will they be favoured male apparatchiks or women and black candidates?

How have the women fared in this first term? Not well. Talking to women ministers this week, most describe lives that sound almost unendurable. Determination, deep engagement with making their policies work plus ambition keeps them going, but some begin to wonder why. Start with the abuse. The political cadres immediately declared the Labour women mainly rubbish - Blair's babes, bleeper fodder, empty vessels. Swathes of male backbench dross went unremarked. Every prominent woman has been personally and poisonously attacked just for being a woman. Ghastly Nanny Tessa Jowell, frightful Toff Margaret Jay - women attract unique bile.

Every woman I spoke to has been done over by the press - rooting in the undergrowth of their past, searching for hypocrisy or angry bygone lovers, ex-husbands, anyone with anything discrediting to tell, with children harried and parents harrassed. If it weren't too painful for them, I could draw up an astounding dossier on this sexist campaign of vilification against women politicians. Where were the male colleagues who should have been standing shoulder to shoulder to defend them? All too often chortling in the bar with the men writing this stuff, or, in Mo's case, conducting a supercilious and jealous "she's not up to it" campaign that drove her out. How many men command one iota of her public affection?

Women ministers, spread painfully thin and lonely in their departmental silos, are still too few to form that critical mass that makes being female normal. Politics remains a male trade, reported on mainly by men: the testosterone rush in the fetid press centre at party conferences is a reminder. It is interesting how instinctively women politicians and women journalists tend to draw together, creating an alternative network - one step outside the briefing and counter-briefing viciousness. The culture changes at a glacial pace.

If women whinge in public it looks like weakness. As ever, some of their tormentors are "sisters" of an older generation. The departure of Betty Boothroyd was greeted with joy by women MPs: the old Tiller girl, beloved by men, disliked women and gave no ground on any change. Gwyneth Dunwoody, the only female candidate for the Speaker's job, would be every bit as bad: women MPs just hope for a modernising man. Margaret Beckett as leader of the house heads the modernisation of the commons committee which has made scant change. Ann Taylor wields her chief whip with all the old mad relish, backed by the tough lads in her office up drinking late and laughing at MPs begging to be let go. Every woman minister (and men if they unbutton enough) has horror stories of unrelenting whips forcing late nights on already unbearable schedules. The sadism of absolute power corrupts absolutely in this whipping, bullying parody of public school.

It's hardly surprising the intimidated new girls didn't make enough fuss. Now they must. No more traditional cross-party agreement with the Tory clubmen who block change - Labour must lay down the law on parliamentary reform. The Fawcett Society, backed by women MPs, is petitioning for a parliament with ordinary hours and terms that fit school holidays, instead of late nights and an absurdly long recess.

The public may not care about the working conditions of their privileged rulers. But the dangerous disengagement with the political process starts here. Polls show people hate the look of West minster, the ranting, strutting and posturing. It will look even more male next time, even more rebarbative to women. The hell of women's working lives in parliament only reflects the low priority the government has given to work/life balance issues that wrench women's lives everywhere. (And men's too.)

In the election no doubt women will be pushed up front. What happens afterwards? If Tony Blair understood how much humanising politics matters to democracy, he would replace his cabinet of unrecognisable bank managers with women in good, prominent jobs. This time put women inside every loop as the key politicial advisers and lobby fixers.

Labour gets too little credit for the all it's done for women - minimum wage, part-time workers' rights and a great deal more. Good policies are no use if without great communicators to sell them. Old neo-endogenous growth Gordon or even "y'know" Blair on Richard and Judy's sofa don't reach women with that story.

Men talking about childcare sound patronising. Women talk best to women - and often better to men too: advertisers know this. It takes Mo, Clare, Tessa, Patricia, Harriet, Estelle, Dawn, two Margarets and all the others to make women voters believe. They are less likely to spout statistics and more likely to admit childcare is still more promise than reality. The political arena of jousting boys on the make doesn't just leave women politicians out, it leaves women voters out too. Since it's older women who mostly vote Tory, while under-35 women mostly vote Labour, history is on the side of the progressive century. But only if Labour has a sex change.

webTitle: No shotgun wedding for Wiltshire couple

fields.headline: No shotgun wedding for Wiltshire couple
fields.standfirst: Gun shy in Wiltshire, herd times for farmers, and the return of flower power
fields.trailText: Gun shy in Wiltshire, herd times for farmers, and the return of flower power
fields.body:
Marriage plans shot to pieces
Bureaucratic killjoys have conspired to ruin the wedding day of George Steele and Doreen Pudney from Chippenham, Wiltshire.

The now not-so-happy couple, who are big Country and Western fans, have been banned from firing replica guns because of fears that it may scare local shoppers.

The sound of fake gunfire was to have been the climax to the ceremony until the superintendent registrar of Wiltshire, Dorothy Windeat, stepped in. She was quite adamant about the issue. "I just don't think it would be appropriate," she said.

Mr Steele, 61, had already approached the local constabulary who told him they had no problem with the one-off blank firing. He said of the diktat: "It's really going to spoil it for us."

Mrs Pudney, 51, was crestfallen at the superintendent's decision. "It's very disappointing," she said. "This was going to be the highlight of our wedding because we thought this is how they would have celebrated in those times."

Despite the ban on fake firearms, the couple will still don traditional Western garb and hope many of their guests will too.
Wiltshire Times

Farmers set sail for cows week
Seven farm workers from Perthshire are to represent Scotland at the Third International Herdmen's Meeting in Tyrol, Austria.

The Scots, who are determined to be great national ambassadors, will organise a mini-Highland Games and are taking a mini-caber specially made for the occasion.

Festivities at the international event kick off with the March of the Herdsmen followed by a field mass. Excitement will reach fever pitch in the afternoon with demonstrations of goat herding running alongside a market of rural products.

A report on the extinction of old animal races in the Alps by Professor Dr Ambros Aichhorn should get everyone's juices flowing before the herdsmen get the chance to visit a farm. And as if all that wasn't enough, a multi-vision presentation entitled Where is the Tyrol? will be followed by a discussion on the subject. What fun.
Blairgrove Advertiser

Self-raising flower
The competition was fierce but no one could deny that Rex Saunby had the biggest sunflower in Market Rasen.

At 13ft 14in, Rex's entry in the sunflower competition was the talk of the village with rumours of a secret recipe. But Mr Saunby, who has reportedly being growing sunflowers for years, refused to comment.

The contest was sparked by the mayor of Market Rasen, Sue Briggs, who grew a giant sunflower in her garden.
Market Rasen Mail

Island life

The traffic island in front of the church in Belper has finally been officially named.

The area has long been known as the Triangle by local people and now Amber Valley Borough Council has bowed to popular demand and put up signs recognising the fact.

Belper Town councillor Alan Cox, who was instrumental in securing the new signage, said: "John Nelson and myself brought up the ideas during a town council meeting. I am glad the council has taken up the suggestion because now everyone will know where the Triangle is."
Belper News

Pig ignorant

A rare pig is in a critical condition after falling into the River Stour.

Owner, smallholder Paul Woodhall, was said to be very concerned after veterinary treatment failed to help the 25 stone Gloucester Old Spot sow which was in shock from the unexpected dip.

The pig's travails led to the fire brigade's boat being sent to the area from Bewdley.
Redditch Advertiser

Letter of the week: anus horribilis

I have lived in Newhaven all my life, only leaving the town for six months during the war and two years in the army.

So Newhaven is my kind of town, my grandfather and my uncle were members of the town council for a great number of years. So I do know my town of Newhaven.

Why is Lewes so favoured and Newhaven not?

In Lewes, down the Avenue, the pavements have been done with pink terracotta paving slabs while in Newhaven's Chapel Street the pavement is a slope of 45 degrees and only about two feet wide, and made from tarmac.

In Lewes precinct there is not a brick out of place! In Newhaven precinct there is a patchwork of tarmac from one end to the other. No wonder people don't come into the town, it's a disgrace!

What the people of Newhaven want to know is, who are the people in the corridors of power in Lewes that are turning Newhaven into the anus of Sussex? We in Newhaven are fed up with it.

R P Pargeter, Newhaven.


Sussex Express

fields.trailText: THE GALLANT ST GALLEN
fields.body:
THE GALLANT ST GALLEN

In his preview of the Chelsea v St Gallen tie, Martin Thorpe wrote: "It is precisely Chelsea's habit of slipping up against the sort of teams they should be beating that has undermined Ken Bates' plans to win a trophy big enough to match his ego."

"I was just wondering which trophy Mr Thorpe considered big enough?" asks a puzzled Mark Gillespie. "I don't remember talk of a Galaxy or Universe cup so far from Fifa."

Maybe next year Mr Bates' grand plans will finally realised. Or perhaps his ego will shrink. Who knows? In the meantime he can comfort himself with knowing that Chelsea's performance made several St Gallen fans very happy last night.

"What a shame for Chelsea!" writes a delirious Raoul Pinto. "Perhaps their players thought the Swiss supporters couldn't be emotional. But if you had been in the stadium you would have been shaking like the rest of us."

Helmut Schmidt believes it was Chelsea's lack of fight that let them down. "Oddly enough, the main reason for my team's victory was that they possessed in abundance that typically British fighting spirit, which Chelsea seemed to lack. There were a lot of skills and nice passing in their game, but no real passion."

RED STAR AT NIGHT

Fans of Red Star Belgrade have also been writing in to salute their team's performance - and to excuse the shocking behaviour of their fans.

"Red Star is the best and their fans are the best," says Darko93. "I think that their behaviour can be excused by the fact that the club was forced to play in Vienna.

"That is great slap in the face for the former World Champion and their fans. And by forcing the match to be played in another country you actually stopped more or less normal fans (that didn't have money to make the trip) to stay home, while the most loyal (and the most psycho ones) still came and made sure revenge was total."

Meanwhile, Damir Sisirak made an impassioned plea for people to forget the politics and concentrate on the football.

"Why is so hard for people to understand that politics and sports should not mix in any way. It was easy for Leicester to play game in their own stadium and we did not complain at all, and why should we? But the moment the game was finished everybody started talking about not playing in Belgrade. How can you do that for fans?

"I believe some people take soccer as a business or something. Where I am coming from soccer is more than life. And now you took that from me and you expect me to understand and forget? If there was any justice in the world we should have played both games on neutral ground. Surely that would have been more fair?

webTitle: Where does the Danish euro vote leave Britain?

fields.headline: Where does the Danish euro vote leave Britain?
fields.standfirst: Denmark has voted "no" to the euro. Does that mean we will stay out too, asks Julian Glover
fields.trailText: Denmark has voted "no" to the euro. Does that mean we will stay out too, asks Julian Glover
fields.body:
Why is the euro in the news?
Because a referendum in Denmark on joining the euro has been won, against early expectations, by the "no" camp. Danes have voted 53%-47% against merging their currency with that of their European partners.

Does this affect Britain?
In theory, no. Denmark is far smaller than Britain, its currency is already tied to the euro and its economy is less international. What's right for Denmark isn't necessarily right for Britain.

On the other hand?
On the other hand the Danish vote has immense significance for Britain. Firstly, it means if Britain does decide to keep the pound it won't be the only EU country outside the euro. That's important. Secondly, it gives heart to opponents of the euro in Britain: they have worked closely with Danish "nej" campaigners and will now be confident they can win any referendum in Britain. Thirdly the Danish vote will terrify New Labour. Ministers fear that defeat in a referendum may destroy their ability to make progress on all sorts of other issues. The Danish vote suggests that it may be impossible for the government to endorse euro membership in a referendum and expect to win. And if they come to believe that, there may be no referendum in Britain at all.

So the government's policy has changed?
Officially, not one jot. Tony Blair has been careful not to suggest he favoured either side in the Danish vote, and in its wake ministers have claimed that government policy on the euro remains the same. But the policy may become irrelevant if the politics of putting it into practice become impossible. That's the real significance of the Danish vote for Britain.

And what is the government's policy?
It is still to "prepare and decide" before putting the issue of British membership to a referendum. Gordon Brown sets great store by the five economic "tests" he has devised to determine whether the time is right to join and will not advocate membership until these criteria have been met.

Is this all?
No. Behind the scenes things are rather more complex. Some ministers, Brown among them, are unenthusiastic about the prospect of membership (though none seems to want to rule it out altogether).

Others, such as Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, believe the government must speak out about the possible benefits of membership if it is to have any chance of persuading the public to vote for it in a referendum. That said, neither the chancellor nor the foreign secretary thinks that Britain should join the single currency immediately, and neither of them wants to rule it out all altogether.

So they really agree?
Not quite. Robin Cook and Gordon Brown might agree about the broad sweep of policy towards the euro, but they certainly disagree when it comes to the matter of tone. The chancellor's early enthusiasm for the single currency, in 1997 and 1998, has been replaced by a cautious neutrality. In contrast, the foreign secretary - always a pro-European - has become openly keen on joining. A draft of a speech he gave earlier this year, for instance, included a promise that the government "would not let Britain lose by staying out" - words that the chancellor would be unlikely to use.

Is the government split on the issue, then?
To a degree. Apart from the foreign secretary, two other leading ministers, Mandelson and trade secretary Stephen Byers, would like the government to be more openly enthusiastic about the euro. But the real issue is not a fundamental split between pro-Europeans and anti-Europeans, but a concern on the part of pro-Europeans that the single currency is not an issue on which the government should or can remain neutral.

What about Tony Blair?
The prime minister's main concern has been to maintain a united front. The last thing he wants is a public split between his chancellor and his foreign secretary as the election approaches. Until now his main concern has been to avoid the single currency becoming an election issue. That might allow William Hague to exploit public disquiet about the subject. Even after the Danish vote, the prime minister hopes to call a referendum on membership after the election - but he will do so only if he thinks it can be won.

webTitle: Mobile internet: Sony launches its latest mini-gadget

fields.headline: Mobile internet: Sony launches its latest mini-gadget
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Ever wanted to trade stocks and watch television while sitting on the toilet? Then Sony's latest wireless gadget could be for you.
fields.body:
Ever wanted to trade stocks and watch television while sitting on the toilet? Then Sony's latest wireless gadget could be for you.

The Japanese hi-tech firm yesterday launched a portable screen that can be used to surf the internet, send email and watch TV, billing it as the digital era's answer to its revolutionary Walkman personal stereo. The Airboard, a sleek, lightweight 26cm monitor that comes with a base station to receive information, enables users to roam around the house and as far as the garden while staying connected and entertained.

Trading stocks while visiting the bathroom was listed as one of the Airboard's possible uses, as well as browsing the net or watching a video while cooking dinner. "There has been nothing like this in the world," said Shizuo Takashino, a director in charge of Sony's home electronics division.

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week seven
fields.standfirst: Each week throughout the season, Football Unlimited writers take on the bookies. Betting site Blue Square gave us £100 each - will we make our millions or lose it all?

fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £107.41
Sean Ingle = £98.42
Paul MacInnes = £83.80
Football Unlimited punters' collective = £67.50

Scott Murray

Southampton v Middlesbrough, four or more goals: £10 @ 15/8

I was initially going to whack a tenner on the home side at evens. That bet looks like value: Boro don't have a bad record at the Dell, drawing on their last two visits, but they don't have a great one either - the time before, they lost by four. And with Boro inconsistent, I'd expect Saints to win this one more often than not.

But then I remembered that Southampton are likely to be without Dean Richards and Tahar El Khalej, their best two defenders. So if Saints are going to win, the odd goal or two may not be enough to see off a team who can field strikers like Boksic, Whelan, Ricard and, er, Deane.

I still fancy Marian Pahars and his cronies to outscore their visitors, though. But given Saints defensive frailties - and the fact that three of the last six matches between these two teams have produced at least four goals - 15/8 on four goals or more looks a more generous proposition than the simple home win.

Sean Ingle

Sunderland to beat Leicester £8 @ 11/10

For 67 glorious seconds last week, I was staring a small fortune in the face (and when you're on what I'm on, then £200 is a small fortune). Bolton had just equalised against Blackburn in the 88th minute, and all my other predictions were also coming off.

But no sooner had I dreamt about finally putting a down-payment on a holiday home in Wales, then news came through of Alpay's own goal in the Boro-Villa match! After a couple of nights of troubled and tortured sleep, I was finally able to reflect that at least one of my trebles came off, which means I'm now back where I started.

This week I hope to creep slowly above the £100 mark with a value bet on Sunderland. They comfortably beat the Foxes in the corresponding fixture last year, are unbeaten at the Stadium of Light and - after a shaky start - haven't lost in their last four games. With Kevin Phillips returning to form, and with confidence high, they should be too good for a Leicester team still licking its wounds after last night's loss to Red Star Belgrade.

Paul MacInnes

Arsenal to draw with Manchester United, and Chelsea to draw with Liverpool: £4.67 double @ 9/4 and 2/1

At times like this one must not lose faith in one's self. Yes, last week I may have spurned the chance to back Preston for the away win against Sheffield Wednesday, preferring to go for the higher value half-time win. Yes, I may have been made to look a plum by the final result (Preston won, but Wednesday were ahead after 45 minutes). But, at all costs, I must remain true to my principles. If only I could remember what they were.

Anyway, this week, my leetle chooms, I have plumped for two draws in the weekend's big matches. The reasons for this are two-fold. Actually, make it three-fold. Firstly, it's the weekend after Europe and, with all four sides playing midweek, performance levels will drop. Two, it's too early in the season for any team to feel they have to go for a win (and thus risk losing). Three, the sides are evenly matched, with a slightly stuttering United facing an exciting but brittle Arsenal, and Ranieri's embryonic Chelsea playing Houllier's out-of-form Liverpool. Watch them struggle, watch them toil, but watch them draw. And if they don't, well I've got a terrible track record to hide behind, haven't I.

Roy Chan, trainee accountant

Arsenal to beat Manchester United @ 13/8, Bolton to draw with Fulham @ 9/4, Cambridge to beat Oldham @ 13/8, Bristol City to beat Oxford @ 6/4, Millwall to beat Peterborough @ 5/4, and Swansea to beat Bury @ 5/4: 1x50p accumulator, 20x20p trebles, 15x20p fourfolds, 6x20p fivefolds = 42 bets at £8.92

It sounds crazy, but perming a series of trebles, four, five and six-timers into 42 different bets can produce big returns. If all six of my predictions come off I'll win well over £300. And I'll get about £80 if five come off, about £25 for four and a couple of quid for just three.

I have chosen Arsenal to beat Manchester United at 13/8 as I think the Gunners' home advantage will prove too much for the so-called invincible champions. Bolton and Fulham to draw at 9/4 looks good as both are unbeaten, and it promises to be a tight match with a tight result. Cambridge to beat Oldham 13/8 is also value as I think Cambridge can beat the defensively frail Oldham.

Bristol City to beat Oxford at 6/4 also looks a decent bet - the Robins have conceded less than a goal a game and can shut out a side which conceded five last week. Millwall to beat Peterborough at 5/4 is also value: the Lions scored five against Oxford last week and there's more to come. Meanwhile, Swansea to beat Bury at 5/4 is a tight call, but I reckon home advantage will tell.

fields.headline: Easy draws,  Elbows, and  Egos
fields.trailText: DRAWING BLANKS
fields.body:
DRAWING BLANKS

It's the second most important trophy in Europe and it's of absolutely no concern to anybody down the Kings Road. It's Euro-vase, and the draw for the second round was made this morning. The Fiver sat through the whole shebang, bravely stomaching the sight of two wobbly Uefa executives gripping their velvet ball bags just for you. Don't say we never go out of our way to please.

BBC1 light-entertainment troupe Liverpool were rewarded for their spectacular 0-0 victory over Rapid Bucharest with an easy-looking draw against Slovan Liberec. To be frank, we've never heard of this lot before - but we do know they're from the Czech Republic, so maybe Patrick Berger and Vladimir Anderton will be familiar with them. Perhaps. One thing is certain, though: Gerard Houllier will be standing around with a trademark totally bewildered look on his face as the first leg is played out at Anfield on October 26.

At the same time, Martin O'Neill will be on the prowl in France, where his team The Celtic Loyals have to face Bordeaux. This is sadly a tough draw for the Celts - their last foray into Europe ended in humiliation at the hands of another French side, Lyon. But they do get to play the second leg at home. That's something at least. Well, isn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Thinking about lingerie? £10 voucher to use when you spend £30 or more at Easyshop. Over 70 brands, there's something for everyone, with fast free delivery

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

RUN BY EUROPE, NOT IN EUROPE

Having faffed their lines against Swiss minnows St Gallen to stumble pathetically out of Euro-vase at the first hurdle, the last thing Chelsea's of Chelsea - the continental club playing only in England - needed was two more pieces of bad news. But that's exactly what they got. X-rays today confirmed that Roberto di Matteo has indeed broken his leg. Ow! And the most talented footballer in the world has given Dennis Wise a good verbal kicking. Oof! Ooyah! Oof!

Last night, poor di Matteo suffered a double fracture of his left leg as his team-mates set about humiliating themselves. The Swiss-born Italian has already undergone an operation and is expected to stay in the country of his birth for a few days. "Given what's happened he's as well as can be expected," said Gwyn Williams, the assistant manager of Chelsea, the continental club playing only in England.

Meanwhile, as one midfielder lay stricken, another was being fondly remembered by Zinedine Zidane. "It is difficult to play a good game when you get an elbow in the face," Zidane opined after being questioned about France's recent friendly with England. "For me, it was very clear that I was the target," he continued, probably gesticulating wildly. "He thumped me as if I was his worst enemy, it was unbelievable. What Wise did, it was worse than anything. He took me for nothing, for a crap." Much more of this sort of talk and Chelsea, the continental club playing only in England, will be in danger of becoming a laughing stock. What's that? Oh.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I've got a little book in which I've written down the names of those people who upset me the most. I don't want to name them because I want it to be a surprise when I get them back. I know I will get them some day" - England vice-captain David Beckham displays his new-found maturity in the pages of OK! magazine.

JEFFREY ARCHER COULDN'T WRITE THIS

It's not often the Fiver feels sorry for Manchester United, and today is no different. Instead - and not for the first time - we feel like shaking the "biggest" football club in the world by it's oversized ego and telling it to pull its act together. Because only 13 days after the club announced that Alison Ryan would be their touchy-feely new director of communications, the club has sacked her from the £100,000 PR post after finding out that she told some gigantic porkies about her past.

First, Ms Ryan claimed that she had a first-class degree from Cambridge when she had only attained a second. And if that wasn't bad enough (and it isn't) she also upgraded her law qualifications and invented a dodgy reference. Eventually, the law society caught up with her, but even then she failed to appear before their disciplinary committee, fleeing to Cuba where she claimed she was doing charity work. Thankfully, Castro soon sent her packing, and last year she was finally debarred by the Bar Council for a series of "serious offences".

However, all this was news to Manchester United, because only two weeks ago chief executive Peter Kenyon described her as having "an impressive track record". And even the Imperial Lord Ferg was horribly duped, claiming: "I am sure Alison will fit in well here". So how could another tragic tale of misfortune befall the world's "biggest" club? Fingers are already pointing at the recruitment agency Howgate Sable, who were given the task of finding Ms Right (and instead found Ms Ryan). And who used to be a consultant for Howgate Sable? Why, none other than Sir Roland Smith, the chairman of United's plc board. That's very unfortunate - to say the least.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Most ridiculous rumour of the day #1: Manchester United will use their multi-million pound deal with Nike to make an audacious bid for Ronaldo, claims Italian newspaper Tuttosport. Ronaldo's press spokesman, Rodriguo Paiva, claims his charge "wants to learn English". That's the evidence.

Most ridiculous rumour of the day #2: Shakhtar Donetsk manager Victor Prokopenko has told Planet Football he fails to understand why Arsenal have not made a formal bid for his goalkeeper Yuri Virt. "Could it be that the price tag for Yuri's transfer is just too high for them?" asks Prokopenko. "Could it be because Virt can't catch a ball to save his life and makes Ian Walker look safe on crosses?" asks the Fiver.

Speaking of Ian Walker, the Spurs keeper has been linked with Celtic.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leicester have decided not to lodge an official complaint over the behaviour of Red Star Belgrade supporters during last night's Euro-vase clash in Vienna. But City chairman John Elsom is optimistic that Uefa may decide to act on their own accord after they study the report of their own observer. Leicester fans were pelted with missiles before the game and then had flares fired at them in the stadium. In addition, City players Ade Akinbiyi and Andrew Impey were subjected to persistent racial abuse from the Red Star fans.

Ivan Zamorano scored two second-half goals for Chile as they beat the United States 2-0 to win the bronze medal in the Olympic football tournament.

Scotland manager Craig Brown has called up Dominic Matteo to his squad to face San Marino and Croatia in World Cup qualifying matches next month. Kevin Gallacher, Paul Lambert and Craig Burley rejoin the squad. fields.bodyText: DRAWING BLANKS It's the second most important trophy in Europe and it's of absolutely no concern to anybody down the Kings Road. It's Euro-vase, and the draw for the second round was made this morning. The Fiver sat through the whole shebang, bravely stomaching the sight of two wobbly Uefa executives gripping their velvet ball bags just for you. Don't say we never go out of our way to please. BBC1 light-entertainment troupe Liverpool were rewarded for their spectacular 0-0 victory over Rapid Bucharest with an easy-looking draw against Slovan Liberec. To be frank, we've never heard of this lot before - but we do know they're from the Czech Republic, so maybe Patrick Berger and Vladimir Anderton will be familiar with them. Perhaps. One thing is certain, though: Gerard Houllier will be standing around with a trademark totally bewildered look on his face as the first leg is played out at Anfield on October 26. At the same time, Martin O'Neill will be on the prowl in France, where his team The Celtic Loyals have to face Bordeaux. This is sadly a tough draw for the Celts - their last foray into Europe ended in humiliation at the hands of another French side, Lyon. But they do get to play the second leg at home. That's something at least. Well, isn't it? * * * * * * * * * * * * * ADVERTISEMENT Thinking about lingerie? £10 voucher to use when you spend £30 or more at Easyshop. Over 70 brands, there's something for everyone, with fast free delivery * * * * * * * * * * * * * RUN BY EUROPE, NOT IN EUROPE Having faffed their lines against Swiss minnows St Gallen to stumble pathetically out of Euro-vase at the first hurdle, the last thing Chelsea's of Chelsea - the continental club playing only in England - needed was two more pieces of bad news. But that's exactly what they got. X-rays today confirmed that Roberto di Matteo has indeed broken his leg. Ow! And the most talented footballer in the world has given Dennis Wise a good verbal kicking. Oof! Ooyah! Oof! Last night, poor di Matteo suffered a double fracture of his left leg as his team-mates set about humiliating themselves. The Swiss-born Italian has already undergone an operation and is expected to stay in the country of his birth for a few days. "Given what's happened he's as well as can be expected," said Gwyn Williams, the assistant manager of Chelsea, the continental club playing only in England. Meanwhile, as one midfielder lay stricken, another was being fondly remembered by Zinedine Zidane. "It is difficult to play a good game when you get an elbow in the face," Zidane opined after being questioned about France's recent friendly with England. "For me, it was very clear that I was the target," he continued, probably gesticulating wildly. "He thumped me as if I was his worst enemy, it was unbelievable. What Wise did, it was worse than anything. He took me for nothing, for a crap." Much more of this sort of talk and Chelsea, the continental club playing only in England, will be in danger of becoming a laughing stock. What's that? Oh. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I've got a little book in which I've written down the names of those people who upset me the most. I don't want to name them because I want it to be a surprise when I get them back. I know I will get them some day" - England vice-captain David Beckham displays his new-found maturity in the pages of OK! magazine. JEFFREY ARCHER COULDN'T WRITE THIS It's not often the Fiver feels sorry for Manchester United, and today is no different. Instead - and not for the first time - we feel like shaking the "biggest" football club in the world by it's oversized ego and telling it to pull its act together. Because only 13 days after the club announced that Alison Ryan would be their touchy-feely new director of communications, the club has sacked her from the £100,000 PR post after finding out that she told some gigantic porkies about her past. First, Ms Ryan claimed that she had a first-class degree from Cambridge when she had only attained a second. And if that wasn't bad enough (and it isn't) she also upgraded her law qualifications and invented a dodgy reference. Eventually, the law society caught up with her, but even then she failed to appear before their disciplinary committee, fleeing to Cuba where she claimed she was doing charity work. Thankfully, Castro soon sent her packing, and last year she was finally debarred by the Bar Council for a series of "serious offences". However, all this was news to Manchester United, because only two weeks ago chief executive Peter Kenyon described her as having "an impressive track record". And even the Imperial Lord Ferg was horribly duped, claiming: "I am sure Alison will fit in well here". So how could another tragic tale of misfortune befall the world's "biggest" club? Fingers are already pointing at the recruitment agency Howgate Sable, who were given the task of finding Ms Right (and instead found Ms Ryan). And who used to be a consultant for Howgate Sable? Why, none other than Sir Roland Smith, the chairman of United's plc board. That's very unfortunate - to say the least. THE RUMOUR MILL Most ridiculous rumour of the day #1: Manchester United will use their multi-million pound deal with Nike to make an audacious bid for Ronaldo, claims Italian newspaper Tuttosport. Ronaldo's press spokesman, Rodriguo Paiva, claims his charge "wants to learn English". That's the evidence. Most ridiculous rumour of the day #2: Shakhtar Donetsk manager Victor Prokopenko has told Planet Football he fails to understand why Arsenal have not made a formal bid for his goalkeeper Yuri Virt. "Could it be that the price tag for Yuri's transfer is just too high for them?" asks Prokopenko. "Could it be because Virt can't catch a ball to save his life and makes Ian Walker look safe on crosses?" asks the Fiver. Speaking of Ian Walker, the Spurs keeper has been linked with Celtic. Leicester fans were pelted with missiles before the game and then had flares fired at them in the stadium. In addition, City players Ade Akinbiyi and Andrew Impey were subjected to persistent racial abuse from the Red Star fans. webTitle: Sept 29: Diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: Moderate highs and gut lurching lows
fields.trailText: Fairly typical week in the life of a monitored authority. A mix of crisis management and measured improvement activity. It feels like too much of the former, but maybe that's because one notices and remembers the lurching gut moments more than the calm intervals.
fields.body:
Fairly typical week in the life of a monitored authority. A mix of crisis management and measured improvement activity. It feels like too much of the former, but maybe that's because one notices and remembers the lurching gut moments more than the calm intervals.

Lurching gut moments include hearing that we've got to suspend another manager, and that some (unrelated) financial fraud has also been found - scope as yet unknown. Gloom as we contemplate how much time will be diverted into investigating this, although most will be done by the fearsome corporate anti-fraud team.

Blood pressure moments include discovering that, yet again, I will be going into my monitoring meeting with the Social Services Inspectorate (SSI) with apologies for not having sent the agreed data set in advance. The good news is that the data set is available. This wasn't the case until about four months ago. Now we can actually discuss trends and look at graphs! I feel as proud as my three-year-old when she completes her Noddy jigsaw - let's hope the SSI is starting to feel equivalent maternal pride.

Good week for bolstering partnerships. Lunch with the director of Age Concern in Lambeth - both of us determined to get things moving for older people and recognising the need for a strategic alliance to push forward improvement.

Friday afternoon spent in Brixton police station interviewing with the borough commander for the borough liaison officer who will support the community safety partnership. Very impressed with the disciplined way in which the police do their performance appraisals - we have a long way to go (it's on the list). Less impressed with the police station itself - squalid reception (I can be smug as we have recently closed our squalid reception and opened a shiny new one) and intrusively noisy air conditioning. Nice to know I have it easier in some respects.

 Lisa Christensen is social services director of Lambeth council

webTitle: FT to launch Creative Business tabloid supplement

fields.headline: FT to launch Creative Business tabloid supplement
fields.trailText: The Financial Times is launching a tabloid supplement, called Creative Business, on October 10 as part of a raft of editorial changes, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Financial Times is launching a tabloid supplement called Creative Business on October 10 as part of a raft of editorial changes.

The weekly, 16-page supplement about the business side of the creative industries is to be edited by former FT deputy home news editor Andrew Davies, who will be responsible for six editorial staff.

Philip Stephens, editor of the FT's UK and Ireland edition, said the development was part of a longer term strategy to make the paper more "accessible". The process began a year ago with a redesign and the launch of a supplement called the Business.

Mr Stephens said that recent ABC figures showing a 6% year-on-year circulation increase suggested the first part of the strategy had been successful. "We got just the right kind of reactions, which suggests people think the FT is now less daunting, more friendly and easier on the eye."

He added that the FT was shifting its target readership to take account of the fact that business culture was now "increasingly mainstream".

"We have to write for a community that isn't a corporate community any more. Fewer of our readers are big company executives, and there are far more potential readers in small and medium-sized businesses."

Creative Business is being launched to fill what Mr Stephens described as a gap in the market for a publication "to help translate creative ideas into business". The section will focus on a broad remit of industries, from television and architecture to film and software design.

From October 9, the FT will incorporate law and business into Inside Track, launch two columns dealing with technology and management, and a new Monday sports section.

fields.headline: Musical politicians
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about our statesmen and their music
fields.trailText: All you need to know about our statesmen and their music.
fields.body:
1. Gerhard Schröder has become an unwilling star of the German music scene. A television comedian has made a rap CD out of an informal recording of him demanding a beer. It's a smash hit, but the chancellor is not amused.

2. Some politicians like to be associated with music: former prime minister Sir Edward Heath, for one, is a whizz on the organ.

3. So of course is Bill Clinton, although he prefers to be remembered for his saxophone playing.

4. Others don't care for musical memories. Tony Blair dislikes being reminded of his strumming days in the 70s with his Oxford rock band, Ugly Rumours, a very, very poor and distant relation of the Rolling Stones.

5. The intertwining of statesmanship and the recording trade has even reached religion. One of the more esoteric discs available was cut by the pope. No, not that one: Shenouda III.

6. The other pope, John Paul II, has also made musical waves, with his mega-hit Abba Pater.

7. Sometimes, musicians get their own back by becoming politicians. Like the late Sonny Bono.

8. Jubilee 2000, the group campaigning for the cancellation of third world debt, has had fun suggesting a political combo for its NetAid concert.

9. Celebs who crave musical recognition are not all politicians.

10. Musicians who crave political success are not always mediocre. Ignacy Paderewski, prime minister of Poland after the first world war, was the greatest concert pianist of his time.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed:  Karma Kit
fields.body:
As fashion folk are all too eager to tell you, nothing, and I mean NOTHING, darling, is as stressful as a fashion week. All that dashing up and down town, running for a taxi only to split your kitten heel, getting from Clements Ribeiro's show across town to McQueen's private party with five minutes to spare is, you know, a total nightmare. No wonder we need a week at an ayurvedic spa to recover.

So thank heavens for London's own darling designer, Matthew Williamson, who has thoughtfully brought out a Karma Kit in time for London Fashion Week. It includes a bottle of jasmine flower mist (to get rid of that Marlboro Light smell), a peppermint pulse point balm (to perk you up in time for that hush-hush party at Fabric), an incense perfume (to provide tranquillity when traipsing up and down Brick Lane looking for a cab) and a lovely pink travel candle (for, well, when have you ever needed a reason to have another scented candle?).

Then there's the gorgeous Matthew Williamson clutchbag. Bright, cheerful, individualistic and fun, Williamson's designs are always a hit with the celeb crowd and this bag exemplifies why.

And lest you think fashion is going soft in its old age, fear not: there are only 100 available (£225, only this week at Harvey Nichols), so they still have that air of exclusivity. After surviving the scrum to get one, you'll no doubt need your Karma Kit to mellow out.

fields.headline: Original sinner
fields.standfirst: A quarter of a century ago, Bruce Oldfield was one of the first bad boys of British fashion.  Deborah Bee  catches up with him on his 50th birthday
fields.trailText: A quarter of a century ago, Bruce Oldfield was one of the first bad boys of British fashion. Deborah Bee catches up with him on his 50th birthday.
fields.body:
Soooooo, spot anything lovely at London Fashion week? Crocheted thong? Mussel shell skirt? Latex bodysuit? British fashion has certainly been living up to its reputation. Though equally renowned for excellent tailoring and truly innovative design, you can always rely on our lot to transform mere clothes into fantastical costumes, turning fashion shows into theatrical events.

You can also rely on the fact that the best of those young Brits will get swept off to head up a fashion house abroad. But back home, Britain has yet to produce a designer who can translate this avant-garde creativity into a global brand. There is no British equivalent of Calvin Klein, Karl Lagerfeld or Giorgio Armani.

Twenty-seven years ago, five bright young designers, with similar reputations for wild behaviour, were launched on to the international fashion circuit by the recently formed British Fashion Council, whose main objective was to promote a previously nonexistent London designer scene. Bruce Oldfield, a striking 23-year-old, was one of them. He now plays down his bad boy reputation for clubbing with the pop star set.

"It was a fantastically exciting time," he enthuses. "We were called the New Wave. There are people who would say I was outrageous back then but I think I'm quite conservative. I remember walking into a club in Jermyn Street with Grace Jones in the 70s and whispering: 'Er, you know, um, when we go in, I think a little less cracking of the whip would be, um, a good thing' and she was like: 'Oh, get a life'."

Today Bruce Oldfield is a happy man. Still sparky and handsome, he runs a small but exclusive couture house from an elegant showroom in Beauchamp Place, supplying sumptuous eveningwear to the upper echelons of British and American society. Ladies who lunch love him.

"I run a very small business," he says simply. "I wouldn't want it to be any bigger. I'm not sure I'd be any good at joining the big bad world."

Oldfield doesn't blame British fashion for our lack of global commercial success. "The British public is not interested in clothes," he points out. "The nearest we get to an international conglomerate is M&S."

Having made the transition from cool to esteemed, Oldfield is well-placed to pinpoint the problems. "After the war," he says, "Britain was de-skilled by the need for cheap clothing. The workers were replaced with machines. There are now very few factories in the UK that can produce any kind of desirable garments in any kind of quantity. It's frightening."

The British government has recognised this problem and last week announced a £1.5m handout. Oldfield doesn't believe this will solve the problem. "What went hand in hand with the need for cheaper clothing was the inherent notion that clothing was a little bit silly, a little bit frivolous. They are quite puritanical, the British. It's considered poor taste to show your wealth. Even now I have customers who wouldn't want their staff to know how much they have spent on a dress. The British don't like show-offs and they don't like clothes that are showy-offy."

The only section of the British public truly interested in fashion, Oldfield maintains, doesn't have the income to support designers. "They are all under 25 and spend what they have in Top Shop. Serious earners have many different calls on their income. Private education, for example."

He is quick to point out how ironic it is that a country that spends relatively little on designer goods is renowned for producing the most creative students in the world. "Most of them, certainly the ones who get noticed, are wacky. They are encouraged to treat fashion like caricature. They're told: 'You're so outrageous and cutting edge. Go on, go on, do it. Make something else that won't sell.' If they are given the platform to do that, of course they will, then they'll sink without trace. Someone will put money behind them, they'll have a few seasons, but they have to get real in a very short space of time. Most don't."

Oldfield believes we are churning out too many designers. From the original five, London Fashion Week now has 49 shows and over 150 exhibitors. "I'm a governor of the London Institute, which covers St Martins and the London College of Fashion, but I'm not always sure our fashion schools give out the right messages."

Oldfield's own fashion education began after following a career in art. "I only studied at St Martins for eight months. I found it a little over-intellectual. I didn't want to hear: 'The bike has two wheels, so design a collection around the bike.' I have imagination and creativity. But the practical side was great: we were trained to cut clothes, make clothes, design clothes; we were taught how to enhance the form. That's what good design is all about - it's not about engaging somebody's mind in some kind of philosophical debate."

So how does he feel when a designer says he is inspired by homeless people? "I laugh. No, actually I don't laugh. I think, what system is producing that kind of a response?"

But it's often these same designers that get taken up by a foreign company with lots of money and plenty of products to sell. Oldfield seems almost wistful on the subject. "I got sent the Dior catalogue the other day. It's very, very beautiful, a glamorous book, but there's not a garment in it. They are only selling bags. What Galliano produces is fabulous, it's wonderful, it makes good press. But Galliano doesn't have to worry about whether or not his clothes are selling. Our young designers can't hope to compete."

The news isn't all bad, though. The UK clothing and textile industry is the seventh largest in the country and at first glance, the designer sector also looks relatively healthy. Since 1990 it has grown threefold and is currently worth £600m - but compare that with Calvin Klein's turnover of £2.76b.

"Rifat Ozbek was the first designer based here to understand the system and milk it," Oldfield says. "He chose Britain as a creative launchpad, then when he moved to Paris, there was a big brouhaha about him abandoning London. I thought, why not? Paris gets more buyers and press."

Presumably this idea would not go down well with the British Fashion Council. But Oldfield is known for being outspoken - not in a dramatic, fashiony way, he simply knows his business. Twenty-five years on, one of the original bad boys may no longer make it into the gossip columns, but he makes very nice dresses at very nice prices. Did he have to tone down his creativity in order to appeal to his more conservative clientele?

"I know my customers - I know where they go on holiday, where they live, what car they drive. A great preponderance of them are aged between 35 and 55, but these women don't want to be told they are getting on and that they should be wearing something a bit more sensible."

Is he envious of his international contemporaries whose names adorn the waistbands of underpants across the world? "Would I be any happier if I had shops all around the world, perfumes and bedlinen? I could - it's a good name, people know it - but I don't want that kind of pressure and I don't need to earn more money. I'd be bored on a big, big yacht. I don't want a Rolls-Royce, thank you very much. Is Calvin Klein any happier with what he's got than I am with what I've got? Probably not."

It's Tuesday September 26 2000. 7.30pm. Queues are forming outside a warehouse in Victoria in readiness for the launch of Alexander McQueen's spring/summer collection. At the Lord Mayor's residence in Mansion House, Bruce Oldfield is celebrating his 50th birthday with a fashion show and charity auction, sponsored by Krug champagne in aid of Barnado's. Oldfield's runway is without sensationalist fashion ploys; his guests lack cool factor. But the models and assembled ladies display some of the most sumptous and elegant couture gowns in the world. Oldfield has won his international acclaim. Even if not a lot of people know it.

"The nearest we get to an international conglomerate is M&S." Having made the transition from cool to esteemed, Oldfield is well-placed to pinpoint the problems. "After the war," he says, "Britain was de-skilled by the need for cheap clothing. The workers were replaced with machines. There are now very few factories in the UK that can produce any kind of desirable garments in any kind of quantity. It's frightening." The British government has recognised this problem and last week announced a £1.5m handout. Oldfield doesn't believe this will solve the problem. "What went hand in hand with the need for cheaper clothing was the inherent notion that clothing was a little bit silly, a little bit frivolous. They are quite puritanical, the British. It's considered poor taste to show your wealth. Even now I have customers who wouldn't want their staff to know how much they have spent on a dress. The British don't like show-offs and they don't like clothes that are showy-offy." The only section of the British public truly interested in fashion, Oldfield maintains, doesn't have the income to support designers. "They are all under 25 and spend what they have in Top Shop. Serious earners have many different calls on their income. Private education, for example." He is quick to point out how ironic it is that a country that spends relatively little on designer goods is renowned for producing the most creative students in the world. "Most of them, certainly the ones who get noticed, are wacky. They are encouraged to treat fashion like caricature. They're told: 'You're so outrageous and cutting edge. Go on, go on, do it. Make something else that won't sell.' If they are given the platform to do that, of course they will, then they'll sink without trace. Someone will put money behind them, they'll have a few seasons, but they have to get real in a very short space of time. Most don't." Oldfield believes we are churning out too many designers. From the original five, London Fashion Week now has 49 shows and over 150 exhibitors. "I'm a governor of the London Institute, which covers St Martins and the London College of Fashion, but I'm not always sure our fashion schools give out the right messages." Oldfield's own fashion education began after following a career in art. "I only studied at St Martins for eight months. I found it a little over-intellectual. I didn't want to hear: 'The bike has two wheels, so design a collection around the bike.' I have imagination and creativity. But the practical side was great: we were trained to cut clothes, make clothes, design clothes; we were taught how to enhance the form. That's what good design is all about - it's not about engaging somebody's mind in some kind of philosophical debate." So how does he feel when a designer says he is inspired by homeless people? "I laugh. No, actually I don't laugh. I think, what system is producing that kind of a response?" But it's often these same designers that get taken up by a foreign company with lots of money and plenty of products to sell. Oldfield seems almost wistful on the subject. "I got sent the Dior catalogue the other day. It's very, very beautiful, a glamorous book, but there's not a garment in it. They are only selling bags. What Galliano produces is fabulous, it's wonderful, it makes good press. But Galliano doesn't have to worry about whether or not his clothes are selling. Our young designers can't hope to compete." The news isn't all bad, though. The UK clothing and textile industry is the seventh largest in the country and at first glance, the designer sector also looks relatively healthy. Since 1990 it has grown threefold and is currently worth £600m - but compare that with Calvin Klein's turnover of £2.76b. "Rifat Ozbek was the first designer based here to understand the system and milk it," Oldfield says. "He chose Britain as a creative launchpad, then when he moved to Paris, there was a big brouhaha about him abandoning London. I thought, why not? Paris gets more buyers and press." Presumably this idea would not go down well with the British Fashion Council. But Oldfield is known for being outspoken - not in a dramatic, fashiony way, he simply knows his business. Twenty-five years on, one of the original bad boys may no longer make it into the gossip columns, but he makes very nice dresses at very nice prices. Did he have to tone down his creativity in order to appeal to his more conservative clientele? "I know my customers - I know where they go on holiday, where they live, what car they drive. A great preponderance of them are aged between 35 and 55, but these women don't want to be told they are getting on and that they should be wearing something a bit more sensible." Is he envious of his international contemporaries whose names adorn the waistbands of underpants across the world? "Would I be any happier if I had shops all around the world, perfumes and bedlinen? I could - it's a good name, people know it - but I don't want that kind of pressure and I don't need to earn more money. I'd be bored on a big, big yacht. I don't want a Rolls-Royce, thank you very much. Is Calvin Klein any happier with what he's got than I am with what I've got? Probably not." It's Tuesday September 26 2000. 7.30pm. Queues are forming outside a warehouse in Victoria in readiness for the launch of Alexander McQueen's spring/summer collection. At the Lord Mayor's residence in Mansion House, Bruce Oldfield is celebrating his 50th birthday with a fashion show and charity auction, sponsored by Krug champagne in aid of Barnado's. Oldfield's runway is without sensationalist fashion ploys; his guests lack cool factor. But the models and assembled ladies display some of the most sumptous and elegant couture gowns in the world. Oldfield has won his international acclaim. Even if not a lot of people know it.

webTitle: Style: Judith Mackrell, a dance critic

fields.headline: Something in the way she moves
fields.standfirst: As the Guardian's dance critic,  Judith Mackrell thought she had seen it all when it came to unnatural poses and weird ways of walking. But then she got a ticket to a fashion show...
fields.trailText: As the Guardian's dance critic, Judith Mackrell thought she had seen it all when it came to unnatural poses and weird ways of walking. But then she got a ticket to a fashion show...
fields.body:
As a dance critic, I'm used to looking at extreme, stylised bodies with unnatural habits of movement. Ballet dancers in particular look like no other breed, with their duck-like walks, their hyper-arched backs and flattened chests. But when I was given tickets to watch the two closing shows of New York Fashion Week, my professional cool was blown entirely as I witnessed for the first time the weird physical demeanour of the models.

I'm not talking thin here. Even though some of the women looked painful to me (dancers may not carry much flesh but they do have muscles), I could see that the models had been bred to function as abstract coat-hangers rather than individual performers. In a world in which clothes are judged more as concepts than as real-life outfits, I could see that the skinnier the models were, the more usefully they resembled the original lines and sketches of the designers' notebooks.

What I didn't get was the bizarrely strained and graceless walk every model in New York seemed to have adopted as she (or he) clumped down the catwalk in next spring's most desirable clothes. Osteopaths and physiotherapists would have been in shock at the nightmare curvature of the spines on display. Hips were thrust forward at vertiginous angles, torsos rocked back and chins jutted out in an attitude of grim agony.

Even odder was the movement that passed as a walk among the women - a curiously stilted prance which, executed in teetering high heels, resulted in a kind of juddering, angry stomp as they paraded by. The fact that all the models had, in addition, to zip down the catwalk at high speed to get through the show, meant that they looked as if they'd all been rounded up for some sadistic boot camp march.

Since the models at both shows were following the same routine, I assume there are people out there coaching them to walk this way. But I can't figure out why. When dancers move unnaturally, there's nearly always a good reason. In classical ballet they labour to turn out their hips so that they can lift their legs higher and make themselves look grander, more visible on the stage. They dance on the tips of their toes so that they can move with brilliant speed and create the illusion of defying gravity. When modern dancers contort their bodies into harsh introverted angles, they are creating a kind of expressive human sculpture. But models are meant to be icons of beauty and glamour, so why were they making themselves look so absurd?

The drastic S bend in the spine I could just about understand in terms of its enforced elongation of the waist - the cut of certain clothes might, as a result, be better displayed. But what function lay in the clunky walk and the grumpy set of the chin, which simply had the effect of making the models look as if they hated being in their clothes and couldn't wait to kick off their shoes? Why would we in the audience want to buy what the models themselves seemed to loathe wearing?

This angry body language might have suited designs that were dark and edgy - rebel chic worn by self-consciously rebellious chicks. But I was watching Donna Karan and Calvin Klein, designers who aim to make women look as if they were born beautiful and expensive. What A-list celeb or high-flying exec would have a fantasy of walking into a room like a sullen, dysfunctional brat?

It was ironic, too, that the Karan show was accompanied by a loud, funky soundtrack, which had most of the punters and the press discreetly boogieing in their seats. The models, though, remained resolutely impervious to the music's rhythms and energy, even though they would have looked so much more fun and more desirable had they sashayed down the catwalk like dancers.

A little spring, fluency or grace would certainly have produced more flattering movement in the delicate, wittily layered organza skirts in Karan's collection, or in the lithe, sporty dresses of Klein. Yet it wasn't as if the models were clumsy clots. I was sitting near the end of the catwalk and so had a perfect view as they were directed away from the hectic glare of the lights and cameras, and back to their changing room. The transformation was startling as these stiff automatons suddenly relaxed into their natural posture, elegantly and expertly navigating their way up a steep and dimly-lit staircase.

I could only conclude that the current catwalk prance is an extreme example of those eccentric affectations that have been assumed by elite classes throughout history. A bizarre, impractical stylisation of behaviour whose function is simply to set apart the group who understand its code. I had thought myself reasonably knowing about fashion, but as no one else was batting an eye at the grotesque body language on show, I realised that my own startled giggles marked me as a total outsider.
