fields.headline: Mixed fortunes for Uefa survivors
fields.trailText: There were mixed fortunes for the two remaining British teams in the Uefa Cup when the draw for the second round of the competition was made this morning.
fields.body:
There were mixed fortunes for the two remaining British teams in the Uefa Cup when the draw for the second round of the competition was made this morning.

Liverpool, who struggled to overcome Rapid Bucharset, have been rewarded for their pitiful efforts with a favourable tie against Slovan Liberec of the Czech Republic.

But Celtic, conquerors of HJK Helskini, face a much sterner test against Bordeaux.

Celtic can at least take comfort in playing their second leg at home - they visit France on October 26. Liverpool will play their first leg at Anfield, before travelling to the Czech Republic on November 9.

webTitle: BBC appoints LWT's Laura Mackie to join drama division

fields.headline: BBC gives key drama role to LWT's Mackie
fields.trailText: 11.30am:The BBC has confirmed that LWT's deputy controller of drama, Laura Mackie, is to join its new drama division, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC has confirmed that LWT's deputy controller of drama, Laura Mackie, is to join its new drama division.

Ms Mackie, who has been deputy to LWT controller Jo Wright since November 1999, has worked on London's Burning and Ross Kemp's A Christmas Carol script. She will join the BBC in the new year.

Earlier this month, the corporation announced that it had poached Granada drama controller Simon Lewis and his deputy, Sue Hogg, and it is reported to be trying to lure Cold Feet producer Christine Langan.

The BBC is still finalising the structure of its drama commissioning and production operations, after offering head of drama serials Jane Tranter the top job. Ms Tranter has yet to confirm her acceptance of the job, which, it is understood, depends on a restructure of commissioning and production functions.

fields.headline: Bring back my lunch
fields.standfirst: Our average midday break lasts 38 minutes and consists of £1.99 worth of stodge, says a new survey.  Matthew Fort calls for the return of a great British institution
fields.trailText: Our average midday break lasts 38 minutes and consists of £1.99 worth of stodge, says a new survey. Matthew Fort calls for the return of a great British institution.
fields.body:
Should you find yourself in any town in southern Italy around midday, you should be prepared for traffic jams. People will be hurrying out or home for lunch. Lunch, for southern Italians (there has been a sad erosion of the respect for lunch in the north) is sacrosanct, just as it still is for the Spanish and, perhaps, the French. But we British, it seems, have lost our appetite for that meal.

Hounded by pressure of the workplace, terrified of being seen to waste time, subservient to the business practices of the Americans, we have given up on lunch. According to a survey by Datamonitor reported this week, we spend an average of 38 minutes and a miserable £1.99 to scrabble the wodge and stodge that pass for food into our mouths as we twitch at each passing second.

Quite aside from the disastrous consequences for the nation's health - as we all know stress and inadequate diet pile up the coronaries, back complaints and nervous breakdowns - it is bad for business. Without adequate nutrition (and, ideally, the nap that should come after), we lose concentration, become tired more easily, and lose our temper with our co-workers, who have, of course, already lost their temper with us. And all that motivates this lemming-like rush to self-destruction is fear.

It is no coincidence that the height of Britain's power, self-confidence and productivity coincided with the height of lunch. The Victorians were mighty eaters. Five courses for lunch? No problem. A reasonable man could easily manage six or seven, and then go back to work before stuffing away a similar - if not a greater - number of dishes with accompanying wines in the evening.

You might argue that they didn't live that long as a result. Perhaps that's true, but neither did they die of stress or whinge about their bad backs either.

The Victorians, and to an even greater extent the Edwardians, appreciated the value of the rituals of lunch. It isn't simply feeding and watering the inner man or woman. If the sole justification for lunch came from topping up with fuel for the day, there would be no reason for continuing its practice at all. A simple injection or pill would serve just as well.

No, the lunch table is a forum for social exchange, for communication and discussion. The lunch table is a neutral zone in the warfare of the workplace. Quite apart from the refreshing rest from the pressures of business that a break for lunch represents, it is also the means by which we come to a better understanding of the people we work with or those with whom we wish to do business. Lunch represents the opportunity to extend relationships beyond the mere mechanics of deals and decision-making to embrace the dynamics of human behaviour. You're never likely to learn those by stuffing sandwiches at your desk.

Besides, lunching has a civilising effect on even the most obdurate of opponents. It is a little publicised footnote to the Paris negotiations that led to the end of the Vietnam war that several of the key sessions were held over lunch. As an American spokesman admitted ruefully at the time: "It is more difficult to threaten to bomb someone back into the Stone Age when you have just passed them the salt."

Perhaps we shouldn't be surprised by the lapsing of lunch. It's just another casualty in a general degradation in the national rituals of eating. Who eats tea any more? Whither elevenses and high tea? Fewer and fewer people, it seems, have the time or the inclination to sit down and eat together, whether at work or at home. But the abandonment of lunch as a serious activity has had social consequences quite as serious as those affecting health and commerce.

The sharp rise in divorce in this country can be attributed, in part at least, to the loss of lunch. If you have a reasonable lunch break, say two hours or so, then you have time to leave your office, visit your paramour, and return, relaxed and refreshed for the afternoon session, before going to home and hearth at the expected hour in the evening.

Give up lunch, and then the only time in a normal working day in which to exorcise your lust is after work and before you go home - or, tackier still, on "business trips" - and that can lead to accidental and painful exposure. "I'm just going to slip off early this afternoon," you tell your colleagues. "Little Mabel is in her school show, and I don't want to disappoint her."

They nod sympathetically. Then, some hours later, the worried partner rings up, wondering where the other is. "Oh," say the sympathetic colleagues, "So-and-so slipped off early to see your little Mabel's performance in the school show." "Funny. She isn't in the show." It would all be so different if we kept a civilised lunch break.

Of course, many people may see lunch from a slightly different perspective from me. I take lunch seriously. I lunch professionally. While some may look on lunch as a brief holiday from work, as a dispensable frivolity or even as a distraction from the business of business, lunching for me is business. While others relax and unwind over a dish of this and that and a glass or two of red infuriator, I have to wade my way through three, and sometimes more, courses and savage a wine list into the bargain, all in the interests of data-gathering or research in the field. It is a hard, demanding and, generally speaking, thankless task, and I get no sympathy from anyone for it. But each day lunch presents me with the possibility of sensory pleasures enhanced by the theatre of human activity. That's lunch for you.

Lunch is good. Lunch is fun. Lunch is pleasurable. Lunch is civilised and civilising. Lunch revives and restores. Lunch benefits us all. It is time to start a movement to guarantee us a decent lunch, every working day, as a basic human right.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: No Bat for Brad, Life of Brian still on the bright side, Vittorio Storaro honoured, Samuel L Jackson avoids Merseyside, news of the weird, and the latest celebrity gossip
fields.body:
 It seems that reports that Brad Pitt would be easing himself into the batmobile were premature. Pi director Darren Aronofsky (currently enjoying festival success with Requiem for a Dream) will be scripting and directing the caped crusader's fifth cinematic outing (see our story), but he told America's TV Guide that Pitt will not be involved. "The media put two and two together and got seven," he said, explaining that he and Pitt had indeed been spotted around Tinseltown but were discussing an entirely different matter. "I did meet with Brad, but we were actually talking about the science fiction [film] that I'm writing," he says. "[Pitt] had seen Requiem for a Dream and really dug it, and wanted to meet me. The word 'Batman' didn't even come up."

 A poll by magazine Total Film names Monty Python's The Life of Brian (pictured) the funniest film ever. The 1979 Python film was originally banned in various parts of Britain and America due to what was deemed its offensively blasphemous content. Leslie Nielsen's Airplane (1980) came a close second.

 Cinematographer Vittorio Storaro, whose credits include Apocalypse Now, The Last Emperor, and Reds, is to be honoured by the American Society of Cinematographers with its Lifetime Achievement Award. Storaro's work is most closely associated with Bernardo Bertolucci, with whom he worked on The Last Tango in Paris and The Sheltering Sky. Director Francis Ford Coppola will present the award at the cinematographer's gala banquet on February 18.

 Samuel L Jackson could find himself on the wrong side of Merseysiders (definitely the wrong place to be). The star, who is due in Liverpool to film 51st State alongside Robert Carlyle, is apparently refusing to stay in the fragrant sea-port. Jackson has elected to reside in the more salubrious surroundings of Southport - a 40-minute drive from the set.

 News of the weird: A UFO expert is investigating claims from various American women that they have been ravished by aliens - who look like Leonardo DiCaprio. Investigator Donald Worley said that one woman, Diana, from Missouri, claimed the space Casanova made her cheat on her husband - but it was "sex beyond anything on earth".

 America's Star magazine suggests that Courteney Cox and David Arquette's 15-month marriage is on the rocks. A so-called friend of the pair said: "It's not a question of there being anyone else involved, it's a case of two huge battling egos. They were in a restaurant just weeks ago and couldn't stop sniping at each other.

 Russell Crowe has apparently taken Meg Ryan home to Australia to meet his parents. The pair boarded separate flights to Australia and hid out at his secluded ranch outside the New South Wales town of Grafton. Said a friend: "Russell couldn't wait for the woman he loves to meet the parents he adores. It's a confirmation that he and Meg are serious about each other and wedding bells will be ringing as soon as her divorce from Dennis Quaid comes through."

fields.headline: Overexposed:  London
fields.body:
London is most definitely in fashion. No, no, no, we're not talking about dear old London Fashion Week. London has become a fashion statement in itself.

The union flag was always going to be a little bit too outré (not to mention vaguely football hooligan-like) as a fashion pattern. But London Style has far more benefits in the aesthetic and ironic departments. So forget about Liam and Patsy wrapping themselves up in swathes of red, blue and white (didn't do them any good, did it?) and think more Sophie Ellis-Bextor in her Peckham T-shirt.

But therein lies the rub. We British hate nothing more than being told that we're cool. One proclamation that "The British are coming" or predictions of "Britcool" were enough to kill the British film industry in the 80s and the music industry in the 90s, and the Liam-in-a-flag shoot is a salutary lesson to the current Civic Pride Chic. There is a treacherous line, when wearing such an item, between looking ironic and looking like a tourist. As any schoolboy can tell you, you don't wear your school scarf unless you want to get a good kicking.

But perhaps that is the ol' English cynicism coming out. Maybe we should celebrate this fashion infatuation with our lovely capital. Ruling the waves again and all that. I rather think, though, that the best way to pay due style homage to this sceptred city is to do it in proper British style - with dry, British understatement. And that means no more T-shirts celebrating Notting Hill. And, please, no more keychains that tell us that, oh yes, London Swings.

fields.headline: Agencies on alert as Unilever sells top brands
fields.trailText: 11am: Unilever's ad agencies are on the alert following the announcement that it is selling several key brands, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Unilever's advertising agencies are this week on the alert following the announcement that it is selling several key brands in exchange for regulatory clearance for its £13.9bn acquisition of US food giant Bestfoods.

J Walter Thompson, Mother and Lowe Lintas & Partners are the most likely to lose out, as Unilever today announced plans to sell its Oxo, Batchelors' Cup a Soup and Supernoodles brands.

Andrew Medd, a partner at Mother, said: "We were informed ahead of the announcement that this was happening. We just have to wait to see what comes next.

"The deal has been approved, but how it effects our relationship with Unilever and the brand is not yet certain. The only thing that is clear is that the brands will have to be sold."

A source close to the move commented: "Our continued relationship with Unilever depends entirely on who buys the brand. Clearly we would not want to work for one of Unilever's main competitors."

Mother won the Supernoodles account from Ammirati Puris Lintas in June 1997. The change of agency coincided with an increase in the brand's ad spend from £1.2m to £6m.

JWT works on a sizeable portion of the Unilever foods portfolio, including the £6m Oxo account, which it has held for 40 years. Lowe Lintas & Partners has handled the £5m Cup a Soup range since 1996.

Unilever will hang on to Bestfoods top-selling brands, including Knorr soups, Hellman's mayonnaise, Ambrosia desserts, Pot Noodle, Bovril and Marmite.

The European Commission granted conditional approval of the deal, which will create the world's biggest pure foods producer, after Unilever made concessions to resolve competition concerns.

In terms of annual sales, the brands being sold are worth £300m. Other brands to be sold include Bean Feast, Royco in Europe, McDonnels in Europe, Bla Band in Scandinavia and Bestfoods' Lesieur mayonnaise.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are pig sick of the Olympics. One in particular is not far off putting its foot through the telly
fields.trailText: Another Premiership manager has joined the race for Sol Campbell. Newcastle boss Bobby Robson wants the England defender to shore up his leaky back line and - mindful that Spurs could lose Campbell for nothing in the summer on a Bosman free - is preparing a £5m bid.
fields.body:
Another Premiership manager has joined the race for Sol Campbell. Newcastle boss Bobby Robson wants the England defender to shore up his leaky back line and - mindful that Spurs could lose Campbell for nothing in the summer on a Bosman free - is preparing a £5m bid.

Newcastle are also planning to add Aston Villa wing-back Mark Delaney to their defence, according to Teamtalk.

Newcastle - my, aren't they busy? - have agreed a £700,000 deal for University of Chile midfielder Clarence Acuna.

Arsenal are about to make a £6.9m offer for Feyenoord goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek, claims Planet Football. The Polish international, last season's Dutch Footballer of the Year, is interested in becoming David Seaman's successor and is "believed to have told close friends that he thinks a deal could be done within a month".

Chicago Fire striker Josh Wolff is interesting Liverpool, according to Planet Football. The 23-year-old has impressed in the US Olympic side, scoring two goals as the States progressed to the semi-finals of the tournament. However, any move for Wolff, who is quick and can also play on the wing, will have to wait until the US Major League play-offs are concluded in mid-October.

Espanyol have contacted Rangers to see if their £12m offer for striker Raul Tamudo still stands, reports onefootball.com. The Spanish club are £22m in debt and are resigned to losing the 22-year-old.

And Espanyol may also dispense with Argentinian utility player Mauro Navas - Sunderland are showing an interest.

Middlesbrough are ready to risk £3m on Lucien Mettomo, says Teamtalk. Blackburn pulled out of a £4.6m deal for the 23-year-old Cameroon defender last week when it emerged he is recovering from a serious knee injury. However, Boro reckon Mettomo is fully fit and will contact St Etienne next week to complete the signing.

Wimbledon are on the verge of landing Sunderland defender Darren Holloway, according to Teamtalk. The two parties are still discussing terms, but Dons manager Terry Burton expects the deal to be completed next week: "I don't anticipate anything happening until after the weekend as he is still carrying a slight ankle injury so there is no rush."

St Mirren have signed former Aston Villa, Blackburn and Leicester striker Graham Fenton on a Bosman free from Stoke.

webTitle: KPN and NTT DoCoMo plan to launch mobile portal

fields.headline: KPN and NTT DoCoMo join up to launch mobile portal
fields.standfirst: Japanese giant opens UK division
fields.trailText: Dutch telecoms company KPN and Japanese cellphone giant NTT DoCoMo plan to launch a pan-European mobile internet portal in 2001. Jason Deans reports.
fields.body:
Dutch telecoms operator KPN and Japanese cellphone giant NTT DoCoMo are joining forces to launch a pan-European mobile internet portal next year.

The portal, which the two partners intend to launch in early 2001, will offer KPN Mobile's Wap services and other features based on DoCoMo's I-mode mobile internet technology, which has proved popular in Japan.

At a later date the KPN/DoCoMo service will be upgraded to take advantage of higher-speed wireless data transmission services, including general packet radio services (GPRS) and third generation, or universal mobile telecommunications system (UMTS), applications.

The service, which will enable users to access news, sporting events, mobile banking and e-commerce, will be introduced first in Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium, where KPN Mobile operates wireless networks.

DoCoMo, which owns a 15% stake in KPN Mobile, is also considering extending its wireless internet joint venture with America Online into Europe.

fields.headline: Japanese phone giant launches UK division
fields.standfirst: KPN and NTT DoCoMo to launch Euro mobile portal
fields.trailText: 11am: Japanese cell phone giant NTT DoCoMo is to invest £3m in a UK subsidiary that will develop mobile multimedia services for Europe, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Japanese cell phone giant NTT DoCoMo is to invest £3m in a UK subsidiary that will develop mobile multimedia services for Europe.

The wholely owned DoCoMo subsidiary is to be based in London and is expected to be open for business in early November, with around 10 employees.

DoCoMo has been at the forefront of the development of Japan's popular I-mode mobile internet technology.

The new unit is expected to work closely with European mobile operators including Hutchison 3G UK - which holds one of the UK third generation mobile licences - and Dutch outfit KPN Mobile, in which DoCoMo has minority stakes.

fields.trailText: One of the four autumn projects that Francis Ford Coppola's American Zoetrope production company will be working on is CQ, the feature directing debut of Francis's son Roman
fields.body:
One of the four autumn projects that Francis Ford Coppola's American Zoetrope production company will be working on is CQ, the feature directing debut of Francis's son Roman (pictured left, in Star Wars: Episode 1).

The younger Coppola also wrote the screenplay, which tells of a young American film-maker in Paris in the late 1960s who takes over directing a low-budget sci-fi movie set in the year 2000.

Coppola Jr, a graduate of NYU film school, has mostly directly music videos to date, but as a teenager he worked on his father's films in various production capacities, and directed visual effects and second-unit shooting of Coppola's Bram Stoker's Dracula.

"We believe in giving the young people some real responsibility early on," Coppola said. "It's [Roman's] time to go out there on the high wire and the family will support him."

Apparently Sofia - whose feature film debut The Virgin Suicides was widely acclaimed on its release earlier this year, gave her brother key casting help, repaying Roman for second-unit contributions on The Virgin Suicides.

Meanwhile their mother Eleanor is filming a documentary about the making of CQ, as she did with Hearts of Darkness, her tale of the nightmare behind Coppola's legendary Apocalypse Now.

fields.headline: Casting couch
fields.trailText: Nic Cage joins forces with U-571 director, Susan Sarandon and Goldie Hawn set for Bangers, Caine and Keaton team up, and Connolly makes a good impression
fields.body:
 Nicolas Cage is to join forces with U-571 director Jonathan Mostow to star as a widowed father who's forced to raise his son by himself. The as yet unnamed project, based on the 1962 movie The Courtship of Eddie's Father, is being financed by Warner Bros. Cage has just finished filming on Captain Corelli's Mandolin, and is set to work next on Spike Jonze's project, Adaptation.

 Susan Sarandon and Goldie Hawn are in negotiations to play the title roles in The Banger Sisters, a comedy about the reunion of two groupies who were best friends during their wild rock 'n' roll days. One sister, who is now a waitress (Hawn), is only too happy to wax nostalgic about the good old days, while the other - a prominent socialite (Sarandon) - is keen to hide her past.

 Michael Caine (pictured) and Michael Keaton are to co-star in the independent picture Quicksand, an action thriller that will mark Caine's third collaboration with director John Mackenzie. Caine will play a washed-up film star who unwittingly becomes entangled in the Cote d'Azur underworld. Keaton plays a New York banker who gets sucked in when he arrives in Monaco to investigate irregularities.

 Billy Connolly is in negotiations to play French painter Camille Pissarro in Gauguin, a low-budget feature film about the life of fellow impressionist Paul Gauguin. The $5m film, directed by Mario Andreacchio, will be shot in Austria and Australia. It tells the story of Gauguin's rejection of his comfortable life as a stockbroker to paint and his first trip to Tahiti at the turn of the 20th century. Although Willem Dafoe had been attached to the title role, an 'upcoming Anglo-Saxon star' is apparently now being considered.

webTitle: Net debut for Blair Witch 2 trailer

fields.headline: Net debut for Blair Witch 2 trailer
fields.trailText: The first trailer for the eagerly awaited sequel Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows, has just been released exclusively by Yahoo on the internet
fields.body:
Can Artisan repeat the phenomenal success of The Blair Witch Project? They certainly hope so, and are attempting to recreate the hype that bolstered last year's release.

The first <A HREF=""trailer for the eagerly awaited sequel Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows, has just been released exclusively by Yahoo on the internet.

And the official site skilfully suggests that this film - like its predecessor - tells of events that really happened, and aims to spook the unwary into believing that the big bad witch really is out there, somewhere.

Last year's Blair Witch Project, which grossed more than $140m (£96m) worldwide, used the internet to conduct a hugely successful word-of-mouth advertising campaign, and its makers are hoping for a similar success with this year's release. The original Blair Witch site cleverly enhanced the documentary style of the film, deliberately blurring the lines between fact and fiction.

This year's official website again suggests we're witnessing events that really happened, and tells the background stories of the main characters - all respondents to an advert posted on the internet offering 'Blair Witch Hunt' tours.

The one-minute, 40-second trailer for the sequel, set in present-day Burkittsville, reflects the themes of the new movie - which we are promised will delve deeper into the legend.

The film opens in cinemas in the UK on October 27 - just in time for Halloween.

webTitle: Independent on Sunday to relaunch Reality magazine

fields.headline: Independent on Sunday to relaunch Reality magazine
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The Independent on Sunday is to relaunch Reality magazine and appoint two senior editorial staff to the arts and culture pages, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Independent on Sunday is to relaunch Reality magazine and appoint two senior editorial staff to the arts and culture pages.

Reality has poached former Femail - the Daily Mail's women's section - features editor Gavanndra Hodge, who will become editor Hero Brown's deputy.

From 15 October, Reality, which was launched in March, will become larger and carry new weekly columns from Simon Carr and Victoria Coren.

The Independent on Sunday is also bringing in the Daily Telegraph's former theatre reviewer, Kate Bassett, as theatre critic, while the Evening Standard's Sholto Byrnes joins as diary editor.

The move represents the second content revamp since editor Janet Street Porter joined the paper in July 1999.

The paper's sales had grown slightly in the last ABCs in August, but there has been a 77,006 year-on-year decline in full-rate sales since 1998.

webTitle: Universal and NTL unveil UK movie channel

fields.headline: Universal first Hollywood studio to launch UK movie channel
fields.trailText: 10.15am: US film giant Universal Studios and cable operator NTL are going head-to-head with Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB by launching a UK movie channel, it will be announced this morning. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
US film giant Universal Studios and cable operator NTL are going head-to-head with Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB by launching a UK movie channel.

The surprise deal could strain the complex relationship between French media conglomerate Vivendi and BSkyB's parent company, News Corporation, as Vivendi owns 25% of BSkyB and is on the verge of merging with Universal's owner, Seagram.

Vivendi's chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, wants to convert his stake into a holding in Sky Global Networks, the company comprised of News Corporation's digital operations. Sky Global will float soon, and the ambitiousMr Messier is keen to have a role in a company valued at £28bn.

The NTL channel, to be called The Studio, combines the UK's largest broadband company with a major Hollywood studio, which has a back catalogue of blockbuster films including The Mummy and Notting Hill. The 50/50 joint venture launches within six months and will be available on all platforms, screening over 1,000 films from several studios.

The Studio will broadcast for 18 hours a day, seven days a week, with NTL subscribers the first to access the service. The channel will be available at basic tier entry-level at no extra cost.

The channel will be managed by Universal Studios Networks UK, which runs the Sci Fi channel on Sky Digital. The films already booked for the channel include Babe, Carlito's Way and True Lies.

Janet Goldsmith, managing director of Universal Studios Networks UK, said: "NTL has a strong track record in developing innovative packages and a forward-thinking approach to this market. We are delighted to be working in partnership with them."

NTL is consolidating its position as the UK's leading cable company by buying up content, having signed a five-year carriage deal with BSkyB this month. The arrangement is expected to produce pay-per-view football channels, as both companies have stakes in Premiership clubs.

Steve Wagner, managing director of marketing at NTL, said: "The channel dovetails well with our recent BSkyB deal and leverages the popularity of movies to encourage many more consumers to watch highly desirable content."

webTitle: Liberty Media to take stake in Sky Global

fields.headline: Vivendi poised to take stake in NewsCorp
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Vivendi is next in line to take a stake in NewsCorp, following yesterday's news that US cable company Liberty Media will take a stake in Sky Global, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Vivendi is next in line to take a stake in NewsCorp, following yesterday's news that US cable company Liberty Media will take a stake in Sky Global.

The complex deal sees Rupert Murdoch's media conglomerate take Liberty's 21% holding in interactive programme guide-maker Gemstar-TV Guide, raising its stake to 43%. In return, Liberty will increase its holding in NewsCorp from 7% to 18% and acquire 4.7% of Sky Global.

Mr Murdoch, chairman of NewsCorp, said: "We have enjoyed a long, productive and mutually beneficial relationship with Liberty Media and Dr John Malone, one of the giants of the media industry.

"That John has chosen to become our single largest non-voting equity owner is as strong an endorsement as we could get of our strategic direction and operational performance."

Mr Murdoch's relationship with Jean-Marie Messier, the Vivendi chairman, will now come under scrutiny, as Mr Messier is known to be keen to take a stake in Sky Global. Vivendi owns 25% of NewsCorp's UK satellite broadcaster, BSkyB, but wants to convert its interest into a holding in Sky Global.

Sky Global's planned flotation is one of the most eagerly anticipated IPOs in years, with Mr Murdoch putting a value of up to $40bn (£28bn) on the company. Mr Messier has ambitious plans for Vivendi, as demonstrated by the company's planned £23bn merger with Seagram, owner of film giant Universal Studios. The merger is awaiting clearance from European Commission regulators, but both parties are confident it will go through.

If Mr Murdoch does not further dilute his holding in NewsCorp to benefit Messier, then Vivendi may decide to take the company head on.

webTitle: Chris Smith to launch culture and arts website

fields.headline: Chris Smith to launch culture and arts website
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Culture secretary Chris Smith is to launch an all-encompassing culture and the arts website. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith is to launch an all-encompassing culture and the arts website that he has already dubbed the "Channel 4 of the internet".

Culture Online (COL) will exist initially on the internet, although there are musings about taking it on to other digital platforms.

Essentially, COL will aim to present and explain the best of British culture and heritage, as a key resource for the whole population, especially schools.

The site and proposed digital TV channel will tap into the UK's national museum and gallery collections, as well as films, music and stage performances.

For instance, someone studying Shakespeare will be able to download a text of a play, watch a performance online, take part in discussion groups and call up costume designs and programmes from past performances. Ticket booking will also be an integrated part of the service.

"In the future, people of all ages and backgrounds will be able to have full and free access to their heritage and their culture in digital form, with proper explanations and links to related material," said Mr Smith.

The £5m project, currently at the development stage, is a central part of Labour's e-government strategy. Smith is speaking to private investors with a view to increasing investment to as much as £100m.

The Department of Culture said it expects to work closely with the likes of the BBC, which is developing complementary initiatives.

webTitle: Army tape reveals 'joy' over Bloody Sunday

fields.headline: Army tape reveals 'joy' over Bloody Sunday
fields.standfirst:
Leaked recording claims general lapped up news of massacre

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: New details of the army's reactions to Bloody Sunday in Londonderry emerged last night after the IRA leaked a tape-recording, purportedly of conversations in a security force communications centre in the city in the aftermath of the massacre.
fields.body:
New details of the army's reactions to Bloody Sunday in Londonderry emerged last night after the IRA leaked a tape-recording, purportedly of conversations in a security force communications centre in the city in the aftermath of the massacre.

The IRA has long claimed that for several years it bugged the room in the now-defunct Victoria Barracks in the city. But there was no explanation last night why the critical recording was passed to the Derry Journal only after more than 28 years.

According to conversations between security force personnel captured on tape, General Robert Ford, then deputy commanding officer in Northern Ireland, was jubilant at the outcome. Three weeks before Bloody Sunday he had recommended shooting selected ringleaders of the youths who regularly rioted in the city.

The Parachute regiment shot dead 13 unarmed Catholics on an illegal civil rights demonstration in Derry on January 30 1972. Another man who was injured died several months later, and the tape will fuel suspicions that the soldiers' actions were pre-meditated.

One man recorded in the communication rooms says to another: "Look there's obviously been a hell of a sort out ... The whole thing's in chaos ... yeah, obviously I think it's gone badly wrong in the Rossville ... the doctor's just been up the hospital and they're pulling the stiffs out there as fast as they can get them out."

Another replies: "There's nothing wrong with that, Alan."

The first man says: "Well, there is because they're the wrong people ... There's about nine and 15 killed by the Parachute regiment in the Rossville area ... they're all women, children, fuck knows what and they're still going up there ... I mean their pigs [armoured cars] are just full of bodies ... There's a 3-tonner up there with bodies in."

The second man later says: "The padre's a bit upset. He's going off to see the commander about all the ill-treatment."

The first man asks: "General Ford?"

His companion replies: "Yeah"

The first man says: "He was lapping it up."

Second man: "Who was?"

First man: "Ford."

Second man: "Was he?"

First man: "Yeah ... he said it was the best thing he'd seen for a long time."

Second man: "Interesting, isn't it?"

First man: "'Well done, Ist Para,' he said. 'Look at them 24 million dollar'."

Second man: "Good excellent."

First man: "He said this is what should happen."

Second man: "Yeah."

First man: "He said we're far too passive ..."

In another exchange, one man in the communications room refers to detachments brought into Derry. He says: "They've been here over the weekend. We've had a pretty good bloodbath here this evening ... which you'll probably hear on the late news."

The Derry Journal said it was convinced the tape was authentic. But there was no explanation of why a tape of events three decades old was only now being leaked, when it would have represented a sensational propaganda coup many years ago.

The recording includes details of army personnel, phone extensions and equipment which would otherwise be confidential. But there were no independent means last night of confirming its veracity.

fields.headline: Rebels defeat jury reforms bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: jury trial
fields.trailText: The government is reeling from a major setback after the House of Lords killed a bill curbing a defendant's right to jury trial.
fields.body:
The government is reeling from a major setback after the House of Lords killed a bill curbing a defendant's right to jury trial.

Rebel Labour peers backed a Tory amendment after a stormy and impassioned debate on the second reading of the Criminal Justice (Mode of Trial) bill. It was the second time that Home secretary Jack Straw has tried and failed to push through the controversial legislation, aimed at saving money and speeding up the logjam in the courts.

But a cross-party alliance of peers, including three former law lords, Lord Ackner, Lord Donaldson and Lord Simon of Glaisdale, spoke against the government.

The government could use the Parliament Act to steamroller the same bill into law in the next sessions. But Labour rebels, including Baroness Kennedy of the Shaws QC warned the Government that "would be seen as a terrible display of arrogance".

The Home office said the government was determined to press ahead with the measure. A spokesman said: "We will not be deterred by the opposition of the House of Lords. We have already introduced this bill twice this session, and we will bring forward further legislation when Parliamentary time allows.

"The bill represents a modest but important modernisation of our criminal justice system, to speed up justice in the interests of victims, witnesses and the public at large."

Shadow Home Secretary Ann Widdecombe said the vote was "another slap down for the Home Secretary and overwhelming evidence of the arrogance at the heart of New Labour - the party who never listen."

"Jack Straw should have listened the first time the House of Lords rejected his foolish measures. Thank goodness that they at least have stood up for common sense and voted to keep this vital tenet of British justice."

Earlier the Attorney general urged the House of Lords to back the bill which would have ended the right of about 18,000 defendants a year in England and Wales to choose whether to be tried by a jury.

Instead, magistrates would choose where people charged with middle-ranking offences should be tried. Lord Williams of Mostyn said: "Cases which involve allegations of serious crime should not be held up, I suggest, by cases which, judged objectively, do not merit a Crown court trial.

"If we wish to have a criminal justice system that not only has something to do with crime and something to do with justice, but wishes to become systematic, then we ought to give these proposals an open-minded reception," he said.

Simon Hughes, Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said: "If ever there was a case for the Government saying it was wrong now is the time.

"A government which claims to be committed to human rights and civil liberties cannot go on threatening one of the oldest rights of all." end

fields.headline: The e-consumer rules OK
fields.standfirst: The internet challenges the fundamental premises of marketing, and marketers will have to do more than just set up a website to keep their consumers interested, writes Lindsey Roberts.
fields.trailText: The internet challenges the fundamental premises of marketing, and marketers will have to do more than just set up a website to keep their consumers interested, writes Lindsey Roberts.
fields.body:
How are businesses gearing up for a new kind of consumer power that is emerging from the electronic revolution?

I undertook research on behalf of Marketing Forum 2000 to answer that question and found real dilemmas for marketing and businesses in their quest to come to terms with the growth in consumer power heralded by changes in electronic media.

The research, which was conducted among both marketers and consumers, found that the rules of marketing haven't fundamentally changed but many of the processes marketers use are now too bureaucratic and ponderous.

Some companies are simply hiving off the electronic division to keep the 'e-types' from being too disruptive a force in the existing corporate culture. This is, in effect, a kind of corporate denial. A better solution is to embrace the need for change and become quicker and less bureaucratic. Size is important in the e-world but speed and agility are vital too. The winners will be those companies that succeed in combining both.

There are implications for ways of working too. In the words of one senior marketer: "This is the death of precedent." Everyone in marketing will have to find quicker, more original ways of working with more emphasis on creativity. This should, surely, be the perfect climate for agencies. While the marketing community is undergoing a revolution, agencies - which have traditionally seen themselves as the natural business partners of marketing clients - are turning into dinosaurs. They have not risen to the challenge of adapting to meet the rapidly changing needs of their customers.

The web agencies fared even worse and were seen as "the dot.coms of the agency world - entrepreneurial, ambitious but lacking substance".

However, the problem is not only for agencies. As far as consumers are concerned, few companies are getting their electronic offering right. There is too much emphasis on design and too little on functionality in websites. One of the consumer respondents summed it up: "Your website is your shop - whether or not you are planning to sell from it. Most people who visit are looking for information and help and they need to be given it. Then they may stay to browse and even buy. If they don't like the feel of your place, they have the biggest shopping mall in the world on their desktop."

However, this pales into insignificance against the biggest single conclusion from this research. We are witnessing the start of a seismic shift in the balance of power in marketing. We are only feeling the first distant rumbles, but as more people become e-enabled the closer we will get to the epicentre of a major earthquake that has the potential to shake the very foundations on which marketing has been built.

The marketing industry may soon look back with nostalgia at the good "old" world ruled by brands and built on inspiring confidence and reflecting consumer aspirations. Since the arrival of the e-world there has been much talk of building deeper relationships based on the previously undreamed of quality and quantity of data, providing a new depth of knowledge and the ability to anticipate consumer needs.

Attractive as this model may seem to today's marketers, based on the consumer research, I believe it is unlikely that this will be the future of marketing. While it is no news that the new, emergent e-consumer is becoming empowered, marketing has not yet fully understood the implications of meeting the needs of consumers who feel omnipotent rather than in awe. In fact, this sense of omnipotence is not usually a response to marketing. It often comes on the back of a bigger need, such as trying to find out about a medical condition affecting a family member. It takes persistence and a degree of acquired skill to become really competent on the web. But this type of stimulus leads consumers to push through the pain barrier and once they have done so there is no turning back.

There is a glint in the eye and an almost belligerent attitude among those consumers who have "cracked" the web. Marketers and brands really need to understand this phenomenon. Never before have consumers understood that they have the power over a medium and by extension over brands. In the words of just one web-literate consumer "What's fundamentally exciting is that we are controlling it, we are defining how it grows. We don't control the way other media work but we are controlling this and it's immensely exciting." People power is on the increase. Governments can't afford to ignore it and neither can brands and this means marketing needs to change beyond recognition.

Lindsey Roberts is founding partner of the FRESH ideas consultancy. Email: lindsey.roberts@letstalkfresh.com

webTitle: BBC radio plans five new digital services

fields.headline: BBC radio plans five new digital services
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC announced plans for five new radio services yesterday including a black music station and another for the "post-Beatles generation".
fields.body:
The BBC announced plans for five new radio services yesterday including a black music station and another for the "post-Beatles generation".

The services, part of the corporation's ambition to develop a presence in digital radio, also include a drama and comedy station, an enhanced Radio 5 Live and a national BBC Asian network.

However, unlike digital television which caught the public's imagination, digital radio has had a luke warm response. Digital radio is broadcast in CD quality sound but listeners have not been convinced of the advantages enough to spend £500 on the hardware needed to receive the signals.

Jenny Abramsky, director of BBC radio and music, defended the £20m digital investment saying that listeners would also be able to receive the signals on the internet, cable and digital satellite television as well as radio.

If approved by Chris Smith, the culture secretary, the first of the new services will be available early next year.

webTitle: Wolf replaces Haupt at Leo Burnett Worldwide

fields.headline: Wolf takes reins at Leo Burnett Worldwide
fields.trailText: 8am: Linda Wolf, chief executive officer of Leo Burnett Chicago, is to replace Roger Haupt as CEO of Leo Burnett Worldwide. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Linda Wolf, chief executive officer of Leo Burnett Chicago, is to replace Roger Haupt as CEO of Leo Burnett Worldwide.

She also becomes chairman, a position held previously by Richard Fizdale who will remain vice- chairman of the Bcom3 group.

Mr Haupt said: "Linda has more than earned this job. Since becoming CEO of Leo Burnett USA in 1996, Linda shepherded the agency through one of its most turbulent periods in history."

As part of a wider management shake-up, Robert Brennan, currently chief operating officer at Starcom MediaVest Group, becomes president of Leo Burnett Worldwide. Stephen Gatfield, group president for Leo Burnett's Asia Pacific region, becomes chief operating officer of Leo Burnett Worldwide.

Both will work on the brief of transforming the agency from a global advertising agency to a global marketing communications network.

Mr Gatfield will be replaced by Richard Pinder, who is being promoted to regional managing director.

London-based Jeffery Fergus will continue as group president of Leo Burnett's operations Europe, Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific.

Arthur Selkowitz, D'Arcy's worldwide chairman and CEO, becomes vice-chairman and chief client officer of Bcom3.

fields.headline: Five shortlisted for $100m Siemens task
fields.trailText: 8am: Siemens, the German engineering group, has shortlisted five agencies to pitch for for its mobile phones division. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Siemens, the German engineering group, has shortlisted five agencies to pitch for a global assignment worth up to $100m (£68m) for its mobile phones division.

TBWA Worldwide, Wieden & Kennedy in Amsterdam, D'Arcy, J Walter Thompson in Frankfurt and Die Brut in Hamburg will all pitch for the task. A decision is expected by the end of October.

The successful agency will aid Siemens in raising its market share in the global mobile phones market dominated by Finland's Nokia.

In Germany, its home market, Siemens is number two after Nokia, followed by Motorola and Alcatel.

fields.headline: The euro: a timeline
fields.trailText: 1969: The leaders of France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, Netherlands and the Luxembourg (the original six members of the European Economic Community), meet in The Hague to launch an initiative for economic and monetary union (EMU). A committee under Luxembourg prime minister Pierre Werner is formed to set a timetable for the project.
fields.body:
1969: The leaders of France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, Netherlands and the Luxembourg (the original six members of the European Economic Community), meet in The Hague to launch an initiative for economic and monetary union (EMU). A committee under Luxembourg prime minister Pierre Werner is formed to set a timetable for the project.

1970: Werner presents a final report outlining a three-stage plan aimed at creating EMU by 1980.

1972: The UK, Denmark and Eire join the EEC

1974: The oil crisis, onset of recession, the weak dollar and the divergence of national economies conspire to scupper plans to launch the second stage of the Werner Plan.

1979: In order to reduce volatility between European currencies, EEC governments set up the Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) which sets bands outside of which the value of currencies cannot move. The UK stays out of the new system.

1986: EEC governments sign up to the Single Market plan aimed at removing all barriers to the free movement of goods, investment, services and people by 1993.

1988: A committee is set up under commission president Jacques Delors to plan for the final stage of EMU. The Delors plan recommends a three-stage process leading to a single European currency under the control of a European Central Bank.

1990: Britain joins the ERM.

1991: European leaders sign the Maastricht Treaty setting up the European Union (EU) and committing EC countries to EMU. British prime minister John Major secures an opt-out on monetary union for the UK.

1992: Black Wednesday: Britain is forced out of the ERM by huge currency speculation. The Danish voters reject the Maastricht Treaty, it passes in all other countries although the French referendum result is very close. The Major government only gets it past the House of Commons by threatening its own backbenchers with a general election.

1994: Stage 2 of EMU establishes the European Monetary Institute, an embryonic central bank.

1995: European leaders agree to call the new single currency the euro.

1997: Britain's newly elected Labour government announces it is for the euro in principle but that five economic tests must be met before a referendum on the issue is held. The new Conservative leader, William Hague, announces that his party will rule out joining the single currency for at least two parliaments.

1998: European Central Bank is established in Frankfurt.

1999: The euro is born on 1 January in 11 of the 15 EU member states. The participating countries' currencies are irrevocably linked to in value to the euro. Britain, Sweden and Denmark stay out of the single currency and Greece is initially excluded because of its weak economy. The euro spends most its first year losing value against the dollar.

2000: The European Central Bank, along with the central banks of the USA and Japan, intervenes in the currency markets to prop up the value of the euro. The Danes vote no to the single currency by 53% to 47% despite the overwhelming support for the yes campaign by most of the political parties, media and industry.

webTitle: Asking the people - asking for trouble

fields.headline: Asking the people - asking for trouble
fields.standfirst: Should we be given the chance to choose our own prime minister in a referendum? Derek Brown doesn't think so
fields.trailText: 29 September, comment: Should we be given the chance to choose our own prime minister in a referendum? Derek Brown doesn't think so.
fields.body:
There is a growing swell of support for important political issues to be decided by referendum. It is an honourable case, and the trend is probably irreversible. But there are dangers and pitfalls too.

The theory which underpins Britain's famously unwritten constitution is that supreme authority rests with the monarch in parliament. In practice, that cosy concept has been dead for more than 300 years, ever since parliament finally asserted its supremacy in the Glorious Revolution of 1688.

In more recent times, parliament's authority has been hugely eroded by the more amorphous concept of the will of the people. Through the 19th century, a series of electoral reforms extended the franchise across all classes, and ensured that every voter had more or less equal influence (that is, tiny) over the make-up of the House of Commons.

However, universal suffrage - one person, one vote - was introduced only in the late 20s, with the enfranchisement of women on equal terms. Popular democracy is therefore in its infancy, in historical terms, although we have become used for centuries to the comfortable notion that we are all represented in our parliament.

It is that central idea which is threatened by referendums. For ultimately, if we are to decide the great issues of the day ourselves, the importance of our elected representatives is automatically diminished. It could be argued that the authority of MPs has already been grievously eroded by power-hungry executives, our present government being a pretty good example.

Following that line of argument, it may be that we need more referendums so that we can occasionally kick our beloved rulers where it hurts - as in the London mayoral election this year.

The danger is that if we pare away yet more of our MPs' authority, we will automatically be weakening the only real check on the executive in our system: the House of Commons. It would be credulous to argue that the government will and should be answerable to the will of the people. It is also rather scary to speculate the outcome of that will, were it to be given unfettered expression.

For where would we draw the line on what kind of issues are suitable to be put before the people? Those involving constitutional change, certainly, such as the devolution votes in Scotland and Wales, and the 1975 vote on membership of what was the EEC.

The case for a referendum on the single currency is much more dubious, as it involves no fundamental constitutional change - whatever the huffing and puffing patriots say. Already, it is plain that whatever the wording of the question and however the campaign is conducted, the vote will be seen as endorsement or rejection of the EU itself. In that sense, it will be a perilous irrelevance.

And if the case for going to the people is so strong, why stop with the poor old euro? Should we not have a chance - all of us - to choose our prime minister, given the swollen importance of that office? Could we perhaps be consulted on tax rates and other key budget proposals? Or freedom of information? Or capital punishment?

No thanks. That way lies a slippery slope, leading to a mire of cheap populism. Better by far that we stick to our elected representatives, encouraging them from time to time by kicking their backsides in general elections.

The problem with that is that our parliament, collectively, is wildly unrepresentative of the electoral will of the people, and will remain so until there is a fair voting system.

New Labour, terrified by the idea that it would be no longer possible for a party to achieve a majority of 179 with just 44% of the vote, is slithering away from its pre-election commitment to a referendum on reform. Now that would be a referendum worth having.

webTitle: European reaction to the Danish 'no' vote

fields.headline: European reaction to the Danish 'no' vote
fields.standfirst: Official and press reaction to Denmark's   rejection of the euro in the referendum held yesterday
fields.trailText: Official and press reaction to Denmark's rejection of the euro in the referendum held yesterday.
fields.body:
"We respect that decision, even if we regret it This decision does not modify the position of the euro... Denmark is a country which we fully respect of course, but at the same time, one is bound to recognise that the size of the Danish economy represents 2% of the overall (euro) zone.

"That in no way reduces the importance that we attach to the Danish decision, but it doesn't impact upon the fundamental economic situation nor indeed upon the prospects for the single currency.

"We welcome the decision taken by the Danish government to continue the peg of the Danish krone to the euro via the exchange rate mechanism Legally this does not prevent Denmark joining later if the Danish people change their minds."
French Finance Minister Laurent Fabius, at a Brussels meeting of the Eurogroup, which France currently chairs

"I share the regrets, but from now on it's business as usual The Danish people have chosen to deprive themselves of the benefits Denmark would have gained from going into the euro."
Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, at the Eurogroup meeting

"Will the upping of the stakes (loss of political influence, risk of an interest rates rise, threat to 15,000-20,000 jobs) attempted in extremis by [Prime Minister Poul Nyrup] Rasmussen's team, be enough to convince all the followers of the "wait and see"?...

"If the UK and Sweden were to one day enter the euro, Denmark will then be able to reconsider its choice. It is this calculation, a bit of a hypocritical one, which many Danes are likely to make today, convinced as they are (80% of them are at least) that they will be able to correct their mistake at a later stage."
Nathalie Dubois in Libération

"What is more surprising is that more than half the Danes have rejected what a majority of the Danish parties, the press and the economic world all advised them to do. This 'pause' will give them time to reflect because 'once inside, we will be there definitively, it is the point of no return,' points out Holger K Nielsen, the leader of the Popular Socialist party in favour of the no vote.

"As they await possible future changes, the Danes wish for a little more flexibility in the integration process to avoid being swallowed up by Europe. A local saying recommends 'not to eat cherries with people larger than you because they then spit the cores in your face'. The time of cherries has not come yet!"
Michel Bole-Richard in Le Monde

"The division between the political elite and the people that the result reflects can serve as a warning not only to Denmark, forced already in 1992 to take into account the first referendum which rejected the Maastricht treaty, but also to the rest of the EU. The construction of Europe cannot be done without the support of the people and by focusing only on the macroeconomics, but by espousing other values and taking into account the concrete preoccupations of the people."
Leader in El Pais

webTitle: Why Britain should stay a euro-free zone

fields.headline: Why Britain should stay a euro-free zone
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair should follow Denmark's example and steer clear of the single currency, says economics editor Larry Elliott
fields.trailText: Tony Blair should follow Denmark's example and steer clear of the single currency, says economics editor Larry Elliott.
fields.body:
The chances of early British membership of the euro have diminished markedly as a result of yesterday's no vote in the Danish referendum. And rightly so. For all the talk about the single currency being part of an inevitable historical process it is quite obvious that many people across Europe see the euro as a bad idea. When given the opportunity to vote on it, they don't like it.

There are three good reasons why the Blair government should give the single currency a wide berth. First, there is the economic argument. The euro's value has plummeted by more than 25% since its launch in January 1999 dashing hopes that it would be a rock-solid currency.

Moreover, the one-size-fits-all interest rate for the 11 member countries has meant that the cost of borrowing is too low in some countries - witness Ireland's inflation rate of more than 6% - and too high in others, particularly Germany. Had Britain joined the euro at its inception, the result would have been high inflation in the short term and a very serious recession in the long term.

Second, there is the democratic argument. One of the main factors in the Danish referendum was the sense among voters that they wanted more control over their lives, rather than ceding decision-making to remote, unaccountable and centralised bodies.

In Britain, the government's recent difficulties have been as much about the backlash against what people see as top-down decision-making by an out-of-touch elite as it has been about the nuances of policy. On road fuel tax, on the Dome, and on pensions, the government did not listen. It must make sure it does over the euro, because as the Danes have illustrated, it is no longer possible for the great and the good - either at national, European or global level - to dictate policy over the heads of the people.

Finally, there is the political argument. In Denmark, the entire political, media and business establishment was for the euro, yet the yes camp still lost convincingly. In Britain, where the balance of forces for and against the single currency is much more even and opinion polls show a deep scepticism about monetary union, the government has to acknowledge that it could lose a referendum by a thumping majority.

If that happened, Mr Blair's administration would be broken: it would lose its moral authority and find it much harder to push through its domestic agenda of improving public services, tackling poverty and raising living standards.

In the end, the government will probably conclude that the potential costs of a lost referendum far outweigh the nebulous benefits of winning one against the odds. And it will be right.

fields.headline: Cook firm on euro referendum
fields.trailText: The government today insisted that yesterday's rejection of the euro by the Danish people does not affect its own plans to hold a referendum after the next general election.
fields.body:
The government today insisted that yesterday's rejection of the euro by the Danish people does not affect its own plans to hold a referendum after the next general election.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, argued today that if the economic circumstances were deemed to be conducive to joining the euro, it would be "irresponsible" not to hold a poll on joining the single currency. Economic considerations for the euro were important for Britain however difficult it might be to make the political case, Mr Cook said.

But the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said the Danish vote was an important watershed in resistance to the single currency, shooting a hole in the argument that joining the euro was an inevitability.

Pointing out the economic benefits of the eurozone, Mr Cook said: "The vote last night does not alter in any way the fundamental fact that the eurozone contains 250m people who provide the market for the majority of our exports, and that there are 5,000 American and Japanese companies which invest here because they want to export to that market."

He said the chief executive of Nissan had warned recently that there was a question mark over whether the company could site production of a new model at its Sunderland plant because Britain was not part of the euro.

"Those are the critical, crucial questions that will weigh with the British people, who will make the decision on what is right for Britain, not what is right for Denmark," Mr Cook continued.

"I find it rather odd that those very people who stress sovereignty, who stress the right of Britain to make independent decisions, seem this morning to be saying that Denmark should decide for Britain. It shouldn't. Britain should decide for itself, and I think it would be very unwise for us to close off the option.

"If the chancellor does decide that there would be economic advantages of going in, I think it would be very irresponsible for the government now to say that even if he reaches that decision, we are not going to ask the British people," the foreign secretary told Radio 4's Today programme.

Speaking on Radio 4's Today programme Mr Portillo said the result of the Danish referendum proved there was nothing inevitable about joining the single currency. "I think there has been an important change with this referendum, and that is that the only arguments that were really made in favour about going in, were that we should be fearful in some way of being left out, fearful of being isolated," he said. "Well of course we are not now isolated, other people in Europe have taken the same view.

"The other argument was that it was somehow inevitable that we would join the euro. Well, it clearly isn't inevitable. It is within the capability of the British people to vote no if they are offered that chance in a referendum."

webTitle: Denmark says no to the euro

fields.headline: Denmark says no to the euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Denmark last night said a resounding No to the euro after a cliffhanging referendum whose result will narrow Tony Blair's choices over the single currency and encourage the development of a "two-speed" Europe, leaving Britain in the slow lane.
fields.body:
Denmark last night said a resounding No to the euro after a cliffhanging referendum whose result will narrow Tony Blair's choices over the single currency and encourage the development of a "two-speed" Europe, leaving Britain in the slow lane.

With 99% of votes counted, TV projections showed 53% against and 47% for, promising a comfortable final majority for jubilant nej-sayers.

The result immediately echoed across the EU and beyond, with the euro starting to drop in late trading in New York.

Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, did his best to put a brave face on the outcome but had to admit that he was disappointed.

"The EU is obviously not happy about this result but it will continue on its path which has produced exceptional results," he said last night. "I don't think the Danish economy will in future benefit from this decision."

In an aside which is certain to anger Tony Blair, Mr Prodi seemed to signal that the Danish vote may now open the way to something which Britain vehemently opposes - a two-speed Europe in which a small core of so-called pioneer countries race ahead of the laggards who cannot make up their minds.

Reinforced cooperation as it is called is now very much on the cards, he suggested, but he was at pains to stress that this was not an exclusive club and that membership was open to all.

Mr Blair insisted that the knife-edge decision of the 4m deeply divided Danish voters would not affect his long-standing policy on the euro. "Denmark has got its own decision and we have got our own decision," he said.

But the Conservative leader, William Hague,said: "This vote blows out of the water Labour's scare tactics on the euro.

"They claimed that Britain would be isolated if we keep the pound. We are not. They claimed euro membership was inevitable. It is not. They claimed Europe must be one size fits all. It must not."

Other EU leaders put a brave face on the news, claiming it would not have a significant effect. "I hope that ... people around Europe will perceive this as a purely Danish decision," said Sweden's prime minister, Goran Persson, who like Mr Blair has to decide whether to call a referendum.

Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister, said: "The Danes are making their choice as a sovereign people. I have a lot of respect for this country, but its size for the European economy is not major."

As champagne corks popped in the folketing, Pia Kjaersgaard, the head of the far-right, anti-immigration Danish People's party, struck a note of undisguised triumph. "The rest of Europe should look at Denmark and see what we feel," she said. "We should not move ahead so quickly."

Glum Yes campaigners predicted that it would be years before another referendum.

Denmark's big day followed a six-month campaign that saw little argument about the economic merits of joining the euro but much discussion of deep-seated anxieties about the erosion of national identity and independence.

By lunchtime, crowds were streaming past Copenhagen's famous Tivoli gardens and into the capital's town hall to vote.

Emerging from a polling booth, economist and Yes voter Soren Voetmann said: "I have tried to use common sense and not my emotions. There has been too much emotion."

But Christen Thrane, 23, a young mother, was against. "It's too fast and I am not sure what we are getting into," she said. "It's important that we keep our Danish money and I fear adopting the euro will damage our social welfare system."

Danes were voting whether to keep their opt-out from the 1993 Maastricht treaty, negotiated after a referendum in 1992 rejected the entire single currency project.

Yesterday's referendum was Denmark's sixth since deciding to join the EEC in 1972. But it was the first time any of the EU's 15 members had voted directly on whether to adopt the single currency.

Last night's result will top the agenda when EU finance ministers meet in Brussels today.

fields.headline: Anti-euro vote emboldens UK sceptics
fields.standfirst:
Labour looks to Denmark for referendum lessons
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Britain's Eurosceptics were last night hoping that the strength of the Danish No vote would sufficiently scare an already nervous Downing Street into an indefinite postponement of its plans to hold a similar referendum in the UK early in the next parliament.
fields.body:
Britain's Eurosceptics were last night hoping that the strength of the Danish No vote would sufficiently scare an already nervous Downing Street into an indefinite postponement of its plans to hold a similar referendum in the UK early in the next parliament.

However, the Foreign Office and its satellites yesterday argued the votes simply showed the importance of framing the right campaign with the right messages, something the pro-euro Danish politicians failed to do.

One ministerial source in Brighton for the Labour conference, but anxiously awaiting news from Copenhagen, tried to affect insouciance: "There is no doubt that this result will affect the debate for a month or possibly up to Christmas. But the British referendum is at least two or three years away, and by then no one is going to remember what happened in Denmark."

But Nick Herbert, the chief executive for Business for Sterling, was in celebratory mood: "I think this is a going to be a very sobering result for the pro-European lobby in Britain. After all, the entire political establishment, the media and the business lobby in the country were pushing for a Yes vote.

"In Britain, if there is a referendum here, the political classes, the media and the public will be divided. Still more it is clear that all the scare tactics about the impact on the currency, interest rates and trade simply did not work.

"The establishment also tried to portray the opponents of the euro as extremists, yet the people rose up despite the pressure and saw through the implications. It suggests if the pro-Europeans try the same scare tactics here, they won't work."

Mr Herbert claimed the lessons for the pro-Europeans in Britain were profound. The Danish currency is already inside the ERM, its trade is intimately linked with the EU and its economy is closely allied to euroland. Mr Herbert said: "So the economic implications for the Danes of joining the euro were not that great. That suggests the Danes recognised there were more important constitutional issues at stake in the referendum in terms of loss of political sovereignty."

If there is a referendum in Britain, he says, the pro-European lobby would face a much more difficult task. "They will have to overcome not only the doubts over sovereignty, but also the much more complex economic implications."

Mark Leonard from the Foreign Policy Centre, a thinktank allied to the Foreign Office, has already prepared a pamphlet and action plan on Denmark. He argued yesterday that Britain's pro-Europeans will lose the referendum unless they win the political as well as the economic argument.

"Of course people care about jobs and mortgages, but they still won't vote for the euro if we don't win the argument on sovereignty. We have to point out the consequences of being sidelined in Europe," Mr Leonard said.

Pro-European MPs close to the Foreign Office refuse to be downhearted. They argue that the vote had a great deal to do with the internal politics of Denmark, including the Danes' fear that as a small country they would be kicked around by an expanded EU.

Mr Leonard also said public trust in politicians who support the single currency is lower in Denmark than in Britain. Only 8% of the electorate expressed a lot of trust in the Danish prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen.

The poll also coincided with all-time lows in the value of the euro and took place two years into Mr Rasmussen's leadership, amid mid-term blues. Mr Blair plans to poll early in his second term.

Another Labour source said: "The point is that we will have to make the case that in the long term if we stay out of the euro, we will be relegated to a second league state with all the major decisions in the EU being made by members of the currency. We cannot get round that point."

Mr Blair will make a speech on the future constitution of Europe in Warsaw next week.

A Foreign Office source said: "It is a speech that will try to square the circle. It will try to be pro-nation state, even Gaullist on the one hand, and pro-European Union of the other. It is the start of a long dialogue ahead."

fields.headline: Saudis break ranks on quotas
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Saudi Arabia undermined the unified front Opec presented to the west at the Caracas summit yesterday when it promised to pump as much crude as necessary to lower world oil prices.
fields.body:
Saudi Arabia undermined the unified front Opec presented to the west at the Caracas summit yesterday when it promised to pump as much crude as necessary to lower world oil prices.

The assurance from the world's largest oil producer that it would act came after Venezuela said on Wednesday that further attempts by western leaders to ease prices by dipping into strategic reserves would be met by cuts in Opec production quotas.

"The kingdom is willing and ready to offer the amount necessary to stabilise the world oil market," Crown Prince Abdullah said. "We are worried by the increase in oil prices which, if continued permanently, could lead to a negative impact on the world economy and the prospects for world economic growth."

His statement caused an immediate dip in world oil prices. Brent crude fell by 37 cents to $30.17 a barrel and US light crude fell 28 cents to $31.18.

Prince Abdullah repeated Opec's call for oil-importing countries to play their role in easing prices by reducing taxes on fuel. "We call upon consuming countries to share the sacrifice through the taxes that they impose on oil ... We are unfairly blamed for all the problems of the world economy."

Opec has increased production three times this year - to 3.2m barrels a day - in response to diplomatic arm-twisting from industrialised countries, which are afraid that the 10-year peak in prices could spark inflation.

Last week the US announced that it would release 30m barrels from its emergency reserves over the next three months to shore up supplies, prompting the EU to consider similar action. However, some member countries say that such supplies should only be used for emergencies.

Oil prices have trebled in the last 18 months. This year's price rise has mainly been driven by fears of fuel shortages in the US, which consumes a fifth of world petroleum supplies.

Poor countries which have been hardest hit by the hike in world oil prices may get extra help from the International Monetary Fund, it emerged yesterday. The IMF warned last week that high oil prices could cut growth in poor countries by up to one percentage point.

The west's energy watchdog, the International Energy Agency (IEA), has called an emergency meeting of its governing board on October 4 to discuss the crisis in the world oil market.

webTitle: Government acts to avert fuel blockades

fields.headline: Government acts to avert fuel blockades
fields.trailText: The government will today unveil a "memorandum of understanding", agreed with the oil companies and police, aimed at securing essential fuel supplies in the event of further blockades.
fields.body:
The government will today unveil a "memorandum of understanding", agreed with the oil companies and police, aimed at securing essential fuel supplies in the event of further blockades.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, who heads the government's fuel taskforce, was set to publish details of the agreement after it was formally endorsed by ministers and representatives of the industry and the police.

In a statement to the House of Lords yesterday, transport minister Lord Macdonald said it would cover the practical arrangements for the co-ordination and co-operation needed to protect essential services.

Government sources said it would include the development of joint early-warning and crisis-management systems, as well as dealing with the intimidation of tanker drivers.

The taskforce had also been looking at the oil companies' contractual arrangements with the tanker drivers, most of whom are self-employed, which made it difficult for the companies to order them to cross the blockades.

The taskforce was also looking at the options for new legislation, giving the police greater powers to deal with public disorder and imposing a legal duty on the oil companies to maintain essential supplies.

Lord Macdonald stressed, however, that the government would continue to respect workers' rights under employment legislation as well as the right to peaceful protest.

He emphasised that ministers, who had faced accusations that they were arrogant and out of touch, were listening to the concerns of the protesters.

The "existing channels" of communication with the haulage industry would be kept open during the consultation process, leading up to the pre-Budget report from the chancellor, Gordon Brown, Lord Macdonald said.

But he warned that the government would not be dictated to by the protesters, who have threatened to resume their blockades if there was no cut in fuel duty within 60 days.
