webTitle: Twins' parents end fight to stop operation

fields.headline: Twins' parents end fight to stop operation
fields.standfirst: Conjoined twins' parents end fight to stop fatal operation
fields.trailText: The fate of the conjoined twins, Jodie and Mary, was sealed yesterday when their parents gave up the legal fight to prevent an operation which is bound to lead to the death of the weaker girl.
fields.body:
The fate of the conjoined twins, Jodie and Mary, was sealed yesterday when their parents gave up the legal fight to prevent an operation which is bound to lead to the death of the weaker girl.

The couple decided they could do no more after two courts and four judges agreed that the procedure must go ahead, despite their fierce objections on religious grounds.

The dramatic decision not to take the case to the House of Lords or to Europe clears the way for doctors to operate as soon as they believe the time is right.

Surgeons initially indicated that they would like to separate the seven-week-old twins when they were three months old, but if the girls' condition suddenly deteriorates they could proceed at once.

The parents, who are from the Maltese island of Gozo, are still fervently opposed to the operation but have promised not to try to flee Britain with their children.

However, pro-life campaigners repeated an offer to arrange for the parents and children to be taken to a safe haven in Italy. They also criticised the official solicitor, who has been acting independently of the parents on Mary's behalf, for not fighting on.

Yesterday's decision ends a legal battle which has involved complex legal, moral and religious issues and which has attracted worldwide attention and divided public opinion.

The twins were born on August 8 at St Mary's hospital in Manchester. When it became clear that if the twins were separated Mary would die, the parents, who are Catholic, refused to give their permission for the operation, preferring to let nature - or God's will - take its course. If no operation takes place both twins are expected to perish within six months because Jodie's heart would not stand the extra pressure.

Wanting to save Jodie, the doctors asked the high court to rule that the operation should go ahead. A judge backed them but the parents appealed. After an extraordinary hearing in which both the Catholic church and the ProLife Alliance argued that the parents' wishes should be respected, three senior judges sided with the doctors.

It had been thought that the parents would continue their fight but yesterday afternoon their solicitor, John Kitchingman, announced that they felt they could do no more.

He said: "The parents - having taken this case to two courts and four judges, whose decisions were unanimous - feel that they have done all they can for both daughters and are unable to take this any further."

Mr Kitchingman also appealed for the parents' privacy to be respected. However, it is known that they have received several six-figure offers to tell their story. One legal source close to the case said the parents would be "foolish" not to consider the offers. Even if the separation operation goes well, it is possible that Jodie could be disabled and need expensive care for the rest of her life.

The unique nature of the case was brought out in an unusually lengthy statement from the official solicitor, Laurence Oates.

He too had decided not to take the case further. He said he had taken into account not only the parents' stance but also the "moral, ethical and legal arguments" submitted by the Archbishop of Westminster and the ProLife Alliance during the appeal.

Mr Oates repeated the judges' point that the ruling was "specific" to this case. He was satisfied that the decision would not "undermine the law deriving from and supporting the respect to the sanctity of life and the belief that life has equal value".

Pro-life campaigners and the Catholic church are worried that the twins' case could enshrine in law the principle that it is permissible to carry out a wrong act in order to do right.

Last night the ProLife Alliance said it believed the parents would be within their rights to take the children out of the country. But a spokesperson said: "They may have lost the will to fight on."

The appeal court case ended last Friday with the judges describing their agonising decision over whether or not the operation should go ahead.

Senior judge Lord Justice Ward concluded: "Mary has always been fated for early death. Though Mary has the right to life she has little right to be alive. She is alive only because, to put it bluntly but nonetheless accurately, she sucks the life blood of Jodie and her parasitic living will soon be the cause of Jodie ceasing to live.

"Jodie is entitled to protest that Mary is killing her. The best interests of the twins is to give the chance of life to the child whose actual bodily condition is capable of accepting the chance to her advantage even if that has to be at the cost of the sacrifice of a life. I am left in no doubt at all that the scales come down heavily in Jodie's favour."

The children were born joined at the abdomen but doctors are confident that Jodie could have a full and healthy life - if given the chance to operate. They believe there is only a 5 per cent chance of Jodie dying if they could pick the time of the operation. If the operation had to be carried out in an emergency, however, this could rise to 64 per cent. Mary will inevitably die within minutes of any operation.

The operation could be brought forward if Mary, who relies on her stronger sister for oxygenated blood, continues to grow - as she has been doing - apparently at the expense of her twin. fields.bodyText: The fate of the conjoined twins, Jodie and Mary, was sealed yesterday when their parents gave up the legal fight to prevent an operation which is bound to lead to the death of the weaker girl. The couple decided they could do no more after two courts and four judges agreed that the procedure must go ahead, despite their fierce objections on religious grounds. The dramatic decision not to take the case to the House of Lords or to Europe clears the way for doctors to operate as soon as they believe the time is right. Surgeons initially indicated that they would like to separate the seven-week-old twins when they were three months old, but if the girls' condition suddenly deteriorates they could proceed at once. The parents, who are from the Maltese island of Gozo, are still fervently opposed to the operation but have promised not to try to flee Britain with their children. However, pro-life campaigners repeated an offer to arrange for the parents and children to be taken to a safe haven in Italy. They also criticised the official solicitor, who has been acting independently of the parents on Mary's behalf, for not fighting on. Yesterday's decision ends a legal battle which has involved complex legal, moral and religious issues and which has attracted worldwide attention and divided public opinion. The twins were born on August 8 at St Mary's hospital in Manchester. When it became clear that if the twins were separated Mary would die, the parents, who are Catholic, refused to give their permission for the operation, preferring to let nature - or God's will - take its course. One legal source close to the case said the parents would be "foolish" not to consider the offers. Even if the separation operation goes well, it is possible that Jodie could be disabled and need expensive care for the rest of her life. fields.headline: Ferry death toll rises to 79
fields.trailText: The captain and four crewmen of the Greek ferry that sank off Paros on Tuesday were charged with manslaughter last night as the expected death toll climbed to 79.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll in Paros and Michael Howard in Athens
fields.body:
The captain and four crewmen of the Greek ferry that sank off Paros on Tuesday were charged with manslaughter last night as the expected death toll climbed to 79.

The five were transferred in a coastguard patrol from Paros to the nearby island of Syros where a prosecutor is expected today to spell out the charges and vent Greece's rising fury at the disaster.

The government vowed harsh penalties for those responsible for the Express Samina's unexplained collision with an illuminated, charted rocky islet, which threw an estimated 530 passengers into stormy waters.

"The prosecutor has already begun charge proceedings against five people. He would not have done this without any grounds," said the merchant marine minister, Christos Papoutsis.

The revelation that Captain Vassilis Yannakis had been in command of at least one other ship that sank fuelled accusations that he had caused Tuesday night's disaster by abandoning the bridge for the bar to watch a televised football match.

The other four crew were named as his deputy, Tasso Psychoyios, trainee captain Yannis Patilas, radio operator Yannis Tsoumos and seaman Panayotis Kazakis. Through their lawyers, the men protested their innocence and said they would fight the charges, which include breaching maritime safety rules and sinking a ship.

Against a tide of public anger and newspaper headlines proclaiming: "Criminals!", the ferry's owner, Minoan Flying Dolphins, defended the captain. Pythagoras Nagos, a company spokesperson, said Captain Yannakis had hit a harbour quayside 12 years ago when commanding a small ferry but was a reliable professional.

"He is a very good captain. He knows the Paros route like he knows the money in his pocket," he said. "He has admitted that he was not on the bridge at the time but he is not obliged to be there 24 hours a day."

But the daily newspaper To Vima reported that the collision to which Mr Nagos referred was not with a harbour but a rocky outcrop off Crete. It said the captain had been asleep and had delegated duties. The paper also claimed that he had collided with another ship in Piraeus harbour.

The daily Kathimerini was scathing about Tuesday's disaster: "The captain was watching the Panathaikos match, even the officers, the crew was incapable of handling the crisis and the boat, one of the most pathetic in the Greek fleet, was carried onto rocks that were nevertheless clearly lit up."

Mr Nagos dismissed one media report that the captain had deliberately sank the Express Samina to make an insurance claim: "We are not premeditated killers, for God's sake."

Prosecutors are believed to be turning their attention to the second in command, Mr Psychoyios, who is reported to have been on the bridge. The investigation is also focusing on claims that the ship was on automatic pilot minutes before striking the outcrop.

The death toll rose to 65 early yesterday after two bodies were recovered overnight. A total of 448 people have been rescued but some are still missing. Between 525 and 530 people were believed to have been on board. No Britons were among the dead.

Strong winds yesterday prevented divers from searching the wrecked hull, which is believed to contain up to 14 corpses. It is lying on the seabed at a depth of 38 metres.

Two helicopters, four Greek navy boats, two coastguard rescue vessels and a British warship were sweeping the waters for survivors off Paros, a popular tourist destination in the Cyclades islands south-east of Athens.

Survivors yesterday relived the terror of the moment the 35-year-old ferry listed and then sank within half an hour. Passengers, some without lifejackets, were thrown into rough, dark seas.

fields.headline: Hurst's shirt fetches £91,000
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: The England number 10 shirt worn by Sir Geoff Hurst in the 1966 World Cup final was sold for a record £91,750 at auction yesterday.
fields.body:
The England number 10 shirt worn by Sir Geoff Hurst in the 1966 World Cup final made footballing history for a second time yesterday when it was sold for a record £91,750 at auction.

A soccer-mad British collector was described as "overjoyed" with his acquisition which he bid for by telephone from his hotel room in Sydney where he is holidaying during the Olympic games.

Christie's spokeswoman Jill Potterton said the die-hard Tottenham Hotspur fan who attended the 1966 final as a 12- year-old had stayed up until all hours to join in the bidding from all around the world. She added: "He doesn't want to be named but he comes from west London and the shirt will now take pride of place in his private collection at home."

The price was more than three times that expected by experts at Christie's, and more than double the previous record of £44, 000 for one worn by the late Bobby Moore, Hurst's captain on the historic day.

The successful bidder later told Christie's staff that he hoped the shirt would ultimately go on show at the foot ball museum in Preston once it is opened.

West Ham, the club Sir Geoff played for at the time of the World Cup final in which he scored a hat-trick, was believed to be among the unsuccessful British bidders for the shirt.

Another of the 129 lots put up by Sir Geoff, the blue cap awarded to him for the final stages of the World Cup triumph, fetched £37,600.

Before the auction, Sir Geoff said: "It was always my intention to leave the collection to my children, but I have three daughters so how do you split it up fairly? They have selected some special items they want to keep and we have also kept some pieces for the grandchildren.

"But I have already lost a significant proportion of the collection in two burglaries, so it is all kept locked away now and no-one sees it.

"I am as patriotic as the next man and will cherish my footballing days but at this stage in my life I would like to have some control over the distribution of the collection."

Other items up for sale included a nine carat gold FA Cup winner's medal from 1964 and items from Sir Geoff's West Ham days.

webTitle: Fate of slap case teacher in balance

fields.headline: Fate of slap case teacher in balance
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Mystery last night surrounded the fate of headteacher Marjorie Evans, who was cleared this month of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, after governors refused to disclose the outcome of a meeting to decide her future.
fields.body:
Mystery last night surrounded the fate of headteacher Marjorie Evans, who was cleared this month of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, after governors refused to disclose the outcome of a meeting to decide her future.

But Graham Powell was voted out of his role as chairman of the board of governors during the three and a quarter hour meeting at St Mary's junior school in Caldicot, south Wales.

Members of the board are believed to be divided over their support for the headteacher, who has been questioned by police over further allegations that she mistreated pupils at the school.

Mr Powell's replacement, Robert Gibbs, the former vice-chairman, refused to comment on whether Mrs Evans would be reinstated.

In a statement, he said: "After long and careful consideration the necessary decision was made concerning staffing matters.

"The governors are not in the position to reveal the content of their deliberations until staff at the school know themselves."

After the meeting, which Mrs Evans did not attend, Mr Powell said the decision about his own post was a "democratic" one and that he was not disappointed by the vote.

Mrs Evans was first suspended a year ago from St Mary's after being charged with assaulting a pupil who was trying to headbutt, punch and push her.

The 56-year-old from Usk, south Wales, was convicted of common assault at Abergavenny magistrates court in July.

But a high court judge sitting at Cardiff crown court overturned the decision earlier this month.

After the successful appeal, Mrs Evans said she wanted to get back to the school as soon as possible.

But her hopes were dashed after it was revealed that police were investigating fresh allegations of pupil mistreatment.

Her suspension remained in force and the school's governors said they would reconsider the issue at the end of the month.

Mrs Evans and three other members of staff were questioned by police earlier this week concerning the new allegations. A report has been submitted to the crown prosecution service.

webTitle: How 405 days of wedded bliss adds up to a $450m fortune

fields.headline: How 405 days of wedded bliss adds up to a $450m fortune
fields.standfirst: The former topless model who married a fabulously rich 89-year-old wins her right to half his estate
fields.trailText: It was, of course, the happiest day of her life when the former Playmate of the Year picked her way daintily across a carpet of white rosebuds to the chapel where she committed her life to the Texan billionaire.
fields.body:
It was, of course, the happiest day of her life when the former Playmate of the Year picked her way daintily across a carpet of white rosebuds to the chapel where she committed her life to the Texan billionaire.

But there was an obvious price to be paid by Anna Nicole Smith, a 26-year-old full of life, breast implants and her favourite food - mashed potatoes and gravy - when she married her beau, the oil baron J Howard Marshall II, aged 89.

Now a judge has put a figure on the one-time topless dancer's sacrifice: $449.7m (£300m), or $1.11m for each day of their union, a match rent asunder only by his death 14 months after they became man and wife.

Smith says that he had promised her half his fortune, estimated at $1.6bn, if she would only give him her hand. E Pierce Marshall, the oilman's 60-year-old son, says she is a gold-digger.

The old man, whose previous mistress was also, by coincidence, a topless dancer - she died during a facelift operation - left a will that omitted mention of the near-6ft blonde.

Instead, the document left everything to a charity and E Pierce, who says his father was senile when he made the promise to his stepmother, the third Mrs J Howard Marshall II.

Smith took her case to a bankruptcy court in Los Angeles, which ruled that E Pierce had deprived her of her due and awarded her the almost half-a-billion dollars plus punitive damages to be fixed later. She is supported by Marshall's eldest disinherited son, J Howard III.

Wonderful

"Oh my God, this is wonderful news," said Smith, now 32. "He promised me half of everything because he loved me and he wanted to make me happy. He bought me just about anything I wanted. He loved to surprise me. No one ever took care of me in my whole life and this man did that and I loved him for it."

And indeed Marshall did take care of her, as one might expect of the man who owned a chunk of Koch Industries Inc, the second-largest privately held corporation in the United States.

Naturally there were houses and cars, the humdrum baubles of a smitten money-machine's five-year courtship of the woman who was a fried chicken restaurant waitress until she started making her way in the world. But there were highlights too: the $50,000 each month for out-of-pocket expenses, more than enough to take care of her $4,000-a-month food bill; the day he treated her to a trip to a jeweller's in New York and came away $2m lighter.

People talked, of course they did. They talked of the nanny, the bodyguard, the driver, two actors and a director and their words reached the ears of E Pierce. "Oh sure, he was trying to get surveillance put in my bedroom and my bathroom," said Smith.

J Howard, though, would not be deflected from his course and finally the couple married at the White Dove wedding chapel, in Houston, in June 1994. As is the way with such ceremonies, tears were shed, not least by the bridegroom when Smith informed him that it would not be possible to spend the wedding night together due to a pressing modelling engagement.

But, all agreed, at least she looked beautiful in her white wedding dress and modest veil. She was not to wear them again until his funeral the following summer.

No sooner had the family divided the ashes than Smith went to pieces. The 1993 Playmate of the Year tried to fill the emptiness at the core of her life with Twinkies, Ho-Hos and Dream Pies, junk food sustenance that inflated a frame that had once been chosen to replace Claudia Schiffer as the Guess? jeans model into 200lb at the mercy of liposuction.

But the complexity has not left Smith's life, with the Los Angeles court ruling that fraudulent handling of her late husband's estate by E Pierce left her penniless. Now she faces another hearing in Houston to determine the validity of Marshall's will and is understood to have taken acting classes and lost 50lb in pursuit of justice.

Her attorney says that the outcome of the first case prepares the ground for victory in the second

"Does that change things? Oh, I think it does," said Philip Boesch. "It's pretty powerful language and it's telling of the damages done to her."

But her opponent, E Pierce, remained defiant. "This extraordinary decision is a miscarriage of justice that is not supported by the facts and will not stand up on appeal," he said. "We are confident that a Texas jury that is permitted to evaluate all of the evidence in the case will allow my father's clearly stated wishes to be carried out."

Relatives who fight for their rights

 John Lennon's son, Julian, had to fight a protracted battle before he could claim any of his inheritance. His share of the former Beatle's £250m estate was put in trust until he reached 30.

But Yoko Ono, Lennon's second wife, gained control of the estate in 1980 after her husband was shot dead outside their apartment in New York. She said she was told to pay Julian's inheritance only when he was mature enough.

"I don't want a legal war but if I have to, I will," the 32-year-old declared in 1994. "I'm trying to talk things over with Yoko, I only hope it will be amicable. The cash isn't the issue, it's the principle. My father wanted me to be looked after when I reached 30 - but there has been nothing."

Two years later, after wrangling between lawyers, Yoko Ono, then 63, issued her stepson with an ultimatum of "growing up" or not getting a penny. She subsequently agreed to pay Julian $20m (£12m) on the grounds that he had finally matured.

 The only daughter of the British artist Henry Moore took the foundation which controlled her father's works to court, claiming ownership of sculptures and drawings estimated to be worth up to £200m.

Mary Danowski and her three children attempted to win title to the disputed works in 1993. The four would have inherited all his estate if the charitable foundation had not been set up.

Mr Moore gave the charity his entire estate with the exception of his Hertfordshire home and his studios. After his death in 1986 a dispute arose over who owned the works.

 Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza de Kaszon (Heini to his friends), the owner of a collection of 1,500 paintings, including several masterpieces, is at loggerheads with his eldest son, Georg Heinrich (Heini Jnr to friends). They are battling over control of the Thyssen Bornemisza group which produces industrial equipment and a profit of about £60m a year.

Baron Thyssen, who transferred the group to his son in 1983, began a lawsuit in Bermuda last year in which he claimed he was owed tens of millions of dollars by Heini Jnr as part of the handover deal. He bemoaned the greed of his boy, writing: "I want you to know that it remains my intention that each of my children should obtain his or her proper share of my assets upon my death. At present, Heini Jnr has manoeuvred himself into a position where, in the absence of action on my part, he would get far too much, and I wish to correct this."

With the art collection at stake, as well as nine houses across the world, not to mention the group itself, there is much to play for.

Two years later, after wrangling between lawyers, Yoko Ono, then 63, issued her stepson with an ultimatum of "growing up" or not getting a penny. She subsequently agreed to pay Julian $20m (£12m) on the grounds that he had finally matured.  The only daughter of the British artist Henry Moore took the foundation which controlled her father's works to court, claiming ownership of sculptures and drawings estimated to be worth up to £200m. Mary Danowski and her three children attempted to win title to the disputed works in 1993. The four would have inherited all his estate if the charitable foundation had not been set up. Mr Moore gave the charity his entire estate with the exception of his Hertfordshire home and his studios. After his death in 1986 a dispute arose over who owned the works.  Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza de Kaszon (Heini to his friends), the owner of a collection of 1,500 paintings, including several masterpieces, is at loggerheads with his eldest son, Georg Heinrich (Heini Jnr to friends). They are battling over control of the Thyssen Bornemisza group which produces industrial equipment and a profit of about £60m a year. fields.headline: Tomorrow's world
fields.standfirst:
Rising oil prices and voters prepared to take to the streets could give Labour a rocky second term
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government's defeat over pensions is a pointer to the central dilemma it will face if - as is still overwhelmingly likely - Labour wins the next general election.
fields.body:
The government's defeat over pensions is a pointer to the central dilemma it will face if - as is still overwhelmingly likely - Labour wins the next general election.

Those in Brighton who applauded Barbara Castle's plea for a restoration of the link between the basic state pension and rising national earnings have public opinion on their side. But many voters who wish to see a rise in the state pension are opposed to any increase in taxation. Some will undoubtedly have supported the fuel protesters a couple of weeks ago. There is a basic contradiction in British attitudes to taxation and public spending.

Whatever the size of its majority, the next Labour government will face two risks: the end of an economic boom fuelled by cheap energy and the continued rise of the politics of direct action. Each poses dilemmas for which the government seems ill prepared. Together they could propel it into a different world.

It is too soon to know how sharp a shock high oil prices will inflict on the world economy. The developed world is less dependent on oil than it was at the time of the last oil shock 30 years ago. We are a good deal more energy- efficient. In real terms the price of oil is still low, and the release of strategic oil reserves in Europe and then the US may push it lower. So far, we are not facing a price hike of the sort that triggered recession in the 70s.

Even so, the tripling of the oil price over the past two years should serve as a warning. The new economy is not that new. Business still depends crucially on energy inputs. A case can be made that the long boom in rich coun tries at the end of the 20th century was more a side effect of cheap oil than the result of new technologies.

Moreover, the prospects of the world economy over the coming year depend crucially on the weather. A cold winter will increase fuel consumption and push up the oil price. In the US, where dependency on cheap energy is greatest and expectations of the new economy are most exaggerated, the shock could be severe - not least on Wall Street. There is a lesson here for anyone who still thinks that living standards in the richest countries can go on rising indefinitely, regardless of finite resources.

There is also a challenge for the government. Mr Blair came to power on the back of two huge gifts of fortune - a Tory party more discredited and despised than it had been in living memory, and an ongoing economic boom. Neither of these circumstances can reasonably be expected to last forever. At present, though, a sharp change in the economic climate poses a greater risk to the government than the rather remote prospect of a sustained Tory revival.

In an ironic reversal of fortune, the fuel protests and the defeat on pensions in Brighton have caught the government in a pincer. Its reputation now hangs on how successful it is in reconciling demands for higher public expenditure with the resistance of financial markets - and large numbers of voters - to higher taxes. In turn, this depends to a considerable extent on how it responds to the eruption of populist street politics.

The leakage of political energy away from established parties is a familiar fact of the age, but its implications have gone largely unexplored. When political initiative shifts on to the streets, government loses its capacity to implement any clear strategy. If it responds by trying to second guess an increasingly fickle public it can lose all credibility. As the former Tory MP George Walden has noted in his incisive recent book, The New Elites, the end result of the politics of populism is that people come to view their leaders with contempt. During the past weeks, when for a time it plainly lost control of events, the government came perilously close to being seen in this way.

One of the lessons of the past few weeks, is how easily and quickly a postmodern economy can be disrupted. In a matter of days, a loose, leaderless network of about 2,000 farmers and hauliers linked together by mobile phones was able to bring the country to the verge of standstill. It is hard to believe that this lesson will be forgotten - either by the people who carried off this coup, or by future protesters. The government will probably have to get used to direct action as a recurrent feature of politics.

There is another, even more disturbing, lesson. Voters will not tolerate the levels of taxation required to provide the public services, environmental policies and pensions they insist they want. So far, the government has managed to straddle this contradiction. Boosted by a booming economy and a series of windfalls, tax revenues are buoyant. But with a further rise in the price of oil this could change very quickly. It will be infinitely more difficult to meet voters' conflicting demands when the economy is in recession.

The government's dilemma has always been how to promote social-democratic values at a time when many traditional social-democratic policies have ceased to be effective. The contradictory public attitudes expressed in Brighton and at the petrol pumps suggest the next Labour government will face choices harder than any it has had to make so far.

John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE

fields.trailText: Speculation that the European Commission is preparing to clear the controversial £80bn merger between America Online with media group Time Warner mounted last night.
fields.body:
Speculation that the European Commission is preparing to clear the controversial £80bn merger between America Online with media group Time Warner mounted last night.

The outlook for EMI Music's £13 bn proposed tie-up with Warner Music, which is closely linked to the AOL deal, is, however, less bright and it has emerged that Brussels is likely to block that merger.

Competition experts from the 15 member states met in Brussels behind closed doors on Wednesday to discuss the two mega-mergers and are reported to have favoured such an approach. According to one EU source, Mario Monti, the EC competition commissioner, has yet to take a final decision on the two deals but unless he receives any significant last minute concessions from EMI or Warner Music this is exactly what he intends to do.

fields.headline: That Pinter enigma
fields.trailText: Harold Pinter: our greatest living playwright has just turned 70, and frankly he shows no sign of mellowing.
fields.body:
Seventy years old. And still angry. And when I say "angry", I mean absolutely furious. I'm talking about Harold Pinter, of course: our greatest living playwright has just turned 70, and frankly he shows no sign of mellowing.

Only last Saturday, at a finger-buffet served by their friendly staff in Harold's lovely Holland Park home, a friend of the family asked him whether he didn't think Richard Nixon was under-rated vis-a-vis foreign policy. After a brief pause to finish off his smoked salmon puff with chervil and cottage cheese in a pastry wrap, Harold slammed his fist down on the nearest table, a courageous move if somewhat impulsive, as a large dish of profiteroles had been placed there only minutes before.

It might have been a disaster, but luckily most of the profiteroles stayed in the rough vicinity of the table, and the vast majority of the remaining 10-20% flew through the air before being fortuitously caught in the nooks and crannies of guests' apparel. Lady Antonia smiled benignly at the few profiteroles that were now slithering down their covetable Regency-style wallpaper, secure in the knowledge that not five years ago she had redecorated the room employing Sanderson's eezi-wipe wallpaper throughout, ready for just such an eventuality.

The room fell silent. "I take your point," replied the family friend who had originally asked the Nixon question, anxious to smooth things over. Harold simply glowered back. The family friend smiled diplomatically and pressed on. "I'd have to agree with you that he should have listened more to the admirable Kissinger, if that's what you mean," he said - and bang went the meringues too.

But we were all of us agreed that he is undoubtedly our greatest living playwright. "He's undoubtedly our greatest living playwright," I said to Joan Bakewell as we queued for the wine cup together. "Oh, yes," she replied, "I'd have to agree that he's undoubtedly our greatest living playwright." Joan then turned to Melvyn Bragg, and asked him where he stood on the issue. "In my opinion," said Melvyn, "he's our greatest living playwright. Undoubtedly," he replied, asking Germaine Greer, just behind him in the queue, if she agreed. "Pinter?" said Germaine, ever the iconoclast, "Harold Pinter? I'm going to stick my neck out here and say that IN MY OPINION without a doubt he's our greatest living playwright".

For 70 years, he has literally stunned audiences the world over. The curtain goes up. A man in a room. The man is very ordinary. And so is the room. Another man enters. Or perhaps a woman. Or both. No one knows why they are there, least of all them. Who are they? Heaven knows. They talk, haltingly. They make inquiries of one another. One of them opens a window. An air of menace enters. The first man is pushed over by the other. Words are exchanged. They glare at one another. They sit down. But in the end, no one knows any more about them than they did at the beginning. And so the curtain goes down on yet another extraordinary Pinter Enigma. Brilliant!

Who can forget The Caretaker? Who can forget The Birthday Party? And who can forget all those other unforgettable plays _ their titles five, 10, 20 years on far too elusive and subtle to be caught by the crude umbrella of human memory?

May I share my own memories of the man himself with a wider readership? I first met him back in the late 60s - or was it the early 70s? - when he was still seen as one of the angry young men, forever battling against the out-of-date theatrical establishment. I had just entered the green room of the Old Vic. There he was, the man himself, easily winning an arm-wrestling match against the ailing Terence Rattigan.

It was a matter of minutes before Rattigan was yelling in pain, begging for mercy. Next up was William Douglas Home, whose recent entertainment, The Reluctant Debutante, had proved such an outstanding success during its run at Her Majesty's. But in 30 seconds he, too, had cracked, having sprained his knuckles in three separate places.

All of us there knew we were present at an historic watershed in the English theatre - and how right we were. Overnight, West End theatrical costumiers were forced to shred their crinolines, dinner jackets, tennis whites and tiaras and to replace them with a wide selection of grubby two-piece suits, ill fitting T-shirts and expertly smeared overalls.

Thirty years later, Pinter is still very much Pinter. Who can forget his last play, Celebration, in which he so movingly portrayed the plight of a restaurant manager confronted with a room full of vulgar paying customers - some of them in trade? Angry? No, don't talk to Harold about angry. He's not angry. He's livid.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: Balkan wars are over

fields.headline: At last it's possible to say that the Balkan wars are over
fields.standfirst:
Kostunica is not perfect, but he has offered Serbs deliverance
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Kostunica is not perfect, but he has offered Serbs deliverance.
fields.body:
The young Joyce Cary went off in 1912 to join the Balkan armies fighting to expel the Turks because he wanted to experience a war and thought that this might be the last fight for many years. Coming up with the Montenegrins to take the surrender of the Turks at Scutari six months later, he wrote of passing through "the broken wire of the February battle, many small graves, many little shelters full of spent cases. There was a sweet sickly smell of dead unburied bodies." The men were ordered to take cover as the final negotiations took place. "As the order was passed back from flagman to flagman," Cary wrote in a tone of finality, "the companies sank down in succession, the padding and rustling of moccasins ceased, and there was a sudden dead silence."

Cary, like many others, thought that would be the end of the killing. But establishing nation states in the rivalrous and demographically mixed region over which Turkey had ruled proved a lengthy and bloody business. The Balkan wars did not end with Turkey's defeat, for the peoples of the peninsula were soon fighting each other. Their conflicts then contributed to, and were caught up in, the two world wars. They subsided afterwards as Moscow's order took hold, only to fire up again, in the case of Yugoslavia, after the disintegration of the communist world.

But this week it is at last possible to say that the Balkan wars are over. The belated last chapter of the story of nationalist conflict in the region, which has involved Europe and North America in 10 years of agonised diplomatic, humanitarian and ultimately military intervention, has ended.

True, there could be some kind of terminal struggle in Serbia itself, although that seems the less likely prospect. A diminished Milosevic may stagger on for a while. Certainly a confused transition is to be expected, since the country has no real mechanisms for a transfer of power. Violence can also hardly be ruled out in the future in such places as Kosovo, Montenegro or Albania.

But the repudiation of Slobodan Milosevic by such a large proportion of his own people, in part because his military project failed so completely, must mark, too, a repudiation of war as a means of pursuing national objectives. Vojislav Kostunica does not differ much from Milosevic on Serbia's right to Kosovo; on the status of the Bosnian Serb entity, Republika Srpska; or on the desirability of Montenegro staying with Serbia. But he would not march to secure them. Milosevic himself could not now, after such a reverse, order such actions. They have become impossible.

In choosing Kostunica in such large numbers, it may be said that the Serbians have voted for a clean Milosevic. They voted for a man who has never said that Serbia's objectives in the wars of the last 10 years were wrong; who denies the authority of the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague; who considers Nato intervention an outrage: and who insists that Serbia will not be a vassal state of the west.

Yet it is clear that "something big has moved deep in the Serbian electoral heart", as the journalist Dejan Anastasijevic put it in a recent essay on the Serbian opposition. Faced with a discredited but still powerful leader on the one hand and an opposition with a talent for throwing away its opportunities on the other, Serbs somehow threaded their way through these twin obstacles and lighted upon a man who offered the possibility of deliverance.

Kostunica did not win them; they found him. When the first opinion polls in July showed Kostunica achieving high ratings, other politicians, and the pollsters themselves, could not believe the figures. Kostunica had been on the political scene for years and had never attracted such support. The pollsters redid the surveys and found them accurate.

Kostunica had not, unlike the much more prominent opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic, joined Milosevic in government, but his patriotism, as Serbs understand it, was not in doubt. He was too much of a middling figure to be blamed for the opposition's episodic lurches from unity to disunity or for the dithering which Draskovic, in particular, showed on the one or two occasions when it might have been possible to bounce Milosevic out of power. This combination of qualifications suddenly had magic. Serbs had discovered, in what to outsiders seemed a blasted political landscape, a man who they could use to bring about change.

If they are to be congratulated on a degree of good sense that was not quite expected, it is also worth saying that Kostunica's showing is some sort of vindication of recent western policy, for all its imperfections and errors, toward former Yugoslavia. Western leaders did, in the end, rid themselves of the habit of consulting with the chief arsonist about how to put out fires and they did, in the end, understand that change in Serbia had to be the fundamental goal of policy. Critics took a perverse delight in pointing out that Milosevic, like Saddam, was still very much in charge and that neither war nor economic boycott seemed able to shift him. But that was to ignore his progressive loss of political credit, the gradual shrinkage of his constituency and the blunting of what had once been sharp political instincts.

The increasing prominence of his wife and her strange party, the splits within the government and now the failure not only in the presiden tial contest but in the municipal polls show how telling this has been. When police, soldiers and officials vote against the leader who has sustained them, he must be far gone. To this process western policy has contributed - how much, admittedly, is not yet clear - by general pressure on the regime since the Kosovo intervention and by encouraging and funding a range of opposition and human rights groups.

Democracy has been a curse and a blessing in former Yugoslavia. It brought war, but it can also bring down those who waged war, as it did in Croatia and as it is to be hoped it has now done in Serbia. Serbians voted last weekend in the knowledge that the ultimate basis of Milosevic's power was their freely given votes, as his long and nearly unbroken record of success in countless elections shows. Now they have taken them away. It is time to start thinking about a post-war, post-Milosevic era - whether he is gone by the weekend or whether he manages to hang on for some while by one subterfuge or another. There will be plenty of problems in such an era, but they will be better problems than those of the last dreadful decade.

Memoir of the Bobotes by Joyce Cary is published by Phoenix Press

 Out of Time edited by Dejan Anastasijevic with Anthony Borden is published by Beta News Agency and the Institute for War and Peace Reporting

He was too much of a middling figure to be blamed for the opposition's episodic lurches from unity to disunity or for the dithering which Draskovic, in particular, showed on the one or two occasions when it might have been possible to bounce Milosevic out of power. This combination of qualifications suddenly had magic. Serbs had discovered, in what to outsiders seemed a blasted political landscape, a man who they could use to bring about change. If they are to be congratulated on a degree of good sense that was not quite expected, it is also worth saying that Kostunica's showing is some sort of vindication of recent western policy, for all its imperfections and errors, toward former Yugoslavia. Western leaders did, in the end, rid themselves of the habit of consulting with the chief arsonist about how to put out fires and they did, in the end, understand that change in Serbia had to be the fundamental goal of policy. Critics took a perverse delight in pointing out that Milosevic, like Saddam, was still very much in charge and that neither war nor economic boycott seemed able to shift him. But that was to ignore his progressive loss of political credit, the gradual shrinkage of his constituency and the blunting of what had once been sharp political instincts. The increasing prominence of his wife and her strange party, the splits within the government and now the failure not only in the presiden tial contest but in the municipal polls show how telling this has been. When police, soldiers and officials vote against the leader who has sustained them, he must be far gone. To this process western policy has contributed - how much, admittedly, is not yet clear - by general pressure on the regime since the Kosovo intervention and by encouraging and funding a range of opposition and human rights groups. Democracy has been a curse and a blessing in former Yugoslavia. It brought war, but it can also bring down those who waged war, as it did in Croatia and as it is to be hoped it has now done in Serbia. Serbians voted last weekend in the knowledge that the ultimate basis of Milosevic's power was their freely given votes, as his long and nearly unbroken record of success in countless elections shows. Now they have taken them away. It is time to start thinking about a post-war, post-Milosevic era - whether he is gone by the weekend or whether he manages to hang on for some while by one subterfuge or another. There will be plenty of problems in such an era, but they will be better problems than those of the last dreadful decade. fields.headline: Nationwide alert for bomb attacks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Security services expect a bombing campaign by dissident Irish republicans between now and Christmas, and yesterday warned the public to be on guard.
fields.body:
Security services expect a bombing campaign by dissident Irish republicans between now and Christmas, and yesterday warned the public to be on guard.

The Real IRA, believed to have been behind the rocket fired at MI6's headquarters in central London last week, has the capacity to mount further high profile attacks in Britain, according to intelligence sources.

David Veness, head of special operations at the Metropolitan police, said yesterday that inquiries were under way to trace witnesses.

"This was the third incident in the capital since June and although the attack on the SIS [Secret Intelligence Service, commonly known as MI6] building was different to those at Hammersmith and Acton, all three could well be part of a terror campaign."

He warned: "We can not rule out further incidents in the capital or elsewhere in the country. It is essential the public remain vigilant at all times."

Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, said: "Fighting terrorism has got to be our priority. When you have limited resources then other areas such as fighting street crime are going to suffer."

The Real IRA's tactics appear to be to attack targets for propaganda value and disruption. The attack on MI6 and the placing of bombs on Hammersmith bridge in June and on a railway at Acton, west London, in July led to widespread chaos.

Intelligence sources believe the Real IRA has up to 200 supporters, half of them prepared to engage directly in terrorist activities. Though they include a number of defectors from the IRA, many are young recruits with no previous record.

Security sources say the dissident group has no links with the IRA and is not acting for it. They do not know whether the group has old IRA weapons.

The Real IRA possesses battlefield weapons which can be carried in bags.

Scotland Yard has reviewed the safety of public buildings and popular attractions in London.

However, it acknowledged that it was impossible in an open society to guarantee the security of buildings by physical means.

The 3ft-long rocket-propelled grenade anti-tank weapon which hit the MI6 building, but caused little damage, is believed to have been smuggled into Ireland from Croatia via France and subsequently into Britain.

It is the first time such a weapon - designed to penetrate light armour - has been used by Irish groups in Britain. Part of the launcher was left behind and is being tested.

fields.headline: 'Luddites' we should not ignore
fields.standfirst:
Instead of vilifying the Prague protesters, we could learn from them
Special report: the IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: Prague is over; the IMF/World Bank meeting has shut down early, thanks to pressure from activists who travelled from all over the world to protest against the bank's policies in developing countries. To most people it looked like yet another set-piece confrontation between a ragtag bunch of scruffy protesters and hard-headed cops in riot gear; after Seattle and Washington came S26, the Battle of Prague.
fields.body:
Prague is over; the IMF/World Bank meeting has shut down early, thanks to pressure from activists who travelled from all over the world to protest against the bank's policies in developing countries. To most people it looked like yet another set-piece confrontation between a ragtag bunch of scruffy protesters and hard-headed cops in riot gear; after Seattle and Washington came S26, the Battle of Prague.

Yes, there was violence. "Black block" anarchists threw rocks and Molotov cocktails at the police; police charged and beat protesters, fired teargas and water cannon. But even the wildest of commentators estimate the number of violent activists as 1-2% of the 15,000 protesters. Almost all of the many hundreds of NGOs, trade unions and affinity groups attending were peaceful. Yesterday reports were coming out of Prague about police brutality and human-rights abuses against arrested protesters. Members of Ya Basta, a popular group of Italian activists who were extraordinarily well-disciplined and restrained in their direct action, have been labelled "terrorists" by the Czech authorities.

But much of the protest was a positive affair: there was a samba band, a pink cardboard tank, upbeat trade unionists from Mexico to Manchester; there were well-attended counter-summits, with intellectuals and philosophers theorising on the nuts and bolts of the movement. Many of the demonstrators could give, on demand, a sophisticated critique of the global economy.

Focusing on the violence makes it easy to demonise the demonstrators as something dangerous and "other". They are dismissed in a variety of contradictory ways: they're rioters, they're rich middle-class kids with nothing better to do, they're crusty undesirables, they're disorganised, they lack vision, they're Luddites. But by condemning them in such crude terms, we condemn ourselves to misunderstand the most significant political movement to emerge in a generation.

The Telegraph casts the activists as "highly educated, bourgeois offspring rejecting the ways and wealth of their parents' generation". Well, you do have to have the fare to get there. But when it comes to anti-globalisation, the developing world has led the way. The west is playing catch-up. Anti-IMF/World Bank protests have been held all over the global south for more than a decade, from Indonesia to Brazil, from the Philippines to Bolivia.

Critics of the movement can't bear the anarchy of it; they see its disparateness as cluelessness rather than a deliberate attempt to overcome traditional hierarchies. But if a movement can force such powerful institutions as the IMF and World Bank to come to a halt early, and if protesters can get inside the conference centre in spite of 11,000 riot police, 5,000 army back-up and a few tanks, their organising skills might be considered rather impressive.

In the run-up to Tuesday's demonstration I attended the convergence centre, where "spokes council" meetings took place, and found the sense of community and organisation there astonishing and moving. Every "affinity group" - NGO or group of friends - sent a spokesperson to meetings to make decisions and work out strategy. It sounds impossible to contain, and it was laborious, but it worked and consensus was found. It felt like proper democracy in a way that the ballot box does not.

I was aware, too, of something different about the experience of S26, but it wasn't until the journey home that I realised what it was. No one had tried to sell me anything. The night-time parties weren't sponsored by a beer company. Nothing was branded.

The movement's umbrella is a huge one, which can accommodate a vast array of opinions. Is that so terrible a thing? The Zapatistas - heroes to many protesters - say that anti-globalisation demonstrators are made up of "one no, many yeses". The no is to rampant capitalism, the yes is to different kinds of societies. It's web-like, it looks like the internet, and it couldn't exist without it.

The movement needs to ask itself where it goes from here. It must find a role that is not only, as Naomi Klein, chronicler of anti-corporatism, puts it, turning up at international meetings like Deadheads following the Grateful Dead. But this is a new movement, and it's in no hurry. Whether it burns out or turns into the next big thing will take time to see.

Clare Short says that the protesters are "today's Luddites ... their call to halt historical change and tear down our international institutions offers no solution" - as if neoliberal globalisation were an inevitability. It isn't. It's a particular form of economics, of human behaviour and development - as Nelson Mandela pointedly told Labour's conference in Brighton yesterday - and resisting it might just be more modern and radical than critics of the anti-globalisation movement dare to think.

webTitle: New drug will boost breast cancer fight

fields.headline: New drug will boost breast cancer fight
fields.trailText: Tamoxifen, the drug used to treat breast cancer, looks set to lose its wonder status following the announcement that a new medicine out-performed it in trials on women with advanced tumours.
fields.body:
Tamoxifen, the drug used to treat breast cancer, looks set to lose its wonder status following the announcement that a new medicine out-performed it in trials on women with advanced tumours.

The announcement, at the European breast cancer conference in Brussels yesterday, will alarm the Department of Health because it has serious implications for the NHS drugs bill.

Because tamoxifen has been around for a long time and is out of patent, it is cheap, at £10 a month per patient. The new drug, letrozole, costs £85 a month. If it receives a licence for first-line treatment of women with advanced breast cancer, as the manufacturers expect, it must inevitably be referred to the national institute for clinical excellence for a decision on cost effectiveness. Novartis claims that up to 20,000 breast cancer patients in Britain could benefit from the new drug.

The trials, involving more than 900 post-menopausal women, compared letrozole with tamoxifen. All of them had tumours that were so large that breast conserving surgery was not considered possible by their doctors. The results showed that more women who took a course of the new drug were able to avoid having mastectomies - 45% compared with 35% on tamoxifen.

Tamoxifen halts the progression of the disease for an average of six months. The trials showed that letrozole continued working for 9.4 months. Women on the new drug had a 30% lower risk of their cancer progressing than those on tamoxifen.

One of the international experts who helped develop the drug, Stephen Johnston, consultant medical oncologist at the Royal Marsden hospital in London, said: "For us it is very exciting that the trials have shown such a clear and dramatic benefit and for the first time have substantial improvements in results over tamoxifen.

"It represents a real benefit because we can say to patients that there is a treatment that can control their cancer for longer."

Paul Ellis, consultant clinical oncologist at Guy's, St Thomas' and Kings' Cancer Centre, said that the results were good news for women in Britain where breast cancer rates are among the highest in the world.

"These findings are likely to have a major impact on established treatment protocols," he said.

A paper published today in the Lancet medical journal shows that the numbers of women given the wrong treatment in the US for early stage breast cancer has risen. Some were unnecessarily given mastectomies, but more were given breast conservation treatment when they needed radical surgery.

Richard Sainsbury, from Huddersfield royal infirmary, said in a commentary article that British women with early stage breast cancer were still unnecessarily having a breast removed.

fields.headline: Winsor clamps down on Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rail regulator Tom Winsor is to impose new controls on Railtrack to prevent it disposing of rail and land assets for commercial gain, his office announced last night.
fields.body:
Rail regulator Tom Winsor is to impose new controls on Railtrack to prevent it disposing of rail and land assets for commercial gain, his office announced last night.

The move follows a complaint from a train operating company at Mr Winsor's own station at Staplehurst in Kent that Railtrack was allowing a supermarket to be constructed on land which the train company wanted as a car park for commuters.

Mr Winsor said that safeguards were needed "to protect against the disposal of these assets - once lost to the railway industry, they would be prohibitively expensive to replace."

Mr Winsor said: "I am proposing that assets within Railtrack's regulated business should be ring-fenced.

"Railtrack benefits from substantial public funding and it is important to make sure that it focuses its resources on the core business of maintaining and developing the railway network."

He published a list of 13 local planning authorities from Scotland to Dorset who have registered concern over the disposal of Railtrack sites. They are mainly on land situated close to railway stations.

When he was appointed last year, Mr Winsor said that Railtrack's network licence was not fit for the purpose of regulating a private sector company with essential public service obligations.

webTitle: Woman jailed and placed on register for sex with boys, 14

fields.headline: Woman jailed and placed on register for sex with boys, 14
fields.trailText: A woman was yesterday jailed for 12 months and placed on the sex offenders' register for 10 years after being found guilty of having sex with two 14-year-old boys who were friends of her daughter.
fields.body:
A woman was yesterday jailed for 12 months and placed on the sex offenders' register for 10 years after being found guilty of having sex with two 14-year-old boys who were friends of her daughter.

Frances Edmonds, 35, had denied having sex with the two boys, who claimed she frequently flirted with them dressed only in a nightie, before sleeping with them on numerous occasions at her home.

The jury at Stafford crown court, who had earlier cleared the mother-of-four of one indecent assault charge, took more than five hours to convict her of three further counts of indecent assault against the two boys at her Staffordshire home.

Judge John Shand told her: "This was not a loving relationship. This was cynical sexual exploitation of young boys."

The judge said the offences were so serious that only a custodial sentence was possible.

He said he accepted that the boys were not coerced into sex and consent was given, but: "The court of appeal has made it plain that no particular distinction should be drawn between men who have intercourse with young girls and women who have intercourse with young boys.

"You showed no frankness and no remorse as a woman in her mid-30s. You flirted with 14-year-old boys and they responded."

Her defence counsel, Mark Hayward, told the court in mitigation: "It is common that cases of sexual abuse usually committed by men on little girls have a cynical element of grooming.

"In this case there is a certain element of flirting that is not acceptable but there is no deliberate attempt to snare a child.

"If anything was done here it was playing on the youths' curiosity. This was generally a too liberal household and she acted out a weakness of character, rather than being a more cynical manipulator of the young."

During the four day trial the jury of six men and six women saw one of the boys, who is now aged 15, break down in tears as he recounted having sex with Edmonds. He told the jury that he "lost count" of the number of times he had slept with her.

The second boy to give evidence, who is now aged 16, claimed he slept with Edmonds on three occasions.

The jury was told that Edmonds ran an "open house" and youngsters would regularly stay at the house after school, drinking, dancing and watching TV. It was also alleged that one of the boys had sex with Edmonds, who was also known as Frankie, while her four-year-old son lay in a cot nearby.

Heidi Kubik, prosecuting, told the court: "Frankie started flirting with the boys wearing revealing clothing and encouraging them to act in a sexually inappropriate way. The defendant developed a sexual relationship with each of these two boys."

Edmonds emphatically denied having sex with either of them. "It didn't happen," she told the jury.

Asked why such "wicked" allegations had been made, she said: "I believe it was for two reasons. I told them off for being in my daughter's bedroom - and my ex-husband was involved in making them [the allegations]."

While giving evidence, Edmonds said one of the boys had picked her up in a fireman's lift, taken her into a bedroom and dropped her on to the bed before pulling a wardrobe across the door and pinning her against the wall. But she managed to get free and escape through a window.

Edmonds told the jury she thought the boy was just having fun and showing off in front of his friends.

Cross-examining the youths, Mr Hayward suggested they had fabricated the whole story and were indulging in an "adolescent fantasy".

Edmonds's children, two boys aged five and seven and two girls aged 10 and 15, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were not in court to hear the verdict. The two youngest will be cared for by their father.

A spokesman for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children declined to comment on the case, but said the charity supported the removal of gender distinction in abuse cases. "There is no evidence to show that young boys seduced by older women are any less likely to be affected than young girls abused by older men."

A spokeswoman for Kidscape, a child protection charity, said: "Twelve months is too low a sentence. She deserves everything she gets. There seems to be one rule for older men who abuse boys and another for older women who abuse boys."

webTitle: Book of quotations offers variations on a theme

fields.headline: Book of quotations offers variations on a theme
fields.trailText: Oxford University Press has produced a dictionary of quotations which departs from traditional collation by author and era, instead grouping entries around subjects.
fields.body:
Oxford University Press has produced a dictionary of quotations which departs from traditional collation by author and era, instead grouping entries around subjects.

The Oxford Dictionary of Thematic Quotations offers more than 600 easy-to-browse contemporary themes, ranging from acting to weather.

"This is a book to which people will turn in order to listen to contemporary discussion on a wide range of topics," said Elizabeth Knowles, managing editor of OUP's quotations dictionaries.

"The thematic divisions focus on issues of today. We have still included remarks from some classic authors, but the topics chosen are those that reflect modern concerns."

She said contrasting comments under each heading would provide readers with food for thought.

The entry for politics, for example, gives Harold Wilson's words on the 1964 sterling crisis: "A week is a long time in politics." But the then backbencher Ken Livingstone said in 1997: "Politics is a marathon, not a sprint." Both observations, it seems, have weathered well.

Under the heading quotations, a remark from Winston Churchill reads: "It is a good thing for an uneducated man to read books of quotations." Yet on the same page the American essayist Ralph Emerson suggests that parroting other people's words limits true thought: "I hate quotation. Tell me what you know."

Ms Knowles said the dictionary incorporated comments from more than 1,000 wits, including contemporary figures such as Joan Collins, Jeremy Paxman and the rap artist Ice Cube.

Noel Gallagher's profane boast as to the crowd pulling power of his band, Oasis - "has God played Knebworth?" - makes it into the dictionary, though it may not prove as resonant as Friedrich Nietzsche's 1882 assault on the almighty: "God is dead: but ... there will perhaps be caves, for ages yet, in which his shadow will be shown."

Ms Knowles identified a recent drift towards the shorter, sometimes more glib soundbite, but cautioned against accusing modern commentators of failing to match up.

"I don't believe the standard has fallen," she said. "What gets overlooked is that the past is represented by the few quotations that have lasted and the many remarks we remember from the last couple of years will not all stand the test of time."

The dictionary includes entries from the few politicians fighting the trend towards verbless soundbites.

Modern topics under discussion include personal computers, which, according to Timothy Leary in 1996, were "the LSD of the 90s", heralding an era in which the US historian Francis Fukuyama last year claimed: "Silicon Valley is the Florence of the late 20th century."

Other contemporary commentators are recorded battling over the role of science in society.

"We ought not to permit a cottage industry in the God business," the US Republican John Marchi said three years ago on hearing that British scientists had cloned a sheep.

But, argues Stephen Jay Gould, science is "an integral part of culture. It's not this for eign thing, done by an arcane priesthood. It is one of the glories of human intellectual tradition."

A number of injudicious remarks are also dredged up. The weather forecaster Michael Fish is quoted on the eve of the October 1987 hurricane as telling his viewers: "A woman rang to say she heard there was a hurricane on the way. Well, don't worry, there isn't."

Jonathan Aitken's comments on "the cancer of bent and twisted journalism" in 1995 are also uncharitably revisited.

 The Oxford Dictionary of Thematic Quotations, edited by Susan Ratcliffe; £14.99.

webTitle: Jay wants to close women's pay gap

fields.headline: Jay wants to close women's pay gap
fields.trailText: Britain will fall behind its European competitors if it fails to close the 19% pay gap between men and women, Lady Jay, the minister for women, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain will fall behind its European competitors if it fails to close the 19% pay gap between men and women, Lady Jay, the minister for women, warned yesterday.

Bemoaning the fact that women earned only 81p for every pound earned by men, that they dominated the 10 lowest paid occupations, and that just one company director in 20 was female, the leader of the House of Lords said: "For years, we've fought to end these inequalities. Today we have to win for economic reasons as well as for social justice. "In the skills-based new economy, if we, as women, do not have equality, not only will we lose out, but business and the country will lose out in productivity and competitiveness."

Lady Jay continued: "As a government, we will ensure that in the future no women will have to wait years for their right to equal pay to be realised."

Her pledge came in a week in which ministers at Brighton outlined how the Equal Pay Act could be amended to make it easier for women to challenge unfair wage levels.

Under the reforms, the work of industrial tribunals will be streamlined with employers forced to respond to questionnaires from industrial tribunals within a fixed period to prevent businesses prolonging the process.

webTitle: Welfare minister admits missing family but denies he is planning to quit

fields.headline: Welfare minister admits missing family but denies he is planning to quit
fields.trailText: Alistair Darling, one of the rising stars of the cabinet, was forced to deny yesterday that he is intending to abandon his political career after he spoke of the "increasing problem" of    balancing work and family life.
fields.body:
Alistair Darling, one of the rising stars of the cabinet, was forced to deny yesterday that he is intending to abandon his political career after he spoke of the "increasing problem" of balancing work and family life. The social security secretary, who is being lined up for a key role in Labour's election campaign, insisted that he relished his work and was determined to remain as an MP. Mr Darling issued his statement last night after a frank interview with the New Statesman in which he spoke of the wrench of leaving his wife and two children in Edinburgh during the week.

"It's an increasing problem," he said. "The only solution is for me to stop what I'm doing." Mr Darling told the magazine that he was not intending to resign. But he fuelled speculation about his political future when he said: "My children are nine and 12 and every Monday morning is an increasing wrench... There are times when I think that all I've got is access. I don't see them during the week; I'm never there."

Mr Darling indicated that Mo Mowlam's decision to stand down at the next election had made him think about his future. "Politicians have a limited shelf life and I suppose one of the nice things for Mo is that she has chosen when to go."

Asked whether he was thinking of following in Ms Mowlam's footsteps, Mr Darling, 46, said: "I've no plans at the moment. But politics isn't a career and I don't see it as a career."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Hats off to the British Olympic team and their medal-winning ways. No wonder Mr Tony Blair felt able to announce an extra £750m for sport during his speech to the party in Brighton on Tuesday.
fields.body:
 Hats off to the British Olympic team and their medal-winning ways. No wonder Mr Tony Blair felt able to announce an extra £750m for sport during his speech to the party in Brighton on Tuesday. Except that Alastair Campbell intended Mr Tony to break the good news on the Breakfast With Frost programme the previous Sunday - but the soufflé-like toughness of the interview meant Mr Tony simply forgot to mention it. That didn't stop the party machine sending a deluge of faxes to Labour party offices and local newspapers throughout the country, explaining how Tony had found three quarter of a billion pounds to keep kids off the street. "Speaking on Breakfast with Frost this morning," said the multitude of press releases on Sunday, "the prime minister described the programme as being good for sport and good for cutting crime." It just goes to show: even Labour party apparatchiks can't be bothered to watch either Tony Blair or David Frost at that hour on a Sunday morning.

 A glance at the letters page opposite shows the definitive answer (from Kew Gardens, no less) on the dangers of eating yew berries, described in last Saturday's Daily Express as "sweet tasting". But Rosie Boycott isn't the first Express editor to try to put the paper's long-suffering readership out of their misery this way. A Diary reader recalls a stir back in the 1950s when the Express printed a recipe suggesting readers substitute highly poisonous laurel leaves for bay leaves.

 And now some news that will settle all those tedious pub arguments. The Severn bridge has been named Britain's top bridge by the Civic Trust. But what of the wobbly Millennium bridge, surely the most famous bridge of recent years? "The trust only considered winners of the trust's bridge award between 1960 and 1999," said Julie Thrift, awards officer for the trust, cruelly denying Ove Arup's construction being considered. An optimistic Ms Thrift hopes the bridge will be entered sometime in the future. "It's ground-breaking, so you have to expect some teething problems," said Julie. "You must understand that bridges are very complex things."

 My so-called rival at the Times had a cracking tale yesterday about Andrew Rawnsley, author of the frothtastic tittle-tattle on Brown and Blair, being barred from entering a knees-up at the Labour conference, and doing the usual "don't you know who I am?" routine. A cracking tale, as I say, but only half true. Andrew rings to say he in fact had an invitation to the party, but was trying to talk the doorman into letting in Times journalist Alice Miles. While Andrew distracted the jobsworth, Alice slipped by. "Andrew was just being his usual chivalrous self," said Alice.

 We all know the Tory party front bench is short of talent, but who could have predicted this week's stunning political come-back from the dead (literally). Under the heading "Tory shadow cabinet reshuffle", ePolitix.com's website readers were told: "Sir Keith Joseph has been appointed shadow chief secretary to the Treasury."

 Long-time Diary readers (both of you) will be excited to hear that the Guardian staff is to be enhanced by a familiar name: Oofy Wegg-Prosser! The former special adviser to Peter Mandelson is about to join the Guardian Unlimited website empire. How things have changed since the Diary tested Oofy's rapid rebuttal skills - when he set a new world record squashing whispers that Mandy was to make an aerobics video ("Fitness for the Over-40s") with Dame Thora Hird, in 0.63 seconds. Relations were even broken off on January 8, 1997 over the "soup quote" fiasco (when Oofy failed to make his refusal of a bowl of nourishing soup retroactively off the record). And now he's one of us. It's a bittersweet moment, though. We've gained a colleague, but lost an old friend.

fields.headline: Brighton diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: • Tonytown was supposed to run like clockwork with everything, including the spontaneity, scripted in advance. Take yesterday afternoon. A copy of the three-page running order details how TB, JP, NM, G (Tony Blair, John Prescott, Nelson Mandela and singer Gabrielle) plus chums choreographed as if in one of Andrew Lloyd-Webber's musicals. Stand up, sit down, enter stage left, exit stage left, get Pauline on,   get Pauline off, enter Cherie, escort Cherie on, take Gabrielle on, take Gabrielle off (not forgetting her microphone), kids in T-shirts form up stage right, platform party goes into audience, T-shirt kids applaud platform party off, TB takes NM to lectern, etc, etc, etc. When Mandela failed to stand in a purple oval at 15.55 as instructed, a dark suited figure directed Blair and Prescott to move him two yards to the right. Even the world's greatest living statesman was treated as an extra in the new Labour extravaganza.
fields.body:
 Tonytown was supposed to run like clockwork with everything, including the spontaneity, scripted in advance. Take yesterday afternoon. A copy of the three-page running order details how TB, JP, NM, G (Tony Blair, John Prescott, Nelson Mandela and singer Gabrielle) plus chums choreographed as if in one of Andrew Lloyd-Webber's musicals. Stand up, sit down, enter stage left, exit stage left, get Pauline on, get Pauline off, enter Cherie, escort Cherie on, take Gabrielle on, take Gabrielle off (not forgetting her microphone), kids in T-shirts form up stage right, platform party goes into audience, T-shirt kids applaud platform party off, TB takes NM to lectern, etc, etc, etc. When Mandela failed to stand in a purple oval at 15.55 as instructed, a dark suited figure directed Blair and Prescott to move him two yards to the right. Even the world's greatest living statesman was treated as an extra in the new Labour extravaganza.

 Labour had Mandela this year, the Tories a rally for General Pinochet last year. Little more needs saying except the former ANC leader appears to have been keeping an eye on Tonytown. Earlier in the week a pensioner complained there were no OAPs on the top table. After his first standing ovation, Mandela, in his late seventies, quipped: "I know why you've come here. You're just curious. You want to see what a pensioner from the colonies looks like."

 The great man's presence was also used to ditch the traditional singing of The Red Flag to close the conference. Millbank claimed it had been missed in 1996 but some fear its absence in Labour's centenary year means Blair seized his chance to consign it to the dustbin of history. A recorded version of Let's Work Together, Tonytown's happy clappy theme tune, was instead played repeatedly.

 Tonytown's "Mr Big" evaded capture, the master criminal remaining at large after stealing the Family Planning Association's condom demonstrator. Another was sent down from London and the disrupted competition to find the fastest contraceptive fitter was won by a male delegate in an impressive three seconds. For some reason the FPA has decided not to re-run the contest at next week's gathering of the Blimps and blue rinse brigade along the south coast in Bournemouth. Willieville, not quite as big as Tonytown though it has pretensions, promises to be a far more sedate affair. Or perhaps not...
