fields.headline: BTG seeks £120m to expand
fields.trailText: BTG, which commercialises patents, announced yesterday that it was raising £120m to expand the business and create a new company dedicated to genomics.
fields.body:
BTG, which commercialises patents, announced yesterday that it was raising £120m to expand the business and create a new company dedicated to genomics.

A one for nine rights issue, at £12 a share, will enable it to exploit new developments around the world.

The company will channel £35m into further varicose vein treatments, £5m into genomics-based technologies and £21m into developing and buying new biotechnologies - including £9.5m for new cancer treatments.

Rusi Kathoke, BTG's finance director, said they had been anticipating the move for 18 months and had "very detailed plans" for investments.

"The money we have raised is for us to do more of the same and get greater value," he said.

"Our aim is to be able to feed potential technologies into our portfolio that will generate the sort of patent volumes Varisolve [its existing varicose vein treatment] has achieved. If we can do that, we'd be on a totally different level."

The deeply discounted rights issue, underwritten by Credit Suisse First Boston, initially left BTG's shares lower in early trading. But by the market's close yesterday they had risen 55p, or 3.4%, to £16.60. Dr Erling Refsum, biotech analyst with Nomura, said the reaction was "very positive". "People like BTG and the shares have been so tightly held it has been difficult to get hold of them," he said.

"They have bought the story that this is going to make BTG grow faster."

Until now the company has concentrated on identifying early stage technologies being developed by universities and research centres.

Varisolve, which it bought from a surgeon in 1996, has been one of its biggest successes. BTG has since spun this off into a separate company, Provensis.The company's portfolio at present covers more than 300 technologies, protected by over 5,000 granted patents and patent applications.

Earlier this year, BTG reported its first profit in six years on the back of a sharp rise in revenues from licensing and patent sales.

BTG, which was floated in 1995, reported a pre-tax profit of £920,000 for the year to March 31, compared with a loss of £6m previously.

The result was bolstered by a one-off gain of £2.5m from the sale of investments. However, revenue soared by 63%, to £36.4m.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:  Ireland warns on inflation  Inter-Alliance wins sales staff  Britain in for net bank boom  Petrol crisis hits confidence
fields.body:
Ireland warns on inflation

Ireland's central bank yesterday issued its sternest warning to date about the country's still soaring inflation rate. The bank maintained that the rate of price rises - now at 6.2%, or three times the European Union average - would stay high next year, even in the event of wages and budget restraint.

The bank underscored its "grave concern" that inflation was gathering a momentum of its own. It said controls were unlikely to prevent the rate averaging 4% or more next year, and warned that the Irish economy was vulnerable to a recession.

Inter-Alliance wins sales staff

Inter-Alliance, the financial advisory group, has agreed to take on over half the UK sales force of Lincoln National, the US life insurer. The company, which will almost double in size as a result, is expected to employ 600 of the 1,000-strong team. The move may cost it up to £3m in restructuring costs, which includes training.

Britain in for net bank boom

Britain is in line for an internet banking boom, a survey said yesterday. It forecasts that by 2003, 25% of all banking transactions will be carried out over the internet, compared with about 4% today. However, the survey also showed that the internet's arrival would not necessarily mean the end of high street branches.

Petrol crisis hits confidence

Panic over petrol shortages sent consumer confidence tumbling to a 21-month low in September, according to a poll published today.

The monthly Consumer Confidence Barometre, published by market researchers GfK on behalf of the European commission, fell six points to minus 5, the lowest score since December 1998.

webTitle: Monti issues warning on price fixing

fields.headline: Monti issues warning on price fixing
fields.standfirst: EC tells mobile operators not to pass on cost of 3G licences to subscribers
fields.trailText: The European commission yesterday put mobile telephone companies on notice that they will not get away with any collective attempt to fix artificially high prices for the much-hyped next generation of handsets.
fields.body:
The European commission yesterday put mobile telephone companies on notice that they will not get away with any collective attempt to fix artificially high prices for the much-hyped next generation of handsets.

Mario Monti, the EC's powerful anti-monopoly chief, warned operators that Brussels would not allow companies to pass the "astronomical" costs of purchasing licences for so-called 3G services on to the public.

"We shall not consider the huge investments made in acquiring the licences as a justification for excessive consumer prices, unacceptable concentration levels or leniency on state aid," he told an audience in Barcelona.

In his clearest hint to date that he will be looking out for cartels and illegal price-fixing agreements when the new services are rolled out, Mr Monti vowed constant vigilance and said he would be taking a closer look at the sector.

The next generation networks, known as universal mobile telecommunications systems, represent a massive commercial opportunity for UK operators, which are desperate to recoup some of the £22.5bn they paid for the country's five licences.

Firms will be able to offer high-speed internet access and video phones. But the EC is aware that those such as BT Cellnet, TIW, One2One, Vodafone and Orange, which all won licences, may be unable to resist the temptation of charging their customers a heavy premium for such services.

It also knows that operators are bound to argue that they will set their prices at a level which the market can take. However, if all five firms come out with similar tariffs or consumer groups file a complaint to Brussels, the EC's suspicions are likely to be aroused and it may launch an investigation. Free and fair competition in the telecoms sector is one of Brussels' most frequently stated aims because it believes that low prices are essential if people are to be encouraged on to the internet.

Mr Monti pointed out yesterday that despite market liberalisation, all European ex-monopoly operators, such as BT, remain in a dominant position in the market.

"We are not yet in a situation of sustainable competition on the markets with a sufficient number of entrants acting independently from the incumbent operators. Competition is still weak in several communications markets," he said.

webTitle: Unilever sells Oxo to seal £13bn deal

fields.headline: Unilever sells Oxo to seal £13bn deal
fields.trailText: Anglo-Dutch food company Unilever can proceed with its £13bn purchase of America's Bestfoods but has had to agree to sell off well known brands such as Oxo and Batchelors to win regulatory approval, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Anglo-Dutch food company Unilever can proceed with its £13bn purchase of America's Bestfoods but has had to agree to sell off well known brands such as Oxo and Batchelors to win regulatory approval, it emerged yesterday.

The European commission said it had only agreed to sanction the deal - which will make Unilever one of the world's top two food companies - after extracting concessions worth around £350m a year in sales.

Unilever will have to divest itself of brands such as Lesieur, McDonnells, Oxo, Batchelors, Royco and Bla Band, but by buying Bestfoods it will be acquiring other household names such as Hellman's mayonnaise and Knorr stock cubes.

Unilever is known to have been keen to win EU approval at an early stage and has been negotiating with Brussels for some weeks to strike a deal.

The commission was concerned that the acquisition in its original form would have created anti-competition problems in nearly 150 different markets because of product overlaps in areas such as dry soups, jams, hot sauces and other foodstuffs.

However, Mario Monti, the EC's competition supremo, yesterday announced he was satisfied that Unilever had done enough to allay these fears.

"I believe Unilever's commitments will fully address the commission's concerns and will ensure that consumers will continue to benefit from unfettered competition in the markets affected," he said. "This merger will bring about a major restructuring of the European food industry."

Without concessions the deal would simply not have passed in Brussels, since Mr Monti was adamant that anti-competition problems would have arisen in Britain, Scandinavia and Ireland for a range of products.

Unilever will have to shed manufacturing facilities and sales staff associated with the products it has agreed to dispose of. Whoever buys the brands will not only inherit market share but also acquire access to the customer base.

webTitle: Prescott mobilises activists for election with call to 'walk tall'

fields.headline: Prescott mobilises activists for election with call to 'walk tall'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Labour ended its pre-election party conference last night on a high octane mixture of emotion, contrition and hard-nosed political projection on the strategy it will deploy to William Hague's Conservative opposition in the coming campaign.
fields.body:
Labour ended its pre-election party conference last night on a high octane mixture of emotion, contrition and hard-nosed political projection on the strategy it will deploy to William Hague's Conservative opposition in the coming campaign.

In a call to arms the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, whipped party activists into a frenzy over the Tory record in 18 years of power - and the prospect that "14 pint Billy Fizz" might snatch it back again next year. "Be confident, be proud, walk tall," said Mr Prescott as he itemised Labour's achievements and urged them to "get our message directly to the people".

Concern that voters are still switched off from ministerial claims has been evident all week, though only yesterday did Mr Prescott couple it with a none too veiled warning to senior colleagues that their semi-public feuding in books and newspapers is also damaging Labour's cause.

Taking the traditional swipe at the media, Mr Prescott said: "They have got their agenda and we haved got ours. And it's a different one. So it's the job of everyone in this party - from top to bottom - to get out our agenda and not to feed theirs with the tittle-tattle of years ago."

The emotional climax in Brighton was provided by Nelson Mandela's speech to the conference, a well crafted mixture of exhortation for global solidarity and thanks to Labour for its loyal support in the long struggle against apartheid. He repaid it with a generous endorsement of its abiding moral values which will have gladdened Mr Blair's election strategists.

With an overnight opinion poll suggesting that Mr Hague's opinion poll lead may prove brief - Labour is back on top by two points over the Tories according to Mori - Downing Street showed no inclination to relax its guard after a very bruising month.

The usual barn storming climax to the conference was distinguished by Mr Blair's energetic efforts to explain the week's events to voters who may have missed or misunderstood them. In a tour of the radio and TV studios he repeated the main themes of Tuesday's keynote speech while also spelling out what aides had said in the wake of Wednesday's defeat on the issue of pensions strategy.

The government will not back down in its refusal to re-link the basic state pension to average earnings because it wants to target most help to the poorest pensioners, he explained.

"We will do what we can when the Budget comes around... what we are trying to do is make sure we can do the things people want us to do in the country, but not at the risk of weakening the economy that's the strongest it's been for decades," said Mr Blair.

As for the looming threat of more fuel blockades if Gordon Brown does not cut petrol taxes within six weeks, Mr Blair said: "We have to take steps to make sure this type of blockade can't happen again.

"These protests have been happening all over the world. It is a problem, of course the price of petrol's a problem, but I don't think that people would thank me if we lurched into an emergency budget." He promised to campaign to tell voters why it "is a more complicated situation than sometimes it was presented".

In keeping with his new attempt to sound contrite over recent disasters like the dome he told BBC1: "You learn a lot from your first term in office. You learn that there are some of these issues that don't affect the fundamentals but are still important to people."

Mr Blair's claim to be listening to public discontents was directly challenged - as it has been all week - by up to 1,500 protesters from the Countryside Alliance who demonstrated again on the seafront outside the conference hall.

fields.headline: Yehuda Amichai
fields.standfirst: Irreverent poetic conscience of Israel
fields.trailText: All his life, Yehuda Amichai resisted the appellation, "national poet of Israel"; now that he has died of cancer, aged 76, he cannot escape that tag. His idioms have seeped into everyday Israeli parlance; bereaved mothers recite his poems at the graves of war-dead sons; operas and rock songs use his lyrics. Many hailed him as a seer, who understood his nation's innermost hopes and fears. Collections of his Hebrew verse repeatedly topped bestseller lists.
fields.body:
All his life, Yehuda Amichai resisted the appellation, "national poet of Israel"; now that he has died of cancer, aged 76, he cannot escape that tag. His idioms have seeped into everyday Israeli parlance; bereaved mothers recite his poems at the graves of war-dead sons; operas and rock songs use his lyrics. Many hailed him as a seer, who understood his nation's innermost hopes and fears. Collections of his Hebrew verse repeatedly topped bestseller lists.

Nor was his appeal limited to Israel. Universities from Oxford to Asyut, in Egypt, feted Amichai with honours. Many of his 16 anthologies, and several novels, plays, short stories and essays were rendered into 33 other languages. The Chinese translator Pu Hao called him "close and true, my brother in spirit".

Amichai dealt with weighty issues - God, death, loss, the fate of nations. Yet he did so with a comic eye for detail, elevating the commonplace to the plane of mythic metaphor. Sheets flapping in the midday Jerusalem breeze become flags of contending tribes; a girl opening a refrigerator door is illuminated in "the light of another world"; teenage conscripts sent to the battlefront peer out of coach windows like "faded postage stamps".

The poet's epiphany was equally surreal, as he told Jo Glanville, a former student from England. During the second world war, while serving with the British army in north Africa, a ferocious sandstorm overturned a mobile library. Amichai salvaged an anthology of Auden and Eliot verse, and was instantly smitten. Auden later became a friend and mentor. So did Ted Hughes, who wrote: "Amichai is the poet whose books I open most often. [They] make my life available to me afresh, uncover all kinds of riches and free me from my mental prisons."

Amichai's own childhood was marked by a more literal escape. Born in Würzburg, in Germany, to middle-class Jewish parents, he was 12 when his family fled the Nazis and settled in Palestine. They changed their surname from Pfeuffer to Amichai - it means "My people lives" in Hebrew. In 1946, Yehuda joined the zionist Palmach regiment, and fought in the Negev desert two years later.

A year before graduating from the Hebrew University, in literature and biblical studies, he published his first collection, Ahshav u-be'yamim ha'aherim (Now And In Other Days, 1955). It revolutionised Israeli poetry. Shunning the formalism of pre-state poets, Amichai introduced slang and prosaic modern terms to liberate Hebrew, "this weary language torn from its sleep in the Bible". His words elide seamlessly from biblical phraseology to 20th-century banality: "The man under his fig tree telephoned the man under his vine."

From early on, Amichai rejected his parents' orthodoxy. Yet the metre of holy texts still rang in his ears and echoed in his writing. Sometimes, he railed against a "toothless" or "merciless" God, who had deserted mankind. Mostly, though, his poems are affectionately irreverent. One likens the weekly Torah recital to reading God bedtime stories, much as Scheherezade did in 1001 Nights. Another has the Prophet Jacob climb his ladder to become a window-cleaner to celestial VIPs.

Amichai also respected medieval and early 20th-century Hebrew writers, like Leah Goldberg. He took her poems into battle with him in 1948 - just as soldiers later car ried his verse in their kits during the war of 1973 with Egypt.

During the days of the British mandate in Palestine, Amichai ferried Jewish refugees into Palestine, ran guns for the embryonic Israeli army, and later served in three wars. However, he was always a critical zionist. He opposed triumphalism and campaigned against Israel's Lebanese war. One poem undermines the David v Goliath motif. While David's comrades whoop with joy at his victory, the hero feels shame at carrying Goliath's gory severed head. In another deliberately shocking image, Amichai has Jews begging forgiveness outside an Arab shop on Yom Kippur.

He longed for peace - not so much heavenly bliss, just normality and human affection. His love poems, invariably dedicated to his second wife, Hanna Sokolov, reveal a fascination with the world of women. He once portrayed his mother as "an old windmill/ Two hands always raised to scream to the sky/ And two descending to make sandwiches".

Unlike secular intellectuals who preferred modern Tel Aviv, Amichai adored Jeru- salem, "short and crouched among its hills", its air "filled with prayers and dreams, hard to breathe". A teacher at the Hebrew University, he lived within sight of the ancient city walls, and, at times, felt oppressed by the weight of its history - "even the dead are granted the right to vote". Still, there was room for hope. He knew all Jerusalem's myriad alleyways, and felt sure peace would emerge from one of them.

Amichai always remained approachable and down-to-earth, even after winning the Israel prize for literature in 1982. He asserted the authenticity of the individual in a society where collectivism - both religious and secular - runs deep. "The entire task of an intellectual is to allow one the right to doubt," he wrote.

Not that he lacked detractors. Some criticised him for retreading earlier ideas. Yet Open Closed Open, written in 1997 and translated into Eng lish earlier this year, is being hailed as his masterpiece. From it comes what could well be his epitaph. "All my life I played chess with myself and others. Now [the pieces] are all jumbled together. The game is calm and has no end, no winners, no losers, the hollow rules clang in the wind. I listen. And I am quiet. In my life and in my death."

Amichai is survived by his wife and three children, Ron, David and Emanuella.

webTitle: Digital TV boost for Sugar's firm

fields.headline: Digital TV boost for Sugar's firm
fields.trailText: Amstrad, the consumer electronics group run by Sir Alan Sugar, yesterday reported an 85% increase in pre-tax profits largely on the back of BSkyB's drive into digital television.
fields.body:
Amstrad, the consumer electronics group run by Sir Alan Sugar, yesterday reported an 85% increase in pre-tax profits largely on the back of BSkyB's drive into digital television.

The business is one of five suppliers of the set-top boxes needed to receive the Sky Digital service which is on schedule to be in 5m homes before Christmas. BSkyB recently set new targets of 7m subscribers by the end of 2003.

Amstrad profits reached £15.4m with revenues 34% higher at £126m. "We anticipate supplying BSkyB for the foreseeable future and have orders in place for the current financial year," Sir Alan said. Shares in the company were 6.5p higher at 261.5p.

There were losses of £2.3m from its Amserve division, which is marketing the group's e-m@iler product - a combined phone and email unit which also allows users to send faxes or text messages to mobile telephones. Advertising sent to the phone's graphics display generates further revenues for Amstrad.

Advertisers already signed up include BSkyB, Direct Line and Britannia Music.

Amstrad has been testing the phones in a limited num ber of homes and hopes to have 120,000 installed shortly.

Dixons took a 20% share in the Amserve business in June for £3m in cash together with advertising, service support and distribution of the product in its 1,000 stores.

Amstrad is also working towards its debut in the mobile telephone market and begins large scale production of its first handset during the fourth quarter.

fields.headline: Basil Bernstein
fields.trailText: Basil Bernstein (Obituary, September 27) was a marvellously impish man. He could reasonably be claimed to be the most thoughtful and inventive social scientist to emerge from the London School of Economics since the second world war.
fields.body:
Basil Bernstein (Obituary, September 27) was a marvellously impish man. He could reasonably be claimed to be the most thoughtful and inventive social scientist to emerge from the London School of Economics since the second world war.

At that time, the LSE was still a home for outsiders, and Basil was one - born outside the metropolitan circle if, irrelevantly, near the Metropolitan line in the East End of London. If he went to grammar school, the experience completely failed to pigeonhole him, either as a Hogarthian scholarship boy or as the conventionally recognisable, successful literate or numerate, recruit to the professions.

Houghton Street and sociology gave him a fresh start, but his development was essentially one of auto- didaction, and that again, through neither conquest of the foreign tongues nor quantitative skill, but, instead, by a remorseful and anguished inner conversation about his own social experience.

Among the unconventional consequences was his writing. It is unconventional in style, in form and in content. The prose is extremely difficult because, being an autodidact and not a traditionally learned man, and being an innovator rather than one who seeks to maintain an established conversation, Basil developed his own, if I may borrow one of his own inventions, "elaborated code".

I should add immediately, however, that he was enough of a positivist to seek to make his theories publically available as empirically testable and refutable propositions. The form of publication which he adopted was no less deviant from established English academic custom, which decrees that published work should be completed and written in a language shared by readers of the Times Literary Supplement.

These rules were part of the imprint of a public, or grammar-school, education. Basil did not so much flout as ignore them. He never hesitated to write down an incomplete theoretical argument, nor to publish a later version which was clearer or more developed. The underlying assumption always was that the journey mattered more than the destination.

Put in its most abstract form Basil Bernstein's achievement was to make a serious attempt at surmounting the unending post-Hegelian debate on the relation between man's social consciousness and his material existence. It is true and important that, because of his work, the modern definition of the sociology of education is firmly centred on the analysis of pedagogical processes.
fields.bodyText: Basil Bernstein (Obituary, September 27) was a marvellously impish man. He could reasonably be claimed to be the most thoughtful and inventive social scientist to emerge from the London School of Economics since the second world war. At that time, the LSE was still a home for outsiders, and Basil was one - born outside the metropolitan circle if, irrelevantly, near the Metropolitan line in the East End of London. If he went to grammar school, the experience completely failed to pigeonhole him, either as a Hogarthian scholarship boy or as the conventionally recognisable, successful literate or numerate, recruit to the professions. Houghton Street and sociology gave him a fresh start, but his development was essentially one of auto- didaction, and that again, through neither conquest of the foreign tongues nor quantitative skill, but, instead, by a remorseful and anguished inner conversation about his own social experience. Among the unconventional consequences was his writing. It is unconventional in style, in form and in content. The prose is extremely difficult because, being an autodidact and not a traditionally learned man, and being an innovator rather than one who seeks to maintain an established conversation, Basil developed his own, if I may borrow one of his own inventions, "elaborated code". I should add immediately, however, that he was enough of a positivist to seek to make his theories publically available as empirically testable and refutable propositions. fields.headline: Geoffrey Sheridan
fields.standfirst: Journalist who fought for press freedom and against racism
fields.trailText: The career of the journalist Geoffrey Sheridan, who has died of cancer aged 55, encompassed much of the story of the British far left - and radical, non-aligned socialism - since the 1960s.
fields.body:
The career of the journalist Geoffrey Sheridan, who has died of cancer aged 55, encompassed much of the story of the British far left - and radical, non-aligned socialism - since the 1960s.

Writing for the tabloids, and the Guardian, in the early 1970s, he covered everything from Native Americans on Skid Row to the educational controversy at William Tyndale school, in Islington. He could write for a popular audience with compassion and wit, as he proved in a Sun story about the conditions of women night cleaners, when he described a night spent as a rather inept lavatory cleaner.

Concerned about women's rights issues, he became a regular contributor to the Guardian women's page. And it was Geoffrey who, in 1977, broke the story about the then British Leyland boss, Sir Richard Dobson, taped making racist remarks during an after-dinner speech.

Geoffrey was a founder member of the Campaign for Press and Broadcasting Freedom (CPBF) and the Campaign Against Racism in the Media (CARM). He was an activist in the National Union of Journalists, and, from the late 1960s until its dissolution, a member of the Trotskyist International Marxist Group (IMG).

The son of a tailor, and Communist party member, Geoffrey grew up in Stamford Hill, north London. From 1955 to 1962, he attended Hackney Downs school, where he proved himself an exceptionally bright student. He showed an early interest in journalism, although his enthusiasm was initially driven more by enterprise than idealism. He scanned the locals, and early editions of the London evening papers, for stories he could sell to their rivals. Throughout his life, he united his journalistic nous with business flair.

Geoffrey was part of that postwar, post-austerity generation of state-educated, working-class children who burrowed their way into higher education; in his case to Oxford University. From 1962 to 1965, he read politics, philosophy and economics at Balliol College, and launched into journalism via the university student newspaper. In the post-Hungary, post-Suez climate of the times, the British new left - which rejected orthodox communism - was forming, and Geoffrey allied himself with a group of non-aligned leftwingers, whose radical socialist philosophy influenced the rest of his life.

After graduation, he freelanced and became active in the London left. At the end of the decade, he joined the IMG. By 1977, he was working fulltime for the group's weekly paper, Socialist Challenge. In the early 1980s, after the CPBF was formed, he edited its journal, Free Press. Soon afterwards, he helped to form CARM, and wrote its pamphlet, It Ain't Half Racist, Mum.

By then, Geoffrey was in the Labour party. In 1981, he joined the editorial board of the party's monthly, New Socialist, as business manager. The magazine - if not the party - was then flourishing as a forum for debate, and his business skill kept it on a sound economic footing.

From 1987 until his death, he worked in business planning for Hackney council. He acquired a master's degree in business administration and was based in the central strategy and regeneration unit.

Increasingly, his later writing reflected his curiosity about people and their stories. He faced his early death with great courage, fascinated by the hospital system and the people around him. Patients, he proposed, should record their own ideas and concerns for their hospital clinical notes.

He leaves a son, Sam Masters, and his partner, the GP Dr Jackie Maxmin.

 Geoffrey Michael Sheridan, journalist, born September 25 1944; died September 23 2000

fields.headline: Cliff Bruner
fields.standfirst: Violinist and bandleader who made Texas swing
fields.trailText: Of the men who created western swing, Texas's vivacious hillbilly jazz, few are remembered with as much respect and affection as the fiddler and bandleader Cliff Bruner, who has died of cancer aged 85.
fields.body:
Of the men who created western swing, Texas's vivacious hillbilly jazz, few are remembered with as much respect and affection as the fiddler and bandleader Cliff Bruner, who has died of cancer aged 85.

Names were made fast in the hothouse atmosphere of western swing's flowering in the 1930s, and Bruner was just 20 when he was hired by the singer Milton Brown for his Musical Brownies, the most popular band in Texas. A child of a poor, south Texas family, he had become an itinerant musician in his teens, carrying his fiddle in a flour sack, picking cotton by day and playing for cotton-pickers by night.

In the Brownies, he was exposed not only to their charismatic leader but to the extraordinary talent of Bob Dunn, who pioneered swing playing on the new, amplified steel guitars. When the band broke up after Brown died in a car crash in 1936, several of its members formed their own groups.

Bruner's Texas Wanderers, which would be one of the most durable, moved into the musically virgin territory of south-east Texas, bounded by the cities of Orange, Port Arthur and Beaumont, where they broadcast over KFDM and, in 1937, secured a recording contract with Decca.

Western swing's creators were almost all young men, talented but often volatile, and bands constantly broke up and re-formed. The new lineup of the Texas Wanderers that assembled at the Gunter hotel, San Antonio, for a recording session in September 1938, with Bob Dunn, the electric mandolinist Leo Raley and the lazy-voiced blues-singer and pianist "Moon" Mullican, was one of the genre's most remarkable groups.

"We want nothing but hot numbers," the record com pany had stipulated, and Bruner's men responded with the startling stringband jazz of When You're Smiling, Kangaroo Blues and I'll Keep On Loving You.

The band owed much of its oomph to Bruner. Just how he acquired his swing approach to old-time fiddle tunes and sedate Tin Pan Alley songs remains uncertain. Probably, like his contemporaries JR Chatwell, Dickie Jones and Buddy Ray - all of whom played with him at one time or another - he listened attentively to jazz violinists such as Joe Venuti and Stuff Smith.

Within a few years, Bruner and his fellow fiddlers established their jazz-inflected playing as a defining sound of western swing, and the music played under that banner today - by bands like Asleep At The Wheel or the Time-Warp Top Hands - faithfully preserves that character.

It is not only rock 'n' roll that can trace a line back in Bruner's direction. Small-group western swing quickly elided into the confessional, but stoical, music that would be called honkytonk, a process mirrored in hits like the Floyd Tillman composition, It Makes No Difference Now, and Ted Daffan's Truck Driver's Blues, both of which Bruner introduced on record. Their sales guaranteed him the attention of record companies through the 1940s, a period in which he moved restlessly around Texas.

In 1950, Bruner's wife, Ruth, died from tuberculosis, and, for the sake of his two young daughters, he gave up professional music for the safety of the insurance business.

In the early 1970s, I included some of his old recordings on an album, Beer Parlor Jive, which found its way to Houston and into his hands. Bruner wrote to say that he had enjoyed hearing himself again and added, "I still play my fiddle. We are a group of old pros that have a fine country western band. We play every Friday and Saturday nights."

After retirement in 1977, he recorded a few albums, one with the distinguished swing fiddler and Nashville session player Johnny Gimble, an admirer since the 1940s.

A succession of researchers - including myself, Cary Ginell and Kevin Coffey - visited Bruner to raid his memories and his photo collection, onslaughts that he and his third wife, Ruth, met with great hospitality. In 1977, Coffey produced an impeccable five-CD boxed set of Bruner's vintage work, which, coupled with Ginell's similar commemoration of Milton Brown, containing Bruner's first recordings, permanently locates this imaginative and exciting musician in the centre of an exciting and imaginative music.

He is survived by Ruth, six daughters and three generations of grandchildren.

fields.headline: Mandela thanks Labour faithful
fields.standfirst:
Conference star turn: delegates in tears as veteran of apartheid struggle praises party's solidarity
Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela received a rapturous reception at the Labour party conference yesterday when he issued a call to the world's affluent people to assume the role of "keepers" of the poor.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela received a rapturous reception at the Labour party conference yesterday when he issued a call to the world's affluent people to assume the role of "keepers" of the poor.

After receiving a seven-minute standing ovation before he had even spoken, the former South African president used his appearance to warn that "concern for the common good" was in danger of being lost in the age of the internet. In language which differed sharply from New Labour's attachment to globalisation, Mr Mandela warned of the dangers posed by the "global village.

"The danger is that globalisation can come to mean only the free flow of goods and finance, the open access to markets, the breaking down of barriers to trade and commerce," Mr Mandela said. "The concern for the common good is in danger of being lost in the current understanding of a global world."

Alluding to the Bible, Mr Mandela said that the shrinking of the globe had "made it even more incumbent upon us to become once more the keepers of our brothers and sisters wherever in the world."

The former president, who went out of his way to reassure big business after the collapse of apartheid, qualified his remarks by saying that globalisation could not be avoided. To laughter, he said: "Those who are saying they are not going to prepare for this phenomenon, are like saying, 'I don't recognise winter, therefore I'm not going to buy clothing for winter'."

Labour delegates cried as Mr Mandela, 82, made his first appearance at a British party conference.

His appearance followed a moving video of the anti-apartheid struggle which reminded delegates of how every Labour leader had opposed racism in South Africa.

Mr Mandela opened his speech by praising the Labour party for opposing apartheid, pointedly making no mention of the Tories, some of whose members were active supporters of the apartheid regime. "Apartheid was experienced as such a basic onslaught against human dignity that it demeaned all of us," he said.

To cheers, Mr Mandela said that international support was a key factor which allowed democracy to win through in South Africa.

"Britain was in so many respects the second headquarters of our movement in exile," Mr Mandela said. "Your solidarity helped to make those years of exile bearable and contributed to them not turning out to be wasted years."

The conference listened in silence as the former South African president gave a moving account of the fight against poverty in South Africa, speaking in bleak terms of how Aids is devastating his country. "I told prime minister Tony today that apart from poverty we face a crisis of a dimension which I cannot support in words," he said.

In his final passage, Mr Mandela said that Labour included "good men and women" whose devotion to others allowed him to sleep a contented man.

"As I look at you today I can see men and women who are worthy candidates for immortality," he said.

"They will be like Aristotle or Plato. We will inter them into the earth but they will live for eternity."

webTitle: New fund to focus on small techs

fields.headline: New fund to focus on small techs
fields.trailText: Smaller technology companies will be the target of a £20m venture capital trust being launched next month.
fields.body:
Smaller technology companies will be the target of a £20m venture capital trust being launched next month.

Yorkshire Fund Managers is raising the money which it will channel into innovative new companies. Phil Cammerman, the managing director, said the emphasis would be on providing "early stage finance" for core technology companies.

Those most likely to receive a boost are in the electronics, software, telecoms and health-care sectors.

"We are looking for core technology companies," said Mr Cammerman. "We get into a company at a price which makes sense and means the potential for upside is very, very big.

"We also provide companies with help in getting the necessary experience in areas such as marketing to make sure our investments work."

The prospectus will be issued at the beginning of November and investors can put in a minimum of £3,000.

The fund is being organised in partnership with the Cambridge-based Generics Group, which provides technology advice and assists in monitoring investments.

This British Smaller Technology Companies VCT 2 is the second fund dedicated to smaller technology firms which has been launched by Yorkshire Fund Managers.

The first, started in May 1999, raised just under £14m and has already helped fund companies across Britain.

fields.headline: Freeserve losses double to £18m
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Losses at, Britain's biggest internet service provider, doubled to £17.81m in the first quarter sending its already battered shares spinning down further.
fields.body:
Losses at Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, doubled to £17.81m in the first quarter sending its already battered shares spinning down further.

But company executives dismissed the extra losses as partly the result of one-off marketing spend, and said they were still on target to meet their growth goals.

Turnover at Freeserve rose fourfold to hit £14.6m over the 16 weeks to August 19 compared with a 12 week period the year before.

Freeserve, 80% owned by Dixons, Europe's biggest electrical retailer, said growing sales demonstrated the strength of the business as an independent company.

The company saw its shares rise to 900p in the summer after it revealed it was in talks with Germany's T-Online about a possible merger.

Since discussions broke down the shares have tumbled and last night they ended down a further 7p at 235p as the company confirmed no further talks of any kind were under way.

Freeserve said it had been bringing in just under 10,000 new internet accounts ever week since the first quarter end and now had 250,000 unmetered customers.

Neil Backhouse, the finance director, said that the failure of rivals to offer unmetered access - as much internet time as users want for a flat fee including call charges - had given Freeserve a huge advantage and driven up its total user base to over 2m accounts. Freeserve itself was still subsidising unmetered access.

He said it was enhancing the portal side of the Freeserve business, only matched in Britain by Yahoo!, by encour aging users to stay online longer than they had in the past.

Unmetered access was also generating higher e-commerce and advertising revenue. "We are able to charge £70 per thousand pages for personalised pages on the women's portal say, compared to figures in the teens for the home page," said Mr Backhouse.

Freeserve was forced to admit that there was congestion on its unmetered access service due to heavy demand, but said that this would be eradicated by a forthcoming 25% increase in network capacity.

The company has been criticised by analysts who believe it should concentrate more on content to compete harder with Yahoo! and others rather than worrying about access.

Mr Backhouse said the two aspects of the business served each other. The 186m page impressions Freeserve was obtaining on its portal, two-and-a-half times more than last year, suggested users were happy with the content which was constantly being upgraded.

The company launched a new internet television portal which will be featured on a range of new Bush internet television sets and is also producing its own broadband internet operation.

In the first quarter Freeserve introduced its own brand of Wap (wireless application protocol) phone which is already the fastest selling such phone in Dixons stores.

Some analysts believe that the share price will remain depressed unless another bidder comes along.

France's Wanadoo internet service is apparently one European rival which could be interested in breaking into the British market.

webTitle: Nissan says UK may lose new Micra

fields.headline: Nissan says UK may lose new Micra
fields.standfirst: Car company president insists exchange rate is key issue for Sunderland plant's future
fields.trailText: Nissan president Carlos Ghosn said yesterday that the strength of the pound against the euro had had a staggering effect on the car company's latest sales figures and could jeopardise plans to build the new Micra model at its Sunderland plant.
fields.body:
Nissan president Carlos Ghosn said yesterday that the strength of the pound against the euro had had a staggering effect on the car company's latest sales figures and could jeopardise plans to build the new Micra model at its Sunderland plant.

He said European commission clearance of a proposed £40m British government grant was no guarantee that the car, scheduled to roll off production lines in 2003, would be built in Britain.

Mr Ghosn said that Nissan would need to be convinced about the stability of the exchange rate if it was to opt for Sunderland ahead of plants in France and Spain. "Sunderland losing the Micra is not my preferred solution but I cannot go against economics," he said.

His comments came as British car parts suppliers were facing bad news. Vauxhall chief Nick Reilly said yesterday that the new Vectra - expected to come into production in 2002 - will have between 20 and 25% fewer British components than the present model. He said Britain should sign up for the euro, adding: "It is clearly a positive for the country from the economic point of view to join the euro as soon as we are ready," he said.

Johnson Controls in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, which makes car seat covers, announced that it was to close with the loss of 550 jobs. It blamed a downturn in demand and pressure from car makers for suppliers to cut prices.

Nissan hinted things could get even worse. In a stark warning for the longer term outlook for the future of its Wearside plant, Mr Ghosn said the logic which determined the Micra decision "would come back" when it came to deciding on model renewals.

Nissan is seeking to cut costs in Britain by 30% - including expanding capacity from 330,000 to 500,000 cars a year and cutting component costs - and is awaiting EC approval for £40m of regional grant aid.

Mr Ghosn, brought in to Nissan from Renault when the French group acquired just over a third of the shares, said the cost cuts and grant aid would be helpful, but the sterling-euro exchange rate was the main issue.

"We have to have stability of the exchange rate between the euro and the pound, that is the issue for us."

If the EC decision does not arrive before Nissan's self-imposed deadline the company will press ahead without waiting for Brussels.

The decision about where to build the new Micra - which company sources suggest would safeguard up to 1,300 jobs - will be taken in December or January.

It would be better if the sterling rate were favourable, but what mattered was stability. "If you have a strong currency but at a stable rate you can take action, make plans _ but if you have a moving target all the time there is nothing you can do, there is not even the motivation."

The decision would depend on "the willingness of the UK to safeguard itself as a manufacturing base", noting that while Sunderland was the most productive car plant in Europe it was not the most cost efficient.

Ford has threatened to reconsider a huge investment at its biggest British plant if there is industrial action over the decision to stop building Fiesta cars from 2002.

Jac Nasser, Ford's president, is understood to have made it clear at the Paris Motor Show, that the investment planned for the engine plant at Dagenham in Essex could be reconsidered if there is a strike.

webTitle: Jury backs MS woman on cannabis

fields.headline: Jury backs MS woman on cannabis
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A woman with multiple sclerosis was yesterday cleared of a criminal charge of possessing cannabis, after telling a court that she needed it to relieve the symptoms of the muscle wasting disease.
fields.body:
A woman with multiple sclerosis was yesterday cleared of a criminal charge of possessing cannabis, after telling a court that she needed it to relieve the symptoms of the muscle wasting disease.

The public gallery cheered as Lezley Gibson, 36, was found not guilty by a jury of seven women and five men at Carlisle crown court. She had denied one charge of possessing eight grams of the class B drug, worth £40, on the grounds that she needed it for medical reasons.

Outside court, flanked by her husband, Mark, Mrs Gibson said she would continue smoking cannabis and called for a change in the law: "There are hundreds of people like me out there. No one in my position should have to be dragged through the courts like this, but I am glad it is all over. I feel brilliant." She intended to throw a party to celebrate.

During the four day trial the jury heard that police raided her home in Alston, Cumbria, in August of last year and found cannabis.

She told the court she began smoking 12 years ago, three years after being diagnosed with MS at 21. She had tried other medications and treatments, but nothing made her feel as well as cannabis. She smoked up to five joints a day bought from dealers, because it enabled her to have a more normal life: "I would use paint stripper if I thought it would make me well."

The prosecution did not accept Mrs Gibson had the defence of necessity, because she did not need to smoke cannabis to avoid death or serious injury from her condition.

fields.headline: Great Reconciler does party proud
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Labour conference ended with speeches from John Prescott and Nelson Mandela. What a fantastic double bill, like having Les Dawson and Paul Robeson in the same show. It would be disgracefully cynical for me to suggest that Labour had persuaded the world's most popular politician to cover up their problems, so I won't. But I confess the thought did worm into my head.
fields.body:
The Labour conference ended with speeches from John Prescott and Nelson Mandela. What a fantastic double bill, like having Les Dawson and Paul Robeson in the same show. It would be disgracefully cynical for me to suggest that Labour had persuaded the world's most popular politician to cover up their problems, so I won't. But I confess the thought did worm into my head.

Mr Prescott said he was proud to be there as a warm-up man. So to prepare the way for the Great Reconciler we had the Great Hater. Golly, the deputy PM does good loathing. Farmers were jeered. "Liam Fox! You know what I think about fox hunting, but I'll make an exception.

"Go back to your constituencies and prepare to splatter the Tories!" he yelled. Nye Bevan called them vermin, but he never demanded a programme of mass splattering.

One weapon Labour plans to use against the Conservatives is a beer mat. "Tory froth. I drank 14 pints a day", it says. Mr Prescott waved the mat in the air. In the past parties had manifestos. In 1997 they brought in pledge cards. Now we have beer mats, even the sound-bite reduced to the sound-sip. "Our beer mat is unequivocal: 'Australians wouldn't give a XXXX for... sorry, comrades, wrong side."

Then another dementedly cheered reference to 18 years of Tory rule: "We shall never ever forget and we shall never ever forgive."

This would not be thought on message by President Mandela's spin doctors for whom, I seem to recall, forgiveness was a manifesto pledge.

Still, before he was brought on stage the party had to crank up the frenzy. We saw a video in which a man sang He Ain't Heavy, He's My Brother while apparently being gnawed by ferrets, and which implied that it was the Labour party which had won South Africa's freedom. Then a choir of charming schoolchildren arrived on stage, with a guitarist, and a rock singer called Gabrielle. Some of us hoped she would start a rousing chorus of Things Have Really Gone Pear-Shaped, but she didn't. The stage was packed, nonentities and union hacks from the national executive making up the numbers like villagers in a panto.

Mr Prescott started again. "This man who has an irreducible core inside him," referring to the bizarre phrase coined on Tuesday by Tony Blair. "He does us a great honour by coming here, but he has done us a greater honour by becoming an honorary member of the Labour Party, and so qualifies for a free beer mat." (All right, he didn't say the last bit.)

Then suddenly on stage the man himself appeared. His corps was apparently very reducible because by now it consisted only of T. Blair, who was smiling that huge fixed smile which Mr Mandela appears to inspire in all who get close to him. The cheering was ecstatic. Some people even waved Union Jacks. No one has seen one of them at a Labour conference since Keir Hardie's day.

Mr Mandela's speech was not, to be frank, a rabble rouser. It was a serious, anxious look at globalisation and world poverty. This was received politely but not noisily. Perhaps he was working as a cool down man for John Prescott.

But he did Labour proud, implying that, yes, the party really had made a huge contribution to ending apartheid.

And finally he seemed to go over the top on their behalf. "As I look around me now I see men and women who are worthy candidates for immortality." Steady on, I thought, but he wasn't finished. "Their names will live on for eternity. That is how I conceive the Labour party."

I looked at the prime minister on the TV monitor. He was smiling, seraphic, utterly at peace. He looked, and I can only put it this way, immortal.

fields.headline: PlayStation 2 delay hits Eidos
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Eidos, the computer games maker behind the Tomb Raider series, suffered another blow yesterday when Sony admitted to a shortfall of its long-awaited PlayStation 2.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games maker behind the Tomb Raider series, suffered another blow yesterday when Sony admitted to a shortfall of its long-awaited PlayStation 2.

The announcement caused shares in Eidos to fall more than 6% to 348.5p, continuing a wretched 12 months for the company. The stock has fallen from a peak of £12.73 after two profit warnings earlier this year caused by delays in getting its own product to market.

Sony said it would ship only half as many PlayStation 2 consoles to the US for its October launch as it had initially planned. In the first weekend 500,000 of the consoles will be available. The British launch is expected in November.

The arrival of PlayStation 2 has been much anticipated by games manufacturers who have complained of a drop off in sales while players wait for the new model to arrive in the shops. Eidos sales in the US were 19% lower last year.

A spokesman for Eidos said PlayStation 2 was expected to make its biggest impact over Christmas 2001 and played down the effect of the shortfall. Sony plans to stagger additional shipments of the games console of 100,000 units a week and said it still hoped to meet its targets of 1.3m units in the US by Christmas and 3m by the end of March.

The Japanese electronics firm said it was one month behind schedule because of component shortages.

Software development has also been slower than Sony had anticipated. There will be 26 games available at launch instead of the 50 promised - though games for the first version of the console will be compatible with the new model. Shares in Sony were also hit yesterday and slumped by 9% in early trading on Wall Street.

The collapse of the Eidos share price earlier this year lead to a takeover approach, understood to be from French rival Infogrames.

Eidos said in June that talks had opened with a potential buyer of the business and issued a separate statement last month which said discussions were still ongoing.

Eidos is preparing for the launch of the fifth instalment in its Tomb Raider series featuring the iconic character Lara Croft.

fields.headline: Greek mariners plagued with disaster
fields.trailText: The loss of the Express Samina did not entirely surprise those familiar with the Greek shipping industry.
fields.body:
The loss of the Express Samina did not entirely surprise those familiar with the Greek shipping industry.

Since the Heraklion sank with the loss of 217 lives in 1966, there has been a stream of similar ferry casualties, such as the Eleana, when 25 died, or the Chryssi Avgi, which sank with 18 fatalities.

Only last year 14 Kurdish refugees perished in a fire on board the Superfast III ferry, leaving many to conclude that safety in Greece is not taken as seriously as in other countries, especially during the hectic summer season.

There are no flamboyant figures such as Aristotle Onassis or Stavros Niarchos anymore, but the modern executives still wield enormous political power in a country where shipping challenges tourism as the top foreign money spinner.

That feeling was strengthened when the government fought a successful campaign to exempt local shipowners from tighter international safety regulations after the sinking of the MS Estonia in the Baltic Sea in 1994.

This allowed vessels that were more than 27 years old - such as the 34-year-old Express Samina - to operate without upgraded safety standards until their enforced retirement at the age 35.

Greek shipowner representatives in the UK insisted last night that only competitors would argue that the reputation of the Hellenic fleet was poor. They said that the Greek regulations, which all ferries must comply with, were among the safest.

But it is hard to shrug off the welter of unsavoury stories that has dogged the Greek shipping industry for the past 10 years. The International Transport Workers' Federation, which represents seafarers globally, says Greek shipowners are over-represented in its list of substandard ship operators. Last year, the International Underwriting Association of London, which represents the insurance industry, produced statistics showing that Greek shipowners controlled half of the bulk carrier vessels that had become total losses.

Irrespective of the Greek flag's safety record, most Greek shipowners do not operate their vessels under those colours, choosing instead to register under "flags of convenience" such as Malta and Cyprus, which have historically poor records.

Traditionally, Greek owners have been buyers and sellers of old tonnage, although they have surprised everyone recently by ordering new ships. This is partly due to the tightening noose of international regulation; pressure on tanker owners has increased since the sinking last November of the Erika off the coast of France.

The Erika was owned by Italians, but its demise triggered a flurry of action from European regulators keen to phase out older ships and prevent future pollution cases.

The Greek shipping industry has been at the forefront of attempts to delay the introduction of tougher tanker rules, such as the early phasing out of single-hulled tankers. It has also been tarnished by a series of legal cases such as one involving Greek owner Costas Comninos, whose insurers refused to pay a claim on his Ikarian Reefer ship when it sank. The insurers won the case in London's court of appeal after suggestions that the crew had scuttled the ship.

Against this tide of bad publicity, has been a determined effort to improve the standing ofthe industry, helped by a new generation of often US-educated young Greeks.

They have introduced more operating and financial transparency into their businesses, albeit partly to tap the foreign capital markets.

fields.headline: Wrestling with a question of identity
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Pro-euro arguments in this referendum - Denmark's sixth on a European issue since joining the EEC in 1972 - have been couched largely in economic terms. Yet in some ways it is more about politics and national identity.
fields.body:
Trudging or bicycling to polling stations under grey skies and a light drizzle, Danes turned out en masse yesterday to vote on whether to join Europe's single currency. But once again many seemed to be thinking about a far wider question.

After a six-month campaign, the big day dawned with a sense of inevitable anticlimax, though the Politiken daily underlined the gravity of the choice by giving over its front page to a picture of August Rodin's statue, the Thinker.

Pro-euro arguments in this referendum - Denmark's sixth on a European issue since joining the EEC in 1972 - have been couched largely in economic terms. Yet in some ways it is more about politics and national identity.

Campaigners for a No vote have rarely spoken of the financial implications of joining euroland, because all acknowledge that since the krone is already pegged to the euro, taking the plunge will make little practical difference.

Supporters, led by the Social Democratic prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, argued that staying out of the club would mean higher interest rates and prices, job losses, speculative attacks on the krone and a broader loss of influence.

In a close-run campaign that has displayed a worrying split between elites and ordinary people, both sides used scare tactics, though there was no hard evidence for anti-euro warnings about the future of Danish state pensions.

Debates generated more heat than light on the question of national identity, though supporters argued that it should not be affected.

fields.headline: Russia may offer sanctuary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic's key foreign ally, Russia, has withdrawn its support for the Serbian leader, the French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, said yesterday after meeting the Russian president.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic's key foreign ally, Russia, has withdrawn its support for the Serbian leader, the French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, said yesterday after meeting the Russian president.

Meanwhile, in Moscow and Belgrade rumours spread that Mr Milosevic was seeking a safe haven in Russia.

In Brussels, a senior foreign policy official suggested that the Yugoslav leader's flight to Russia had come up in discussions between Mr Védrine and the Russians yesterday and also in Moscow on Monday, when the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, met President Vladimir Putin.

"Milosevic and his family are seeking contact with the Russians and hoping to move to Moscow," the official said. "This could be one of the ways out ... He is seeking a way out."

Mr Milosevic's half-brother, Borislav, is the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow. Belgrade newspapers reported on Wednesday that the Serb leader's family was already in Russia, while a Moscow newspaper yesterday published what it claimed was a flight plan arranged by Borislav Milosevic to take his brother and his family to Kazakhstan next Monday.

Russian officials and Mr Védrine denied that the issue had come up. The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, said Moscow would not exert any pressure on Belgrade, but insisted that "legitimate" election results should decide Serbia's fate, while Konstantin Kosachev, the MP who led a team of Russian monitors during the Yugoslav poll, warned that the opposition's failure to prove its ballot rigging claims, coupled with a runoff boycott, could prove incendiary since there was a "risk of civil war".

In Brussels, the EU official said that any Russian-western plan to spirit Mr Milosevic out of the country belonged in the realm of rumour. "But Védrine could be discussing this matter in Moscow today ... That would not be out of line with the Putin-Schröder talks."

Yesterday's EU statement recognising Vojislav Kostunica as the president-elect and opposing a runoff on October 8 was preceded by Mr Kostunica having lunch in Belgrade with EU diplomats.

"But Védrine could be discussing this matter in Moscow today ... That would not be out of line with the Putin-Schröder talks." Yesterday's EU statement recognising Vojislav Kostunica as the president-elect and opposing a runoff on October 8 was preceded by Mr Kostunica having lunch in Belgrade with EU diplomats.

fields.headline: Setback for Cardiff cultural centre
fields.trailText: Ambitious plans to create a world class cultural centre for Wales in the heart of Cardiff's regenerated docklands area suffered another setback yesterday after the owners of the land on which it is due to be built announced they had decided to put the site back onto the open market.
fields.body:
Ambitious plans to create a world class cultural centre for Wales in the heart of Cardiff's regenerated docklands area suffered another setback yesterday after the owners of the land on which it is due to be built announced they had decided to put the site back onto the open market.

The Wales Millennium Centre directors are locked in delicate negotiations with the national assembly for Wales, which is seeking to place a £75m cap on the project. It is understood that the WMC did not feel able to sign off the land deal while the sensitive cost review was still taking place.

The site's owners, Grosvenor Waterside, the property development arm of Associated British Ports, said they had lost patience with the WMC for its continued delay in completing the purchase. The company first set the site aside for a cultural centre about 10 years ago.

The prime site is thought to be worth around £5m at current market prices - about double the preferential price at which it is believed to have been offered to the WMC.

A spokesman for the WMC said the latest setback was a disappointment. But it was not one that would affect the eventual outcome. He said it was "unthinkable" that anything other than the WMC would be built on the earmarked site.

Alun Michael, the MP for Cardiff South and Penarth, said the developers should remember they had benefited enormously from the massive public investment in Cardiff Bay. He said the company should not be putting the land on the market when they knew "full well" that efforts were being made to restructure the WMC proposals.

fields.headline: Bills logjam delays new parliament
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The government is to postpone the date of the Queen's speech to the end of November to give controversial measures such as the freedom of information and the right to roam bills a chance to reach the statute book.
fields.body:
The government is to postpone the date of the Queen's speech to the end of November to give controversial measures such as the freedom of information and the right to roam bills a chance to reach the statute book.

The failure to agree a date for the state opening of parliament is believed to have caused some anxiety at Buckingham Palace as the Queen has not been able to finalise her diary of engagements until it is settled.

It is believed that a meeting of the government's business managers, in the House of Lords yesterday, agreed to put back the state opening of parliament rather than be forced to ditch any one of the promised bills because of a shortage of parliamentary time.

The Queen's speech will contain the last batch of bills that Labour will put forward before the general election, which is expected next May.

The decision to postpone the Queen's speech by at least two weeks will be greeted with huge relief, particularly by freedom of information campaigners who had feared that ministers' commitment to the bill would weaken in the face of problems in the House of Lords during the current overspill session.

Ministers yesterday published the list of clauses and schedules for the committee stage of the freedom of information bill, which is expected to start in the middle of October. "The government has been doing serious work on this bill. It is quite clear it is still strongly backed. It has not been dropped," said a House of Lords source.

MPs are not due to return to Westminster until October 23 when they will elect a new speaker, but peers went back on Wednesday to start work on the outstanding number of bills that Labour hopes to get onto the statute book in this 'overspill session' before the next Queen's speech.

Peers are already planning an all night sitting to deal with the countryside bill, which protects sites of scientific interest as well as introducing the right to roam.

The Home Office confirmed yesterday that peers will have to work their way through swaths of amendments to the freedom of information bill before it has a chance to reach the statute book.

The overspill session in the Lords will also see battles over the transport bill, which introduces congestion charges and privatises the national air traffic control system.

fields.headline: Two accused of killing 58 immigrants
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Two Dutch nationals have been charged with the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a refrigerated lorry at Dover in June.
fields.body:
Two Dutch nationals have been charged with the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a refrigerated lorry at Dover in June.

The men, 28 and 56, appeared yesterday in a Rotterdam court, and were also charged with three other men of smuggling aliens, being members of a criminal organisation and counterfeiting.

The bodies of 54 men and four women were found in the lorry by customs officers checking freight vehicles leaving a ferry from Zeebrugge. At an inquest it was said the victims had suffocated after an air vent on the lorry was closed. The dead were found behind palettes of tomatoes, the lorry's notional cargo. Two men who survived the ordeal have been in safe accommodation since.

Last week Folkestone magistrates remanded the Dutch driver of the lorry, Perry Wacker, 32, in custody on 58 counts of manslaughter. Two others, Ying Gou, a translator, and You Yi, a chef, of South Woodford, East London, are charged with conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry.

webTitle: 'We don't want another round. We have won'

fields.headline: 'We don't want another round. We have won'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Mija Lazarovic was planning to kill a pig if Vojislav Kostunica was declared president in Serbia this week. One neighbour put up the money for 1,000 bottles of beer while another was planning to kill a bull.
fields.body:
Mija Lazarovic was planning to kill a pig if Vojislav Kostunica was declared president in Serbia this week. One neighbour put up the money for 1,000 bottles of beer while another was planning to kill a bull.

Now, despite Mr Kostunica's widely recognised victory over Slobodan Milosevic, the president has insisted he wants a second bout and Mija's pig has been given a little more time.

In the village of Majmic, in the Serbian heartland, 27 of the 30 houses voted for Mr Kostunica. Mija, 60, had tried to campaign for a block vote for the opposition candidate but failed. "Mele and Dragan are pensioners and Zoran works in the army," he said. "There was no way to shift them but I think everybody else around here did."

Yesterday, as Mr Milosevic's government announced formally that it wanted a second electoral round, Mija and his neighbours were having none of it.

"I don't want another round - we have already won," said Rada Vasiljevic, 41. "I voted for him [Kostunica] not because of myself but because of my son. He left school three years ago and never found a job.

Most of the people in this region are looking for jobs. In the town of Kragujevac the Zastava car and arms factories once produced 250,000 cars a year. After eight years of sanctions against Serbia and the bombing of the factories by Nato it will produce fewer than 20,000 cars this year. It still makes arms, but the workforce has shrunk from more than 40,000 to 11,000.

Mija is the wealthiest man in the village, with two tractors, a dozen pigs and plenty of land, but his farm has also been hit by the economic crisis. He cannot get oil for his tractors and is forced to buy on the black market.

"Since he came to power we've been going down and down. See these hands?" He holds up two great hams, rough as sandpaper with blackened nails. "I'm proud of these hands. The problem is now no matter how hard I work them I can't make money to live."

Life was once good in Majmic, but now the villagers live off vegetables grown in the gardens of their red-roofed farmhouses.

"Politics is the only topic around here these days because the water is up to our chins and people are desperate," Mija added. "We know they counted every vote at the polling stations in the election and Kostunica was winning. They counted them in the municipalities and he was winning and then the votes came to Belgrade and he wasn't president anymore. Something happened there and it is a shame on them."

State-controlled television news is announcing a second election, then showing a report about police beating rioters on the West Bank in Palestine. "They're doing that all the time now - showing us pictures of rioters in other countries. But if Kostunica loses the election again we will be on the streets and we will be rioting."

Meanwhile, Mija's pig is growing. "I'd like to get her to 200 kilos before Kostunica wins but I don't think I'll have the time," he said.

webTitle: £2m in assets to be confiscated from brothel madam

fields.headline: £2m in assets to be confiscated from brothel madam
fields.trailText: A brothel madam was ordered yesterday to hand over more than £2m she had earned from three "saunas", where women smuggled from Thailand and eastern Europe entertained up to 1,500 men a week.
fields.body:
A brothel madam was ordered yesterday to hand over more than £2m she had earned from three "saunas", where women smuggled from Thailand and eastern Europe entertained up to 1,500 men a week.

Josephine Daly, 64, was thought by Scotland Yard to be among the "premier league of London madams". She even advertised her saunas in police magazines.

She was fined £3,000, ordered to pay £50,000 costs and served with a confiscation order for £2m in assets at Harrow crown court, north-west London.

Judge Barrington Black told Daly, who was brought into court in a wheelchair, that no one was suggesting that prostitution was illegal. "What the law cannot accept is that others, be they men or women, should profit by such an act."

He told Daly, who has no previous convictions, that in determining the right punishment he had taken into account matters including her ill health, although "I have misgivings as to the full extent of your incapacity".

As well as her seven bedroom Victorian villa, named Bunty's Corner after a dog buried in the garden, Daly owns six other properties in London, including a dilapidated 60 room hotel and a hostel where the prostitutes lived. The properties have an estimated combined value of up to £5m.

Although she pleaded guilty to controlling prostitution between 1996 and 1997, police believe she built up her empire over more than 10 years.

The court heard that her various premises had generated a £3m income during 1996 and 1997. However, prosecutors have accepted that 30% of her sauna business was legitimate, and the amount to be confiscated was reduced by a third.

Daly was wheeled from court past flowers and pot plants from well-wishers stacked against a wall. Messages included one from "a customer" which read: "Keep smiling, the end is near." Another told her: "I hope this small token of flowers shows that some of us support you," while a third said: "After today I hope you have the strength to put it all behind you."

Outside court, Daly said she would be "cracking open a bottle of champagne. I was hoping for £1m, which would have been easier to find, but I'll sort it... I don't want to go into prison; I don't think I would come out alive."

She added: "I am afraid I will have to retire now. I can't start again. I am too old. What a shame. Now if I was younger... But it has been an horrific three years, and it is a relief it is all over."

Daly said that despite her guilty pleas and the judge's view that the evidence against her was overwhelming, she did not accept she had broken the law. She had admitted the offences only to spare her daughter, Emilia Tawaih - who was originally charged with her mother, but the prosecution dropped the case against her.

"I didn't know what the girls were getting up to," Daly claimed. "I was never there because of my ill health. They did exactly what they liked."

A police surveillance operation showed that 1,500 men a week were going to the Aqua Sauna, Lanacombe Sauna and the Ishka Bath. At one stage Daly ran a fourth sauna.

Undercover officers paid a £10 entrance fee and were invited to choose a women and a variety of sexual services. At that point they made an excuse and left. Real clients would be offered a drink and given a towel.

Prostitutes got no salary but were allowed to keep whatever they earned. The receptionists delivered the door money to Daly's home in Crouch End, North London, each day.

Outside court, Detective Inspector Paul Holmes said: "She was a significant player in the London prostitution racket. It was highly organised."
