webTitle: Divorcees differ with courts on fairness

fields.headline: Divorcees differ with courts on fairness
fields.trailText: Divorce court guidelines on how family wealth should be split are at odds with divorcing couples' ideas of fairness, according to preliminary findings released yesterday from a study by the National Centre for Social Research and Oxford University.
fields.body:
Divorce court guidelines on how family wealth should be split are at odds with divorcing couples' ideas of fairness, according to preliminary findings released yesterday from a study by the National Centre for Social Research and Oxford University.

A survey of people who divorced between 1992 and 1997 revealed a common belief that assets should belong to the partner who bought or inherited them, and pensions to the partner whose earnings paid for them. The exception was the family home, which was seen as a joint asset.

The divorce courts treat the assets as a joint pot to be redistributed mainly according to the needs of each partner and their children. A husband's pension is also treated as a joint asset, with the wife usually entitled to compensation for her loss of a widow's pension after his death.

The study, Settling Up, funded by the Nuffield Foundation, followed up people who had been through a divorce from a large scale 1999 study of how people resolved legal problems. Interviews were mainly carried out by telephone, but a sample of 40 people was interviewed in depth.

The research found it was more common for the family home to be transferred to one spouse than to be sold and the money used to buy cheaper homes for both. Women were particularly keen to stay in the home but often overlooked the running costs. "Women traded off housing against income, capital and future provision," the researchers said.

It was rare for one partner to pay maintenance to the other. Child support was seen as a "moral obligation" but only half the fathers who agreed to pay made regular payments. Interviewees thought a key factor in the financial carve-up should be how much each partner was to blame for the break-up. This is considered largely irrelevant by the courts. But respondents agreed with the courts that there should be a clean break where possible.

"There was a strong preference among women and men for financial independence and severing the financial relationship," the researchers said.

The findings coincide with the publication of research from Oxford University on how divorce solicitors go about their work. Family Lawyers, by John Eekelaar, Mavis Maclean and Sarah Beinart (Hart Publishing) concludes that they provide good value for money and takes issue with government attempts to reduce their role in the divorce process.

The researchers sat in with 10 solicitors for a working day, ranging from those handling legal aid work for the poorest clients to those doing "big money" divorces with a team including accountants and tax experts. They also talked through a sample of cases from start to finish with 40 solicitors. They found that solicitors doing legal aid work operated more like social workers, dealing with several problems, including eviction, domestic violence, child abduction, child sexual abuse, illness and debt.

Clients threatened with domestic violence were given the solicitor's home phone number.

These "thin cats" of the profession survive on low rates of pay. Ms Maclean, senior research fellow at the centre for socio-legal studies, Wolfson College, Oxford, said: "I was sitting in one solicitor's office when the bank manager rang and said 'We're going to pull in your overdraft.' They're really up against it."

The study looked at the solicitors' bills as a percentage of the assets couples were fighting over and concluded that they provided good value.

For husbands paying privately the typical bill was 2%, going up to 6% for wives on legal aid, whose assets were less. Lawyers did not foster conflict but tried to keep costs down by getting clients to do some work themselves.

webTitle: RSC lures London critics to provinces

fields.headline: RSC lures London critics to provinces
fields.trailText: The Royal Shakespeare Company is inviting metropolitan theatre critics to abandon the comforts of London and Stratford-upon-Avon to attend a first night in a sports hall 200 miles north of Euston.
fields.body:
The Royal Shakespeare Company is inviting metropolitan theatre critics to abandon the comforts of London and Stratford-upon-Avon to attend a first night in a sports hall 200 miles north of Euston.

Adrian Noble, the RSC's artistic director, has written to critics urging them to attend the national press night of a production in a leisure centre in Macclesfield, Cheshire.

The Tempest opens on January 18 and launches the RSC's 21st mobile tour, which takes in 20 British towns, including Telford, St Austell in Cornwall, and Northallerton in North Yorkshire, plus Budapest, Lisbon, Porto and Virginia.

The company takes to the road in five trucks laden with 500 seats, a lighting rig, sets and costumes, and sets up in halls in places which see little live theatre. Many in the audience will be seeing their first Shakespeare play.

The Tempest will be seen at the Pit in London and The Other Place in Stratford before it hits the road, but Mr Noble is urging critics not to head for their familiar seats. "I very much want you to experience the production in the environment for which it is particularly designed," he writes. "The encounter you will have of the performances is a completely different experience to seeing it in one of our London or Stratford theatres."

So far only two national newspaper journalists have accepted Mr Noble's invitation. "The rest are probably still in shock and wondering where Macclesfield is," said a company spokeswoman.

Yesterday Mr Noble said the tour had for 21 years taken plays by Shakespeare and others to places with little or no theatrical tradition. "Over the years, we have found that there has been a richness of response, a sense of the circus coming to town.

"In the tour's early days, productions were not seen in London or Stratford, and London critics did not come unless the tour stopped close to the capital, such as in Milton Keynes.

"We are a national company, and it would be a good thing if national newspaper critics could watch the company carry out an important part of its national responsibilities."

fields.headline: Blowout or quick bite?
fields.standfirst: What workers do for a midday meal
fields.trailText: What workers do for a midday meal...
fields.body:
Rebecca Jones, trainee solicitor: "The longest that the qualified lawyers seem to get is the five minutes it takes to pop down to the shop to grab a sandwich, unless there is a client to entertain. But we trainee solicitors tend to arrange group lunchtime outings - if only to the canteen - a couple of times a week. Soon, the pressures of work will become so great that in any choice between an hour-long lunch and an earlier leaving time - ie, before 10pm - the latter will prevail."

Mike Booth, headteacher: "I haven't had a lunch hour in 27 years. I get to the dinner hall a couple of minutes before the bell rings, so I'm there when the students come in. While eating I sit with the kids, so I'm still working. I should really eat salad, but my school dinner usually includes chips. After eating I spend the rest of the time supervising the kids. Out of more than 50 teachers here I could count on one hand the number who have an undisturbed lunch hour as most of them run lunchtime clubs."

Mark Yeung, management consultant: "We can take as long as we like, but I only very rarely take a full hour. It's not so much external pressure as your own internal pressure to work: if I took an hour I'd feel guilty, so I usually just grab a sandwich or wolf something down in the canteen. The thing I regret the most is not getting out more during my lunch break."

Martin Sellers, farmer: "Generally speaking we have lunch from around 12.30pm to 1.15pm - a proper cooked meal. I watch the television, but I'm not one to go in for a sleep after eating. I think it's much more relaxing to have lunch instead of working all day with no one to talk to. It's very different at this time of year, though, when I'm working all day without a stop. I just eat a sandwich sitting on the tractor."

Dr Sarah Schenker, British Nutrition Foundation: "I'm afraid I do exactly what everyone else seems to do and have a lunch minute at my desk, having run out to buy a sandwich, which I eat while typing. Sometimes the boss says he thinks we should go out and walk about. Nutritionally speaking, you can still get what you need from a lunch at your desk if you choose foods low in fat, high in fibre and the like, but socially and psychologically it's not a good thing. On the continent, they wouldn't dream of having the kind of lunch hours we have."

webTitle: Kray 'too ill' to leave honeymoon suite

fields.headline: Kray 'too ill' to leave honeymoon suite
fields.trailText: A newly married couple had to change their wedding night plans because the former gangland boss Reggie Kray was staying in the honeymoon suite they had booked.
fields.body:
A newly married couple had to change their wedding night plans because the former gangland boss Reggie Kray was staying in the honeymoon suite they had booked.

Kevin and Michelle Baker had hoped to spend their first night as a married couple in a four-poster bed.

Instead they were forced to change to a standard room at the Beefeater Town House hotel, Thorpe St Andrew, to accommodate Kray, who has terminal bladder cancer, and his wife, Roberta.

fields.headline: On the menu: confit
fields.standfirst: Food on the net
fields.trailText: Food on the net
fields.body:
Are we continuing our series on cooking techniques? We are.

Why confit, then? Because it seems just about the most misused word in the culinary lexicon, what with lemon confit, salmon confit, pepper confit, tomato confit, etc.

What can you confit? Usually duck, pork or goose, although you can use other meats.

And how do you confit them? Cook them long and lovingly covered in their own fat. Let them cool in their own fat.

So fat is essential? I'd say so.

So what would you say if I told you that confit is the past participle of the French verb "confire" which simply means "to preserve"? Nothing about just in fat. Va t'en, monstre execrable.

Food on the net

www.godecookery.com

As the cold weather sets in, you'd be forgiven for fancying a spot of pottage of an eve, or perhaps even a whole roast hog. So this handy medieval cookery page is just the thing, complete with recipes, hints and Chaucerian references, courtesy of James L Matterer.

Pros: All recipes are shown with both their original and modern spellings. There's a calorie counter, a glossary of terms and a range of dishes, including stewed hen and ricotta and elderflower pie.

Cons: Unobtainability of ingredients. Thankfully Matterer suggests modern alternatives. In the absence of a porpoise, for example, Puddyng of Purpaysse could be made with a large salmon or trout.

fields.trailText: Gonzales Byass Rare Old Solera sherry
fields.body:
Gonzales Byass Rare Old Solera sherry

Form: Amontillado del Duque; Apostoles palo cortado; Noe Pedro Ximinez; Matusalem sweet oloroso.

Flavour: The style of each bottle varies, but the quality remains consistent. These represent the distillation of the essence of old sherries.

Colours vary from deep amber to mahogany black. Each has enough structure and authority to take on food. This is classy stuff. Lay in for Christmas.

fields.headline: 'Cruel' nun spared jail sentence
fields.trailText: A nun who beat, force-fed and humiliated young girls in her care at children's homes run by the Catholic church, yesterday walked free from court in Aberdeen.
fields.body:
A nun who beat, force-fed and humiliated young girls in her care at children's homes run by the Catholic church, yesterday walked free from court in Aberdeen.

The victims of sister Alphonso said they were outraged at a sheriff's decision to admonish the nun on four charges. Last week, sister Alphonso, 58, was found guilty of slapping, force-feeding and throwing urine-soaked underwear at girls in Nazareth house children's homes during the 1960s and 1970s.

She originally faced 23 charges of child cruelty spanning a 20-year period, but sheriff Colin Harris ordered that some of the charges be dropped and instructed the jury to find her not guilty on others.

Jeanette Adams, who was beaten and force-fed by sister Alphonso as a child, condemned yesterday's decision. "I am disgusted," she said.

Another woman who gave evidence against the nun, Agnes Fowler, said the admonishment would deter other victims of abuse from coming forward to the police. She said: "It is going to stop children from saying: 'This is what happened to me'."

Sister Alphonso showed no emotion at the sheriff court as she was told she would receive no punishment for her crimes.

Sheriff Harris said he had considered whether Sister Alphonso deserved a prison sentence, but had decided against one because she was unwell and the crimes took place some time ago.

He said: "I have taken into account that you are presently 58 years old and suffer from a heart condition. I have concluded that a term of imprisonment would not be an appropriate disposal in your case."

Sister Alphonso, who now likes to be known as Sister Marie, left the court building without commenting, but her solicitor, Jim Hay, made a statement on her behalf.

"Over a period of 40 years Sister Marie has provided outstanding care for countless children and old people. Had it not been for this prosecution Sister Marie would have continued her life of service to the elderly, the sick and the dying," he said.

webTitle: Smart video remembers viewer's favourite shows

fields.headline: Smart video remembers viewer's favourite shows
fields.trailText: The days of the humble video recorder appear numbered after the launch yesterday of a box that can take note of a viewer's preferences and store programmes he or she might like to watch.
fields.body:
The days of the humble video recorder appear numbered after the launch yesterday of a box that can take note of a viewer's preferences and store programmes he or she might like to watch.

TiVo, the product of a US company, could radically alter the way we watch TV, allowing viewers to build schedules of favourite shows. It could also be the answer for a generation yet to work out how to programme existing videos.

TiVo stores up to 40 hours of programmes on a hard drive, instead of a tape. The shows can be selected by choosing from onscreen programme guides, but it can also be set up to record a show's entire series, and can also search and record by genre or by the name of an actor.

The UK version of the box retails for £399 for the recorder, plus either a £10 monthly subscription or a one off payment of £199 for the personalised services. It will be available in high street electrical stores.

It is being marketed alongside Rupert Murdoch-owned BSkyB, but users need not be subscribers to Sky - the system also works with conventional analogue TV as well as cable and On Digital.

"We are really changing the way people think about their TV," said Howard Look, vice-president of TiVo Studios. "You never have to worry about missing your favourite programme, and, if they change the time of the broadcast, TiVo will know about it.

"There are also no more pesky video tapes, no worries about finding one that's blank or recording over your wedding video."

The system has all the pause and rewind functions of a traditional video. And TiVo stores the programme a viewer is watching, allowing a live programme to be paused for up to 30 minutes and then be caught up; instant replays of live shows are also available.

Perhaps the most advanced function of the box is the "smart" element that tracks what a viewer watches, whether it be tennis or costume drama, and records similar shows in the same genre. A fan of Pride and Prejudice for instance might find Vanity Fair has been stored.

In the US 53,000 households have so far signed up.

Fans of the technology suggest it will put an end to viewers being dictated to by schedulers. There is also some evidence viewers use TiVo to fast forward the majority of advertising. This worry for commercial channels has been dismissed by the Granada Media chairman, Charles Allen, who said: "There has always been technology to allow you to skip the advertisements. It's called the kettle."

webTitle: Cambridge to lead Chernobyl cancer inquiry

fields.headline: Cambridge to lead Chernobyl cancer inquiry
fields.trailText: Britain is to coordinate an international effort into discovering how the Chernobyl disaster managed to cause a huge increase in child cancer.
fields.body:
Britain is to coordinate an international effort into discovering how the Chernobyl disaster managed to cause a huge increase in child cancer.

The project could lead to government guidelines such as advice to parents on giving children iodine in the event of a nuclear emergency.

Under the scheme, announced in the journal Science, Cambridge University will make available to international researchers hundreds of samples from Chernobyl-related child cancer tumours held in Minsk, Kiev and Obninsk, outside Moscow.

Until now, laboratories around the world have been unable to get hold of samples from enough children to carry out meaningful studies.

Bureaucratic and political obstacles, such as the fact that the tissue banks are held in three countries - Belarus, Ukraine and Russia - have frustrated outside attempts to investigate the damage the nuclear disaster caused to unprotected civilians.

Researchers will submit proposals to an international panel and if appproved, the Strangeways research laboratory in Cambridge will organise delivery of genetic material from the three tissue banks.

Several dozen people, many of them firefighters, were killed by blasts of radiation in the immediate aftermath of the Chernobyl disaster.

Catastrophe struck when a nuclear power station's reactor blew up in northern Ukraine in 1986 spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe.

However, the only proven long term consequence of the disaster to nearby communities in Ukraine, Belarus and Russia apart from the psychological damage has been a huge increase in child thyroid cancer.

Usually the disease strikes one in a million people a year but in Gomel, the region of Belarus which suffered worst from the disaster, the figure is 90 in a million each year.

More than a thousand children and teenagers have been affected with about 200 new cases each year.

Death is rare but sufferers must have their thyroid gland removed from their neck and take the drug thyroxin for the rest of their lives.

Figures due out later this year suggest a decline in child cases but an increase in the disease among adolescents as those who were infants at the time of the disaster get older.

Gerry Thomas, coordinator of the programme, said yesterday: "This resource will for the first time allow scientists across the world to collaborate in studies of a large number of tumours for which the cause is undisputed.

"Ultimately it will enable us to develop much more informed preventative and therapeutic strategies should another nuclear accident occur."

She was reluctant to comment on past difficulties of getting tissue sample.

But one source familiar with the issue said: "It's extremely difficult for westerners to get access because of the politics involved. Running this through the governments means access should be easier for the key people."

The thyroid gland takes up iodine naturally. In the days after the accident, the wrecked Chernobyl reactor spewed out radioactive iodine, which lodged in the thyroids of babies and children.

The cancers could easily have been prevented if parents had given their children iodine tablets immediately after the accident or even smeared a little household iodine on their throats.

But it was days before the authorities admitted that there was anything wrong.

Sir Dillwyn Williams, chairman of the panel overseeing the project, said research suggested that the very youngest children were at an even greater risk than previously thought from the radioactive iodine.

He said that talks were under way with the Department of Health about changing the guidelines on giving iodine in the event of a nuclear disaster in Britain.

"Discussions are going on with the department here as to whether there should be a change in the dose level at which stable iodine is distributed in the light of the findings after Chernobyl," Sir Dillwyn said.

Doctors in the affected regions insist that there is no evidence of any other Chernobyl-related cancer increase but governments have muddied the waters with misleading statistics.

In Belarus, any child with cancer is automatically classified as a victim of Chernobyl. In Ukraine several years ago, the government included former Chernobyl clean-up workers who had died in traffic accidents in its list of victims of the disaster.

fields.headline: Mankind speeding extinction of wildlife
fields.trailText: A distressing picture of human activities pushing an ever increasing number of mammals, birds, trees and plants to the brink of extinction is published today in the internationally recognised "red list" of endangered species.
fields.body:
A distressing picture of human activities pushing an ever increasing number of mammals, birds, trees and plants to the brink of extinction is published today in the internationally recognised "red list" of endangered species.

Gorillas, the Iberian lynx, some species of dolphins, eagles, eight types of freshwater turtles and 16 types of albatross are all disappearing.

The 2000 list, the most comprehensive look at the chances of survival of everything from the great whales to humble mosses, concludes that mankind is causing extinctions at 50 times the natural rate.

The four-yearly report shows that 11 mammals have slipped into the critically endangered category since 1996, and one monkey, Miss Waldron's red colobus, has not been seen despite extensive searches in the Ivory Coast and Ghana.

The report says: "The global extinction crisis is as bad as or worse than believed, with dramatic declines of many species, including reptiles and primates."

Around a quarter of all reptiles, one in five amphibians and one in three freshwater fish are described as threatened. But the report says that many plants and animals are probably becoming extinct before they have time to be discovered and properly described.

Species in danger are placed in categories. Most enter the red list by being classed as threatened, which means they face a high risk of extinction in the near future. There are 11,046 plants and animals in this category. One in four mam mal species and one in eight of all birds is now red listed.

Critically endangered means extinction is close. Falling into this category is the Cross River gorilla. There are only 150 to 200 left in dense forest on the Nigerian/Cameroon border.

Another is the Philippine eagle, down from an original population of 6,000 to between 350 and 600. The old growth forest on which it depends for survival is being cut down. The World Conservation Union, which compiles the list, believes that if the eagle can be saved so too can 27 other species of bird in the same forest also heading for extinction.

Indonesia, India, Brazil and China are among the countries with the most threatened mammals and birds, while plant species are declining fastest in central and west Africa and south-east Asia.

But Europe is not immune. The Iberian lynx is down to 600 survivors, mainly in Spain, because of loss of habitat.

In the UK, the red squirrel has suffered a crash in population, and the small eyed ray has been killed in large numbers by trawl nets. The common sturgeon, which if caught round British coasts is supposed to be delivered to the Queen, is so critically endangered from overfishing for its caviar in the Baltic that she will be lucky to see one again.

Also threatened in the UK are 11 varieties of Sorbus, a small tree with red berries, because their habitat has been destroyed by limestone quarrying. One, Sorbus bristoliensis, lives only in the Avon Gorge in Somerset and there are only about 100 plants in all.

Craig Hilton-Taylor, the Cambridge based scientist who compiled the list, described his job as the most depressing in the world.

He said: "It is depressing at times. Sometimes there does seem to be no hope, but unless we find out what is happening it is difficult to know what to do about it and what our priorities should be."

But there are glimmers of hope. The otter, threatened worldwide, is recovering in Britain. The white rhino, down to 200 animals and confined to South Africa in the late 1970s, is up to 11,000 and its range has increased to several countries.

webTitle: Cricketers bare all in night match

fields.headline: Cricketers bare all in night match
fields.trailText: Police were called to a cricket club after a group of cricketers decided to hold a naked night match, it emerged today.
fields.body:
Police were called to a cricket club after a group of cricketers decided to hold a naked night match, it emerged today.

The sportsmen were enjoying an end of season celebration at Ben Rhydding Cricket Club, near Ilkley, West Yorkshire, when they decided to strip and have a game.

Using car headlights to light up the field, the 18 cricketers played for about an hour on Saturday night until police were called.

A police spokesman said: "There was no noise and nothing untoward was happening. The cricketers were on their way home by the time we got there."

The club captain, Andrew Jennings, said it was so cold the umpire was allowed to wear a coat.

"It went on for about an hour, much to the amazement of passing traffic," he said. "It's what sport is all about."

fields.headline: No: 1730
fields.standfirst: Thomas More
fields.trailText: Thomas More
fields.body:
Sounds like something Nicole Kidman might shout during sex. Cheeky. 'Tis nothing of the kind, you rogue, as they used to say in ye olden days when More was lord chancellor of England (1529 to 1532, if you need the exact dates for a pub quiz). He had previously served as an MP, chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and speaker of the House of Commons before being introduced to Henry VIII by the creepy Thomas Wolsey. He also wrote Utopia, which earned him comparisons with the most eminent humanists of the Renaissance.

What an achiever. But there was a sticky end involved somewhere, wasn't there? There was. Sir Thomas was beheaded by Henry VIII in 1535 for refusing to recognise the rotund monarch as head of the Church of England. After the schism with Rome, he resigned the chancellorship and was imprisoned for high treason. When he was still unrepentent after a year in prison, Henry VIII lost his patience and Sir Thomas lost his head. Four hundred years later, he was canonised as a martyr.

Oh dear. A sticky end indeed - all that blood and twitching sinews. But so far, so long, long time ago. What is the relevance to this New Britain of ours at the dawn of a spangly, pristine millennium? Sir Thomas is set to become the patron saint of politicians.

Do they deserve one? They certainly need one, and Sir Thomas is as good a candidate as any. He was an accomplished politician himself, using his training as a lawyer to connive, calculate and cook up all sorts of plots without having to face the consequences. He tortured heretics too.

webTitle: Jerry Hall loses jewels in burglary

fields.headline: Jerry Hall loses jewels in burglary
fields.trailText: The model and actor Jerry Hall was recovering last night from the shock of burglars breaking into her £5m London home.
fields.body:
The model and actor Jerry Hall was recovering last night from the shock of burglars breaking into her £5m London home.

It is believed that the burglars stole items worth £7,000 from the house on a hill overlooking Richmond Park in south-west London, on Wednesday night, soon after she had returned from her performance in The Graduate in the West End. A laptop computer and jewellery were among the items taken.

Police from nearby Twickenham station were called to the house at 11.30pm when Ms Hall sounded the alarm after hearing the burglars on the stairs.

A police helicopter and police dogs searched the surrounding areas and parkland but found nothing.

Ms Hall and her four children live in the 26 room house. Although Mick Jagger moved out earlier this year after the couple divorced, the house still contains memorabilia of the Rolling Stones.

Yesterday Ms Hall declined to comment as she left the house at lunchtime for her matinee and evening performances as Mrs Robinson.

fields.headline: Geo posts first profit
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Geo Interactive, a producer of chips which transmit video over mobile telephones, yesterday shook off recent boardroom turmoil to record its first profit to date.
fields.body:
Geo Interactive, a producer of chips which transmit video over mobile telephones, yesterday shook off recent boardroom turmoil to record its first profit to date.

Interim profit from operations to June 30 reached $4m (£2.8m) from a $7.4m loss previously, while turnover rocketed from $300,000 to $12.7m - considerably above analysts' expectations.

Earlier this month Geo's shares slumped 16% in one day when chief executive Shai Schiller resigned suddenly.

Yesterday Eli Reifman, a founder of the Israeli-based company who has taken over the role of chief executive, said Mr Schiller was still with Geo but planned to retire shortly. There were suggestions at the time of Mr Schiller's resignation that he was leaving to set up a rival operation.

Mr Reifman said Geo, which claimed to be the fastest growing stock in Europe last year, was on track to become "a real" FTSE 100 company.

It is close to making the list of top UK firms by capitalisation but Mr Reifman is aware it needs to produce consistent and growing profits to be taken seriously.

He said: "We are near to the FTSE 100 on share value but we are far from being a real FTSE company in essence. Today is the first step in that journey."

The company was only listed on the London Stock Exchange in 1998 after joining the AIM two years earlier.

Shares in the company rose 27.5p to £12.60 as some British investors, who make up the vast majority of its shareholder base, moved back into the stock.

Mr Reifman claims the company is at least 18 months ahead of British rivals such as Forbidden Technologies and Indigo Vision, arguing it it is the only one with commercial applications of its technology in place.

"Our goal over the next 24 months is to become a world leader," said Mr Reifman.

webTitle: Prozac aids women who suffer PMS

fields.headline: Prozac aids women who suffer PMS
fields.trailText: Antidepressant drugs such as Prozac can help women who suffer from premenstrual syndrome, a study published today suggests.
fields.body:
Antidepressant drugs such as Prozac can help women who suffer from premenstrual syndrome, a study published today suggests.

The findings, which show that antidepressants help to reduce the physical and emotional effects associated with PMS, are published in the latest edition of the Lancet.

The group of drugs, called selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors, is increasingly being used as therapy for women whose lives are severely disrupted each month before the onset of their period.

Researchers from Keele University and North Staffordshire hospital studied the effects of drugs on the syndrome. They used the results of 15 trials, involving 904 women using four different drug types.

The results showed that antidepressants were seven times more effective than a placebo in treating physical and emotional symptoms of PMS.

Women taking the drug intermittently to cope with the effects benefited as much as women taking it continuously.

But women taking the drug, rather than the placebo, were 2 times more likely to drop out of the trial because of side effects.

The researchers concluded the drugs were effective treatment and, at a low dose, the side effects were acceptable.

Meir Steiner, a professor in the department of psychiatry at McMaster University in Canada, said other drugs, including calcium carbonate and vitamin B6, could also help sufferers.

webTitle: Abortion pill on sale in US

fields.headline: Abortion pill on sale in US
fields.trailText: Abortion was thrust to the front of the US presidential campaign yesterday when the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved the sale of the abortion pill, RU-486, after a 12-year battle.
fields.body:
Abortion was thrust to the front of the US presidential campaign yesterday when the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved the sale of the abortion pill, RU-486, after a 12-year battle.

RU-486, which will be distributed in the US as Mifeprex, prevents a fertilised egg from attaching itself to the uterus, and can be used by women who are up to 49 days pregnant.

It was first marketed in Britain in 1991, but President George Bush banned its importation. That decision was reversed by the Clinton administration, and the FDA gave provisional approval for its manufacture in the US in 1996. When the original manufacturer pulled out in 1997 because of the controversy, the Population Council, a family planning organisation, persuaded Danco Laboratories to make the pill.

Anti-abortion activists who had tried to prevent the pill going on sale said they would now throw resources behind the Republican candidate, George W Bush, who opposes the pill's distribution.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: The corruption scandal engulfing French president Jacques Chirac's RPR party looked set to run and run yesterday after the government rejected any possibility of an amnesty.
fields.body:
No amnesty for Chirac party

The corruption scandal engulfing French president Jacques Chirac's RPR party looked set to run and run yesterday after the government rejected any possibility of an amnesty.

Justice minister Elisabeth Guigou, said there could be "no question of an amnesty to exempt scandal-tainted politicians from their responsibilities".
Jon Henley , Paris

Italian treason trial begins

Nine Italians, including four ex-generals, went on trial yesterday on charges of treason and giving false testimony in connection with the mysterious Ustica plane crash 20 years ago.

Eighty-one people died when a DC-9 flown by the airline Itavia crashed into the Mediterranean.

Media reports based on radar data released in 1997 showed that Nato fighter aircraft were in the area the night of the crash, possibly following Libyan MiGs flying close to the airliner.
Reuters, Rome

Chinese miners die in explosion

A gas explosion in a coal mine in Dawan Guizhou province, southern China, on Wednesday left as many as 161 miners dead or missing, officials said yesterday.
AP, Shanghai

New warnings on adult films

Hollywood studio Warner Bros is to create new designations for films containing sex, bad language or violence, a Senate inquiry heard yesterday.

Other studios agreed to curb the marketing of adult films to children.
Duncan Campbell , Los Angeles

German train drivers strike

Train drivers staged pay strikes in more than eight German cities yesterday, paralysing commuter rail traffic. Worst-hit was the Frankfurt am Main region.
Tony Paterson, Berlin

webTitle: Letter: Think of the children first

fields.headline: Think of the children first
fields.trailText: Your story (Mandela the face of Unicef adverts, September 28) claims that Nelson Mandela is to appear in a £200m advertising campaign to be directed by Steven Spielberg. While we welcome the coverage given to Unicef's work, we would like to point out that the Global Movement for Children initiative in general, and the advertising component specifically, do not at present have a set budget but it will be considerably less than the figure mentioned.
fields.body:
Your story (Mandela the face of Unicef adverts, September 28) claims that Nelson Mandela is to appear in a £200m advertising campaign to be directed by Steven Spielberg. We have not as yet approached Nelson Mandela in connection with this particular project although he is, together with Graca Machel, leading a renewed effort to highlight children's projects.
David Bull
Executive director, Unicef UK

fields.headline: Germans rock to Chancellor Rap
fields.trailText: German chancellor Gerhard Schröder's thirst for beer during a meet-the-people tour is on the brink of propelling him into the music charts.
fields.body:
German chancellor Gerhard Schröder's thirst for beer during a meet-the-people tour is on the brink of propelling him into the music charts.

The lyrics of a rap CD, entitled Get Me a Bottle of Beer, are derived entirely from a recording of remarks made by Mr Schröder while he signed autographs during a tour of eastern Germany in August.

Against a techno backing, he can be heard saying: "Get me a bottle of beer. Or I'll go on strike here and won't sign any more. Make it a decent slurp."

A television comedian, Stefan Raab, edited the soundbites to produce the CD, which the German music industry has dubbed "Chancellor Rap". It was launched 10 days ago. Since then more than 700,000 people have downloaded the track from the internet while 125,000 have gone out and bought copies.

A spokesman for EMI said: "If the trend continues, the track will be number one."

The chancellery is not amused. Mr Schröder, who has refused an invitation to appear on Mr Raab's show, said: "I am not a fan of his."

fields.headline: The money that matters
fields.trailText: Means testing will not eliminate pensioner poverty as is implied by your leader (Ending pension poverty, September 28). Nor is it more affordable. Means testing produces perverse incentives which sap self-sufficiency and it wastes millions on intrusive bureaucracy.
fields.body:
Means testing will not eliminate pensioner poverty as is implied by your leader (Ending pension poverty, September 28). Nor is it more affordable. Means testing produces perverse incentives which sap self-sufficiency and it wastes millions on intrusive bureaucracy.

The government is setting up an array of "products" to appeal to pensioners - fuel allowances, free TV licences, tax credits as well as increases in existing benefits. The extra money for pensioners is welcome but how long will it take us to realise that it would be spent more effectively if rolled up into a decent universal payment that goes to all pensioners as of right and keeps its value? This is what happened when child benefit was created. Child benefit still remains the most effective mechanism of combating child poverty. It gets to all families with children and is withdrawn from the better off through the tax system. What could be simpler?
Dr Lynne Jones MP

 It is sad that, in putting his eminently reasonable call for adequate pensions, Rodney Bickerstaffe feels obliged to say that he and his demands are not "old" labour (Castle's pension victory, September 28). Sad too that Jeff Rooker - survivor of the Wise-Rooker duo whose struggle linked benefits to earnings in a former Labour government - is now the government defender.

What's wrong with restoring the public service ethos, the value of collective action - and the pension-earnings link? Better "old"-fashioned principles than... what's that other word they've been (over) using since 1997?
John Nicholson
Chief Executive, UK Public Health Association

 As befits trade union leaders looking forward to retiring on nice fat, union pensions, no doubt Brothers Bickerstaffe and Edmunds can see the logic of giving all pensioners the same cost of living increase. Not for them the socialist maxim of "from each according to their ability and to each according to their need". Gordon Brown on Tuesday offered a fair and reasonable way forward for pensions, one that would give, in a short space of time, the very poorest and those who have modest incomes a big boost to their state pensions. Instead of welcoming this initiative the Brothers, by dividing the Labour movement, have considerably lessened the chance of pensioners receiving anything but a miserly redistribution of "old" money by an incoming Tory government.
Glen Pullen
Flitwick, Beds glenpullen@kbnet.co.uk

 I am sure there are many old people living in abject poverty who, of course, need and deserve to be helped. However, I know many old-age pensioners who own their own homes and take holidays abroad. One vociferous group must not be allowed to grab more than their fair share. We old folk have had our day. Let us for once speak up on behalf of the young.
Juanita Woolliscroft
Holt, Norfolk

 So, angry pensioners will not vote for Labour unless the link to earnings is restored? From whom will they receive this favour - the Conservatives?
Julius Mindel
Bournemouth jmindel@edencourt.fsnet.co.uk

 Yes, they are listening. Yes, they have heard us. Yet they still do not understand the fundamental difference between a contributory pension and a means-tested charity hand-out.
L Underwood
High Wycombe, Bucks len@uwood.screaming.net

 The government, supported by Labour MPs, did not hesitate to link their pensions to the highest civil servant pay scale. Justice for some.
Bob Holmes
Axbridge, Somerset

fields.body:

They will thus be able to buy yet more rust buckets, retired from the Baltic or North sea runs, 20 years past their sell-by dates, with which to make huge, competition-free profits. Philip Simmonds
Cambridge

fields.headline: Hidden killer
fields.trailText: It was good to see that the secretary of state for health is allocating more money to cancer (Patients to be offered operation booking system, September 28). And it is good to see how he plans to cut waiting lists for cardiac and cancer services. But what is this country planning to do about our main cause of serious disability and third biggest killer - stroke?

But what is this country planning to do about our main cause of serious disability and third biggest killer - stroke?

Mr Milburn admits that the NHS let his friend Ian Weir down while he was waiting for a heart operation. My sympathy goes to Mr Weir's family, but the NHS is also letting down thousands of stroke patients each year by not giving them the best care available - organised stroke care. Is it not about time Mr Milburn turned his attention to the 100,000 new stroke cases a year?

The Stroke Association
London

Given the risk of inadvertent consumption of the seed, we would strongly advise against any form of consumption of yew berries.

fields.headline: Cherish diversity, not division
fields.trailText: I am sure Faisal Bodi enjoyed the flourish of his comments on me and others (Don't label me, please, September 28) when he wrote that we claimed, without justification, to represent "black" people and that we wanted to melt society down in cooking pots. But let me just remind him of a few basic and very easily checked facts.
fields.body:
I am sure Faisal Bodi enjoyed the flourish of his comments on me and others (Don't label me, please, September 28) when he wrote that we claimed, without justification, to represent "black" people and that we wanted to melt society down in cooking pots. But let me just remind him of a few basic and very easily checked facts.

First, I do not represent anyone. I am a journalist and writer. I talk to people and have ideas of my own. Second, in all my writing, including in my columns this month, I have consistently argued against simplistic assumptions about politics and "black" representation, although I feel strongly that all our institutions remain too white. Finally, the only thing that unites Darcus Howe, Lee Jasper and myself is that we refuse to be confined to pre-destined identities (unlike Bodi who sees himself entirely in terms of an idealised Muslim identity), and that we have taken our ideas out of the ghetto and into the wider arena of national life. Perhaps this is why we are taken seriously by so many Britons.
Yasmin Alibhai-Brown
London

 About once a year we are forced to deal with the lame duck argument that the UK's African, Asian and Caribbean communities have politically nothing in common. And every year we give the same answer. We recognise our immense differences, in fact for the most part we celebrate them.

However, we come together politically on a number of key issues: a fair and just immigration and asylum policy; a democracy that reflects the nation's diversity; a society that offers our communities equality of opportunity; and an environment that ensures our loved ones such as Stephen Lawrence, Ali Ibrahim, Shiji Lapite, Quddas Ali and Muktar Ahmed are not stabbed, shot or beaten senseless not because they were Caribbean, African or Asian but because they were black.

As for Operation Black Vote's success, one need look no further than the mayoral elections. Every candidate courted the black vote as never before. Why? Because victory depended on it.
Lee Jasper
Simon Woolley
Operation Black Vote

fields.headline: A master of misery
fields.trailText: Leonard Cohen is no longer "a monk in California" (Has anyone here seen Leonard? September 27). If Arthur Smith had taken the time to consult the authoritative Leonard Cohen Files website which he disparages as being run by "speccy Norwegians" - he didn't even get that right, the webmaster is actually Finnish - he would have found that Cohen hung up his Zen robes as long ago as June 1999.
fields.body:
Leonard Cohen is no longer "a monk in California" (Has anyone here seen Leonard? September 27). If Arthur Smith had taken the time to consult the authoritative Leonard Cohen Files website which he disparages as being run by "speccy Norwegians" - he didn't even get that right, the webmaster is actually Finnish - he would have found that Cohen hung up his Zen robes as long ago as June 1999.

Furthermore, I thought it was a bit puerile of Mr Smith to complain that the cost of hiring a duck for his show, Arthur Smith Sings Leonard Cohen, had forced him to appoint an unemployed actor to the role instead (Duck gets the bird from West End show, September 27). The humanitarian sentiment may be right-on, but the New Ambassadors theatre is charging £14 for a ticket to the one-hour show. For that sort of money, I'd expect either a real duck or for Mr Smith to pay the actor a bit more than the union minimum!

But as a longtime Cohen fan, I'll come to the show anyway. I hope to have a really miserable evening.
RP Cooper
Twickenham rikc420@ukonline.co.uk

 Has nobody thought to give some credit to Norman Tebbit as the originator of our recent crop of Olympic cycling medals?
Jane Moth
Bolton

 I thought we were due for a nasty one from Steve Bell (September 27). His cartoon of Tony Blair reduced to a mass of teeth and eyeballs went down a treat with my boiled egg and soldiers.
John V Heyes
Oxford

 Of course hard-core videos have plots and pretensions to art (The best possible taste, Guide, September 27). Why else would God have given us the fast-forward button?
Stephen Parkin
London

fields.headline: Life, an artful adventure
fields.trailText: In the cases of President Clinton and Lord Archer (Lord Archer charged with perjury, September 27), their behaviour has not been as pure as driven snow, to say the least. Not good examples, but what business is that of ours? Why should they be exposed in the press, when no crime was committed and the result was to jeopardise their marriages?
fields.body:
In the cases of President Clinton and Lord Archer (Lord Archer charged with perjury, September 27), their behaviour has not been as pure as driven snow, to say the least. Not good examples, but what business is that of ours? Why should they be exposed in the press, when no crime was committed and the result was to jeopardise their marriages? Would not most people be "honour bound", if one may use that phrase, to lie in order to protect their families?

Once starting down that path, Lord Archer seemingly felt compelled to sue for libel and, whatever one might think of his means, the major crime, it seems to me, was in the publication of the original story.
Alan Foster
Cheadle, Cheshire AlanandEd@btinternet.com

 A surgeon, played by Lord Archer, is accused of murdering his wife (Archer takes refuge on stage from a real life drama, September 27). Perjury, perverting the course of justice, bankruptcy and shameless self-promotion. What will Lord Archer do next? Write something half-decent? Join the Labour party? I think that we should be told.
Christopher Coates
London

 Could it be that the target of the recent missile attack (Tank-buster used in attack on MI6, September 23) was not MI6 but Lord Archer? His penthouse is just down the road. Creditors, perhaps?
E H Turner
Norwich

webTitle: BMW unwraps the new, bigger Mini

fields.headline: BMW unwraps the new, bigger Mini
fields.trailText: BMW has taken the wraps off the new Mini, simultaneously revealing the part the car will play in the group's long-term strategy, writes Mark Milner.
fields.body:
BMW has taken the wraps off the new Mini, simultaneously revealing the part the car will play in the group's long-term strategy.

Coupled with the Rolls-Royce brand, which BMW will acquire in 2003, the Mini will give the German car maker a portfolio ranging from the small car sector to the higher end of the luxury market.

But in an oblique reference to BMW's unhappy ownership of Rover, where the group sustained heavy losses, the chairman of the Munich-based managing board, Professor Joachim Milberg - pictured right, with the new car - made it clear the car maker was keen to steer clear of the volume market and to con centrate instead on profitable growth.

Speaking at the preview of the new car at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts on Paris's left bank before the formal launch at the French motor show, Prof Milberg described the Mini as "the second cornerstone of our premium brand strategy".

"We will be the only multi-brand manufacturer not operating in the mass market," he said.

BMW's strategy would be to look at areas showing growth potential where it could make money, he said.

The new Mini, which will go on sale next year, will be available in three models - a basic version, a Mini Cooper and a Mini Cooper S. Executives said the basic version will be "significantly less" than DM30,000 (£9,600).

The new car retains something of the rugged look of the old Mini but at four metres long is larger than the original.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Magnolia | Boys Don't Cry | Les Enfants du Paradis
fields.trailText: Magnolia | Boys Don't Cry | Les Enfants du Paradis
fields.body:
Magnolia
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Entertainment in Video Cert 18
****

Magnolia sees Paul Thomas Anderson flipping through interconnected lives almost at random. It's like flipping a radio dial and seeing what you come up with. Anderson's end product is deep, dark and dangerous - these, by and large, are lives at the end of their tether being acted on by chance and coincidence as much as cause and effect.

It's the film director as God. Anderson even visits a plague of frogs on his characters and his three-hour film is topped and tailed by equally strange occurrences. Anderson's last film, Boogie Nights, had horrible happenings but there was a sense of community and continuity which is significantly lacking here.

The trademark swirling camera of Anderson's regular cinematographer, Robert Elswit - remember Boogie Nights opening shot - is in evidence in complicated set-ups and long takes. Many of his rep team - Julianne Moore, William H Macy, Philip Baker Hall and Alfred Molina - return. But it's Tom Cruise, his familiar toothy grin turned alarmingly feral in a sinister turn that's far further from his persona than he's ventured before and in a humbler role: he's just one of 12 alphabetically named stars, one plot in Anderson's skilfully cut jigsaw. And two names you probably won't know - Melora Walters and John C Reilly - are as good as anyone.

It's a strange, bleak, ambitious tale full of regret, guilt and doppelgangers. Magnolia lacks Boogie Nights's clear structure but positively demands to be watched twice when, I suspect, it may seem even better.

Boys Don't Cry
Rental Fox Pathé Cert 18
****

The potentially tawdry tale of a gender-bending petty thief who tries to start a new life as a male in small-town Nebraska leading to rape and murder is handled with great tact and sensitivity by director/co-writer Kimberly Peirce and a carefully selected cast.

Hilary Swank, who won the Oscar as the film's central character, ended a long hunt for someone who could convince as Brandon/ Teena (she first had to spend a month being accepted as male in real life). No less remarkable is Chloë Sevigny's performance as Lana, the girl who comes to love and trust Brandon both before and after the truth becomes apparent.

Against all possible odds, Swank and Sevigny have given us one of the most natural and romantic screen couples of the year as the two outsiders desperate for a little tenderness and someone to believe in. It's easy to imagine the treatment Lana's shiftless family and friends would have had in most films, but here nobody is a stereotype, everyone is a believable, complex character. Peirce, who is only 33, gives the film an atmosphere of hope mixed with foreboding - a sad tale brilliantly brought to life.

Les Enfants du Paradis
Retail (£15.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Second Sight Cert PG
***

Often referred to but rarely seen these days, Marcel Carné's three-hour plus epic is a flamboyant celebration of French theatre and the ups and downs of love - and of the country's liberation, as if it was released in 1945. It's floridly romantic in a way that makes it seem more dated than, say, L'Atalante, but also funny and stylish in turn and it has a real glow both in its look - in a newly restored print and its affection for its characters. Made in black and white, it was recently voted "best French film ever" by the French Film Academy and despite its length, its complex plot never seems padded and provides some spectacular setpieces.

fields.headline: Dangerous Liasons
fields.standfirst: She is the woman Leonardo DiCaprio would like to bed. She has a penchant for being cast in  amour fou scenarios. And she doesn't think stereotypes are wrong. As her latest movie finds her caught in a destructive love triangle,  Libby Brooks  wonders if Sophie Marceau is more than just a male fantasy
fields.trailText: She is the woman Leonardo DiCaprio would like to bed. She has a penchant for being cast in amour fou scenarios. And she doesn't think stereotypes are wrong. As her latest movie finds her caught in a destructive love triangle, Libby Brooks wonders if Sophie Marceau is more than just a male fantasy
fields.body:
Her face remains, long after the charming flesh has bid farewell, returning still and exact to the mind's eye. Sophie Marceau is certainly beautiful. Beneath the misbehaving fringe, her features have the regular perfection that makes babies smile. Her lips are plump and mobile, her olive gaze soft. The thick, glossed hair tempts the fingers. Her skin is vital.

But beauty is seldom openly self-aware. Marceau insists that she has no concept of her physical effect. "No, never, because to be honest, I" - she rummages in her bag for a lighter - "I've never really been beautiful. I'm photogenic, which is very important, and now I'm getting older I'm aware I have to take care. I shouldn't smoke." She waves her still unlit cigarette. "I'm transformable, and you can do all sorts of different styles with me." She snakes and flutters her hands around her face. "I can be sexy or I can be not sexy at all. I don't want to be stuck in one thing, because I'm not myself one thing."

Nor is 33-year-old Marceau without complexity beyond the surface. A truck driver's daughter from a dreary Parisian suburb, she made her acting debut at 13, in the coming-of-age film La Boum. It branded her on to the national consciousness. One of the few French actresses of her generation to attain international recognition, she has worked the arthouse circuit alongside Antonioni, Wenders, Deneuve and Depardieu as well as shimmering through Mel Gibson's Braveheart and the Bond blockbuster The World Is Not Enough. She is renowned both for her bemusing pensées (she believes that only a woman can play Hamlet properly) and her bluntness. (When Leonardo DiCaprio intimated that he would like to work with her "because she is as hot as it gets", she laughed and told reporters: "He's a child - is he 13? Or 11? Perhaps I could play his nanny.")

Her latest movie concerns the complexity of fidelity: to whom are we faithful, and how are we faithful to them? In La Fidélité, her character Clélia wrestles two conflicting connections - the hopeful, nourishing love she shares with her gentle husband and the visceral compulsion that draws her to a troubled, passionate colleague. Her indecision is, unfortunately, as tortuous as the pacing of the film, and ultimately both relationships are destroyed.

"You can't pretend you are anything other than human," muses Marceau, "which means being full of contradictions. Life is always unexpected. Clélia has chosen faithfulness, but she is very tormented, and she's very tempted, because she's a woman , because life is full of attractions and easiness. According to the director, she is unfaithful. But I think she is faithful, because physically she is faithful, which is a huge step."

Do men and women see physical and emotional fidelity differently? "I wonder if it is deep in the feminine or masculine nature to be that way, or if it is because societies and rules and religions have imposed their way of ordering the world. In the last 50 years women have moved forward so much. If I look at my grandmother - my God! - she had 13 children, she had nothing to say at home, she wasn't happy, but there was no question of adultery or divorce because that wasn't how it was.

"Nowadays, we're thinking that women can change partners every week, but is it the reality? Have we really come out from those 800 years behind the stove? We are caught between the temptation of becoming somebody completely free, or trying to keep some of those rules that have been so difficult to live with for such a long time. It's not easy. We are at a crossroads now, and we have to walk with awareness."

"The director" who doubts the unfaithful heart is in fact Marceau's partner, and father of her five-year-old son Vincent, namely Polish film-maker Andrzej Zulawski. La Fidélité is their fourth collaboration. They fell in love when she was 18 and he was 42, when he first directed her as a teenage prostitute in L'Amour Braque, a modern interpretation of Dostoyevsky's The Idiot. Although she refers to him as her husband, the pair have never married.

She enjoys the familiarity of working with him, she says. "A director has to be a manipulator. It's like an orchestra. If you all play together without someone to give the rhythm, is it quick, is it slow, is it green, is it blue? You get lost. Somebody has to be strong. It's his movie. It's not my movie, it's my part. He loves that." She giggles gleefully. She refers to him by professional title, not personal relationship, and hints at a Pygmalion element to their partnership. "He's a great mentor. He loves to be important in somebody's life, and I think I must too, because we've chosen to live together. A strong personality teaches you to be a strong personality. It doesn't teach you to be a marshmallow, otherwise he's going to get bored very quickly."

Zulawski was reportedly apoplectic when Marceau accepted the role of kittenish villainess Electra King in The World Is Not Enough, considering the role of a Bond woman "beneath her". She now denies any disagreement, before adding the telling caveat: "He never reads my scripts. That's too personal. He has a very strong temper and opinions, so if I want to have an opinion from him, I have to know already what I want."

There is a blankness to Marceau the actress. Though a fluid player, she has none of the gut-given energy of the likes of her contemporary Romane Bohringer. Her on-screen containment is effortless rather than engaging, the reserve thickening for her English-speaking roles. When acting in her native tongue, she has a tendency to be cast in faux amour fou scenarios, playing women who enjoy anonymous, mildly painful sex then yield mistily to manifold psychic agonies or implode with puffy-lipped passion.

She is often offered roles that comprise a male vision of female experience, she admits. "Some of the most beautiful movies about women have been directed and written by men - Bergman, even Zulawski," she begins. (She has only been directed by a woman once in her career. Véra Belmont cast her as the infamous Louis XIV courtesan Marquise du Parque in the 1997 film Marquise. Their relationship was not noted for its ease.)

"But sometimes you have to play somebody more stereotyped," she continues. "I don't think stereotypes are wrong. From something shallow you can really do something," she argues gamely. "If you are able to formulate the way you felt when you first read the script, it's great, because It becomes you, and you are unique."

Her appearance as the girl in Michelangelo Antonioni's Beyond the Clouds in 1995 is arguably one such performance from shallow beginnings. She plays a practically dumb beauty, who bleakly confesses to the murder of her father before seducing the ever insouciant John Malkovich (who "thinks he's really intellectual" according to the tact-free mademoiselle).

"That was only for Antonioni," she says. "You're going to think I'm very snob, but I have such admiration for his work. When I met him, he couldn't talk, he was sitting in a wheelchair, and it was very bizarre not to be able to communicate. (Antonioni suffered a stroke in 1985 which left him aphasic and severely limited in his speech. Wim Wenders collaborated with him to make the film.)

"But I could tell at first sight that he was a director," she states, with the same breathy emphasis that she earlier placed on "woman". "He had a particular grace and light. I didn't like the movie, to be honest, so why? Because I was hypnotised by him, because he's so strong as a director, even though he couldn't talk, like Kaa in The Jungle Book. He could have asked me to do anything ... terrible!" she concludes with relish.

Whether Marceau's other-continental appeal can appease diplomacy-hungry Hollywood remains in the balance. She is clearly uncomfortable with the studio roundelay: "The worst thing is when you have a meeting with a director and he's looking at you like you're the fifth girl he's seen that day. You feel he doesn't understand, you feel terrible afterwards, like you want to go and have a shower." She shudders, delighted by the fact that Universal were "obliged" to take her for the Bond film on the insistence of director Michael Apted, despite their reservations about her bankability.

In her native France, meanwhile, Marceau's status remains stellar. The country offers limitless forgiveness to the woman who, according to a Paris-Match poll, most French men would like to take to bed, despite the fact that she has dismissed its film industry as "too slow, too pretentious", Paris as "insular" and the populace as "more conservative every day". She is a national institution, accompanying the president on an official visit to South Korea, while remaining a billboard regular in varying states of undress.

Nudity, she tells me, is hardly the point. "Sex belongs to life, very much so," she says evenly. "The cinema is to talk about everything, and people have problems talking about sex. It is more difficult for me to talk about sex in my private life than in the movies, but I think it's healthy to talk openly about it because otherwise it can cause pain.

"But technically speaking, love scenes are like any other scenes. They are emotional, and the body is an instrument. So what does the scene mean? Does it mean hate, love, pleasure, rape, what? You are acting something, and I'm not ashamed. Loads of the movies I've done have naked scenes, and there's not one that I think, euh!, I couldn't show it to my son. There is nothing private there. It's acting."

For all her pretty pouts and long-limbed gesturing, there is an essential stillness to Marceau. Through her loose moves she offers watchability, womanliness, sexuality as continuous but contained, displayed rather than given. Her grace does not feel friendly, her presence impacts on the eye alone. Perhaps because the ugly sister of serenity is absence.

There is a quality of a canvas about her. What does beauty do? It creates a distance between the observer and the observed. And in that space we paint her with our fantasies.

 La Fidelite is being shown as part of the Martell French Film Tour which travels to London, Guildford, Exeter, Bristol, Birmingham, Cambridge, Liverpool and York. For details and booking call 0870-50 50 007.
fields.bodyText: Her face remains, long after the charming flesh has bid farewell, returning still and exact to the mind's eye. Sophie Marceau is certainly beautiful. Beneath the misbehaving fringe, her features have the regular perfection that makes babies smile. Her lips are plump and mobile, her olive gaze soft. The thick, glossed hair tempts the fingers. Her skin is vital. But beauty is seldom openly self-aware. Marceau insists that she has no concept of her physical effect. "No, never, because to be honest, I" - she rummages in her bag for a lighter - "I've never really been beautiful. I'm photogenic, which is very important, and now I'm getting older I'm aware I have to take care. I shouldn't smoke." She waves her still unlit cigarette. "I'm transformable, and you can do all sorts of different styles with me." She snakes and flutters her hands around her face. "I can be sexy or I can be not sexy at all. I don't want to be stuck in one thing, because I'm not myself one thing." Nor is 33-year-old Marceau without complexity beyond the surface. A truck driver's daughter from a dreary Parisian suburb, she made her acting debut at 13, in the coming-of-age film La Boum. It branded her on to the national consciousness. One of the few French actresses of her generation to attain international recognition, she has worked the arthouse circuit alongside Antonioni, Wenders, Deneuve and Depardieu as well as shimmering through Mel Gibson's Braveheart and the Bond blockbuster The World Is Not Enough. She is renowned both for her bemusing pensées (she believes that only a woman can play Hamlet properly) and her bluntness. (When Leonardo DiCaprio intimated that he would like to work with her "because she is as hot as it gets", she laughed and told reporters: "He's a child - is he 13? Or 11? Perhaps I could play his nanny.") Her latest movie concerns the complexity of fidelity: to whom are we faithful, and how are we faithful to them? In La Fidélité, her character Clélia wrestles two conflicting connections - the hopeful, nourishing love she shares with her gentle husband and the visceral compulsion that draws her to a troubled, passionate colleague. Her indecision is, unfortunately, as tortuous as the pacing of the film, and ultimately both relationships are destroyed. "You can't pretend you are anything other than human," muses Marceau, "which means being full of contradictions. Life is always unexpected. Clélia has chosen faithfulness, but she is very tormented, and she's very tempted, because she's a woman , because life is full of attractions and easiness. According to the director, she is unfaithful. But I think she is faithful, because physically she is faithful, which is a huge step." Do men and women see physical and emotional fidelity differently? "I wonder if it is deep in the feminine or masculine nature to be that way, or if it is because societies and rules and religions have imposed their way of ordering the world. In the last 50 years women have moved forward so much. If I look at my grandmother - my God! - she had 13 children, she had nothing to say at home, she wasn't happy, but there was no question of adultery or divorce because that wasn't how it was. "Nowadays, we're thinking that women can change partners every week, but is it the reality? Have we really come out from those 800 years behind the stove? We are caught between the temptation of becoming somebody completely free, or trying to keep some of those rules that have been so difficult to live with for such a long time. It's not easy. We are at a crossroads now, and we have to walk with awareness." "The director" who doubts the unfaithful heart is in fact Marceau's partner, and father of her five-year-old son Vincent, namely Polish film-maker Andrzej Zulawski. La Fidélité is their fourth collaboration. They fell in love when she was 18 and he was 42, when he first directed her as a teenage prostitute in L'Amour Braque, a modern interpretation of Dostoyevsky's The Idiot. Although she refers to him as her husband, the pair have never married. She enjoys the familiarity of working with him, she says. "A director has to be a manipulator. It's like an orchestra. If you all play together without someone to give the rhythm, is it quick, is it slow, is it green, is it blue? You get lost. Somebody has to be strong. It's his movie. It's not my movie, it's my part. He loves that." She giggles gleefully. She refers to him by professional title, not personal relationship, and hints at a Pygmalion element to their partnership. "He's a great mentor. He loves to be important in somebody's life, and I think I must too, because we've chosen to live together. A strong personality teaches you to be a strong personality. It doesn't teach you to be a marshmallow, otherwise he's going to get bored very quickly." Zulawski was reportedly apoplectic when Marceau accepted the role of kittenish villainess Electra King in The World Is Not Enough, considering the role of a Bond woman "beneath her". She now denies any disagreement, before adding the telling caveat: "He never reads my scripts. That's too personal. He has a very strong temper and opinions, so if I want to have an opinion from him, I have to know already what I want." There is a blankness to Marceau the actress. "Some of the most beautiful movies about women have been directed and written by men - Bergman, even Zulawski," she begins. (She has only been directed by a woman once in her career. "But sometimes you have to play somebody more stereotyped," she continues. "I don't think stereotypes are wrong. From something shallow you can really do something," she argues gamely. "If you are able to formulate the way you felt when you first read the script, it's great, because It becomes you, and you are unique."
