webTitle: Focus on director Rainer Werner Fassbinder

fields.headline: The director, the theatre and the terrorist
fields.standfirst: Fassbinder is regarded as one of cinema's great precocious talents - yet he served his apprenticeship in the theatre. Now, as his first play is brought to the screen,  Peter Lennon  examines the German film-maker's troubled theatrical years
fields.trailText: Fassbinder is regarded as one of cinema's great precocious talents - yet he served his apprenticeship in the theatre. Now, as his first play is brought to the screen, Peter Lennon examines the German film-maker's troubled theatrical years
fields.body:
By the age of 30, Rainer Werner Fassbinder was already a major figure in European cinema. But the apprenticeship of this man of gargantuan appetites - both artistic and sexual - who had completed more than 40 feature films by the time of his death at 37, was in the theatre. In 1967, he joined Peer Raben's Action Theatre, a feckless group with premises in an old 60-seater cinema in Munich. The precocious 22-year-old quickly took over the direction of the group. His first production was Büchner's Leonce and Lena, in which he also acted.

Now the French director François Ozon has filmed Fassbinder's first play, Water Drops on Burning Rocks, which he wrote at the age of 19. It was not staged until 1985, two years after his death from a drug overdose.

As with any early work by a great talent, the play has been subjected to great scrutiny and an exaggerated amount of respect. In reality, but for the outrageous ending, it is a rather hackeneyed description of a banal domestic relationship - which happens to be homosexual. A young man of artistic leanings is willingly seduced by an older, dominating man and goes to live with him. The older man's interest palls; the young man's fiancée comes to rescue her boy but is willingly seduced by the older man. Then the older man's stricken former wife arrives and reluctantly joins in the orgy.

Ozon tacitly admits the weakness of this piece by reinforcing it with an idea taken from a 1978 Fassbinder film, In a Year of 13 Moons. In Ozon's film, the ex-wife is revealed to be a transsexual who had the operation in the vain hope of holding the interest of her cynical lover. In the original, a man castrates himself because of his obsessive need to conform to society. It was the evils spawned by conformity that obsessed Fassbinder, who regarded it as a plague.

There is ambivalence in Fassbinder's attitude to the exploitation of women. In his 1969 theatrical version of the Bertolt Brecht/John Gay Beggar's Opera (with Fassbinder playing Mack the Knife), he introduced an original song for the prostitutes - Two Dozen Cocks Every Day (That's the Only Way), which could be seen as a bitter indictment of exploitation. But it was claimed that in real life, he persuaded some of the more hopelessly admiring women in his group to "entertain" men to raise funds for his projects.

Perhaps Fassbinder's most significant production of this early period, politically at least, was Axel Caesar Harrmann, an attack on the Springer press, which ruthlessly hounded the left in Germany. An ensemble piece, it was a response to the assassination attempt on Rudi Dutschke, which left the young radical leader permanently incapacitated.

At this time, Fassbinder and his Action Theatre might well have gone down a very different and lethal path. His theatre could be said to have been the cradle of the German terrorist movement of the 60s and 70s. One of its members - or hangers-on - was the subsequently notorious Andreas Baader. Baader, though, is said to have spent most of his time writing political slogans rather than engaging in theatre.

One night in 1967, another member of the group, Horst Söhnlein, was enraged to find on returning from hospital after a car accident that his wife, like many of the company, of both sexes, was having an affair with Fassbinder. He ran amok and wrecked the theatre. Baader had been complaining that what was needed was action, not action theatre and the next night, joined by Baader, Söhnlein set fire to two department stores. American bases followed, and the Baader-Meinhof gang's campaign was underway.

Fassbinder's Danish biographer, Christian Braad Thomsen, maintains that Fassbinder was always against terrorism and that many of his films bear this out. "Fassbinder made some of his most important films from the standpoint that terrorism derives less from a clear political position than from private frustration," he writes. "It was not only a product of the society being fought, but in fact strengthened it."

These themes were already dealt with in his The Burning Village (1970), a stage adaptation of Lope de Vega's Fuente Ovejuna. A village lives under a reign of terror dominated by a commander who murders and rapes. The villagers rebel and capture the commander; the women castrate him and the villagers eat his body. Arrested and brought before the king, the villagers are asked who was resonsible. They reply, "Fuente Ovejuna!" - the name of the village. This expression of solidarity and the impossibility of identifying the murderer persuades the king to let them off. But the rebels attack the court and eat the courtiers. Lope de Vega did not carry it this far, but Fassbinder's message is clear: revolutionaries become as oppressive as their oppressors.

After 18 months, the Action Theatre was no more. The authorities used safety regulations to evict the troupe, although it was clearly their political stance that troubled them. Partly to distance himself from his lethal hangers-on, Fassbinder rechristened his group Antitheater. They were given hospitality in the Büchner theatre, but the tenancy was short-lived. Fassbinder staged Père Ubu, an already notoriously subversive work. But even Alfred Jarry's irreverence was not sufficient for him; he introduced a middle-class family reunion which ends with an orgy. The director of the theatre was so horrified that he turned off the lights in mid-action.

The company then took up residence in the back room of a pub in the Schwabing district of Munich. Finally, in 1974, Fassbinder achieved his ambition to have a theatre of his own. The man recognised as the cultural authority of Frankfurt, Hilmar Hoffmann, invited Fassbinder to become artistic director of the Theater am Turm, Frankfurt's centre for the performing arts. Hoffmann had already offended Fassbinder deeply by turning down his short films for the Oberhausen festival. Conflict was inevitable.

Fassbinder staged a notable Uncle Vanya and Zola's Germinal, but ran into trouble with a production called Garbage, the City and Death, when he was accused - unjustly - of antisemitism. In adapting the novel by Gerhard Zwerenz, Fassbinder carelessly kept the nickname of the villainous landlord who strangles the prostitute heroine - The Rich Jew. The production was stopped and Fassbinder resigned in protest. He later made it into a film, Shadow of Angels.

By this time, Fassbinder was said to have become disillusioned with the stage. He put on one more play for the Hamburg theatre, surprisingly a version of Clare Booth Luce's The Women. He went on to make, among others, The Marriage of Maria Braun, and Berlin-Alexanderplatz, a television series shown in Britain, both widely regarded as masterpieces.

Even in the turmoil of the Antitheatre, he found time to make a critically acclaimed feature film, Love is Colder Than Death. In a time awash with naive notions of art and political liberation, he was fooled neither by the bombast of simplistic radical theatre nor by the utopian illusions of terrorists.

In 1969 he gave the then very fashionable American Living Theatre a rather gentle - for him - comeuppance. He followed Julian Beck and Judith Malina's controversial Paradise Now - a denunciation of the American way of life in which the actors stripped and invited the audience to join them for some hugging on stage - with Preparadise Sorry Now. The original was stopped by the police at the Avignon festival on grounds of indecency. But Fassbinder's complaint was that it was "too religious" - a good enough description of the witless, evangelical level to which the nomadic Living Theatre had sunk by this time.

Fassbinder's version upped the stakes considerably: it offered six murder stories, one featuring Ian Brady and Myra Hindley, pretty strong stuff so close to the revelation of the murders in 1965. It also contained the blasphemous liturgical and cannibalistic elements that featured in much of his theatre work.

Fassbinder was certainly orgiastic and exploitative; he married a couple of his actresses and lived with others, without ever relinquishing his bisexuality. But, unlike Wim Wenders and Volker Schlöndorff, he never went international, preferring to remain a big fish in his own native cesspool.

 Water Drops on Burning Rocks is released on October 6.

webTitle: Six ways to make a scene in a club

fields.headline: Six ways to make a scene in a club
fields.standfirst: As Jason Donovan attempts a comeback with the film Sorted, set in a nightclub.  Jacques Peretti  presents a guide to celluloid clubbing
fields.trailText: As Jason Donovan attempts a comeback with the film Sorted, set in a nightclub. Jacques Peretti presents a guide to celluloid clubbing
fields.body:
From John Schlesinger's Midnight Cowboy to Danny Boyle's Trainspotting, film directors have laboured under two basic misconceptions about the nightclub: (a) that they are remotely glamorous and (b) that they deserve accurate representation on the big screen.

Strange as it may seem, the first rule of filming a nightclub scene is to make it as wholly inaccurate as possible. Real nightclubs are large Asda-style sheds, packed with blotchy, incoherent teenagers falling into one another. Who, save a few Harmony Korine fans, is going to want to watch that?

Because nightclub scenes in films long ago surrendered any notion of reality, they've formed a parallel universe of their own, where LA punks burn oil drums in warehouses, jazz bars drip girls from every furnishing, and raves are crammed with beautiful fashionistas, punching the air to a cameo from Judge Jules. From Casablanca to The Matrix, nightclub scenes have come to form a body of work in their own right - one which refers back to its own lineage rather than anything approximating reality, and can be enjoyed for the ludicrous fantasy world it is.

The Citizen Kane of club scenes is Basic Instinct, in which Michael Douglas, playing an Andrew Neil-lookalike in V-neck jumper and no shirt (a sweaty fashion detail signifying middle-aged man smelling out sex) watches Sharon Stone, who taunts his manhood by indulging in a faux-lesbian sex dance.

The sequence is tragic in about 57 specific ways yet it comes across as one of the most enjoyable club scenes of all time. It captures the dripping seediness and sexual frisson of a cheap venue like few other movies, and is truer to the cold, calculating desperation of the solitary punter than the raft-full of arm-waving rave movies.

Basic Instinct is true to the spirit of clubs, rather than hung-up on details of cool. In this respect, its effect - even more so than the out-and-out spoof, Austin Powers - is less ridiculous than a serious stab at 70s vérité like 54 or Velvet Goldmine, both of which came across as bad school plays. When Powers enters a club, he quotes from Russ Meyer's Beyond the Valley of the Dolls: "This is my scene and it's freaking me out." A homage to an era of groovy film-making that spoofed itself to begin with.

Like Austin Powers, Larry Clark's Kids acknowledged its cinematic lineage by retelling the Saturday Night Fever story 20 years on. In Clark's New York, nothing has changed - the club scene is still dominated by the snobbery and racism of "Bridge and Tunnel" (the derogatory term used for kids from Brooklyn and Queens who must travel over bridge and down tunnel to reach the forbidding red ropes of Manhattan's glittering clubs).

British rave films took the notion of the peripheral nightclub scene and made it the whole reason for the movie. Instead of the timeless naff of Basic Instinct, the Po-Mo kitsch of Austin Powers or the muffled punches of Mean Streets, rave films tried to be down wit' da kidz.

Rave films are essentially the same as 50s monster B-movies, selling themselves as "Most Realistic Scenes Yet Seen!!!" Attempting to portray a club as chemical assault has proved, however, as futile as attempting to make a rubber monster scarier by issuing the audience with a pair of 3-D specs.

Jason Donovan's comeback film, Sorted, is unintentionally as camp as Austin Powers. But while it's easy to laugh at the casting, Donovan is undoubtedly the Dennis Hopper of rave - with a permanent 1,000-yard stare induced by over-exposure to Joseph's multi-coloured dreamcoat no doubt. Rave films have turned into our latest form of costume drama, trading on the club scene in the same way that the English tourist board trade on Jane Austen. Sorted is a fine addition to this body of work, and as such will surely be savoured on video for years to come.

The frat party

Typical scene: Young Tom Cruise organises an impromptu brothel in the middle of high school frat party. Jocks drink Bud through a dirty pair of underpants as Molly Ringwald-wallflower-types throw up on the best friend's shoes.

Typical dialogue: "Hey guys, you wanna see me blow a bottle of Bud outta my ass?"

Distinguishing traits: Grim cloakroom sex and a chance to see Kid'n'Play showing the white kids how to get down.

Key movies: Risky Business; House Party; Weird Science.

Reality rating: (sadly) 10/10

The Studio 54 revival club

Typical scene: Slightly too clean 999-style reconstruction of disco's glory days. Gratuitous use of period drugs by girls in Wonder Woman hotpants and men with helmet hairdos.

Typical dialogue: "I've just seen Bianca shooting up in the toilets and Andy's real mad that Truman's not talking to him."

Traits: Crowbarred wrongish references to era: "My God, have you heard? Bobby Kennedy's been shot"; "You look just like Mork & Mindy."

Key movies: 54; Velvet Goldmine; Last Days of Disco; Boogie Nights.

Reality rating: 5/10

The British rave club

Typical scene: First person voice-over, describing "rush" of entering club with people clapping hands and clasping water bottles (translation: they've taken drugs!!!) Rubbish tie-in soundtrack record by Underworld/Leftfield "kicks in" and girl puts hand on narrator's shoulder (with Celtic rune tattoo).

Typical dialogue: Any 1992 club argot welcome: "Quick, put the drugs in your shoe. It's all gone Pete Tong."

Traits: Characters called Muppet, Smurf, Apple etc. Jokey post-club low-jinks involving tying to lampposts, shooting air-rifles.

Key movies: Human Traffic; Sorted.

Reality rating: 1/10

The 80s Dirty Dancing club

Typical scene: Two girls in stretchy mid-80s Azzedine Alaia skirts dance erotically on a sparsely attended dancefloor. The camera watches them through mesh fencing, broken by shards of steely blue light.

Typical dialogue: "I want you and your friend to perform for me on my yacht."

Traits: Clubs called Electrik Dreamz or Techno Box and the girls should be dancing to Hollywood's idea of the ultimate street-tough soundtrack - INXS or Will Smith.

Key films: Basic Instinct; Frantic; Showgirls.

Reality rating: 10/10

The club in the middle of a pyrotechnic chase

Typical scene: Liquid, transmutating cyborg rides motorbike through plate-glass window of nightclub and must push aside LA punks in Toyah-era haircuts to reach heroine.

Typical dialogue: Annoying skatepunk to Arnie: "Hey, what's your problem, maaaan?" (followed by satisfying killer punch).

Traits: Hatred of alternative haircuts and basic ethos that all nightclub freaks are effeminate and unable to fight cyborgs.

Key films: The Terminator; Star Wars.

Reality rating: 0/10

The grim club

Typical scene: Black Lace perform their novelty hit, Gang Bang, as men in egg-stained suits simulate anal sex with bored girls balancing empty beer glasses. Alternatively, paraplegic Vietnam vet wheels around the dancefloor wielding a pool cue at able-bodied rednecks. As depressing as 12 bottles of vodka drunk alone in the car park.

Typical dialogue: "Fancy a blow-job in my Montego? I've got cash."

Traits: Gallows humour, a small town in Wales, chips stuffed into knickers, angry existential ranting from troubled souls in over-tight Kris Kristofferson denim shirts.

Key films: Rita, Sue & Bob Too; Born on the Fourth of July.

Reality rating: 10/10
fields.bodyText: From John Schlesinger's Midnight Cowboy to Danny Boyle's Trainspotting, film directors have laboured under two basic misconceptions about the nightclub: (a) that they are remotely glamorous and (b) that they deserve accurate representation on the big screen. Strange as it may seem, the first rule of filming a nightclub scene is to make it as wholly inaccurate as possible. Real nightclubs are large Asda-style sheds, packed with blotchy, incoherent teenagers falling into one another. Who, save a few Harmony Korine fans, is going to want to watch that? Because nightclub scenes in films long ago surrendered any notion of reality, they've formed a parallel universe of their own, where LA punks burn oil drums in warehouses, jazz bars drip girls from every furnishing, and raves are crammed with beautiful fashionistas, punching the air to a cameo from Judge Jules. From Casablanca to The Matrix, nightclub scenes have come to form a body of work in their own right - one which refers back to its own lineage rather than anything approximating reality, and can be enjoyed for the ludicrous fantasy world it is. The Citizen Kane of club scenes is Basic Instinct, in which Michael Douglas, playing an Andrew Neil-lookalike in V-neck jumper and no shirt (a sweaty fashion detail signifying middle-aged man smelling out sex) watches Sharon Stone, who taunts his manhood by indulging in a faux-lesbian sex dance. The sequence is tragic in about 57 specific ways yet it comes across as one of the most enjoyable club scenes of all time. It captures the dripping seediness and sexual frisson of a cheap venue like few other movies, and is truer to the cold, calculating desperation of the solitary punter than the raft-full of arm-waving rave movies. Basic Instinct is true to the spirit of clubs, rather than hung-up on details of cool. In this respect, its effect - even more so than the out-and-out spoof, Austin Powers - is less ridiculous than a serious stab at 70s vérité like 54 or Velvet Goldmine, both of which came across as bad school plays. When Powers enters a club, he quotes from Russ Meyer's Beyond the Valley of the Dolls: "This is my scene and it's freaking me out." A homage to an era of groovy film-making that spoofed itself to begin with. Like Austin Powers, Larry Clark's Kids acknowledged its cinematic lineage by retelling the Saturday Night Fever story 20 years on. In Clark's New York, nothing has changed - the club scene is still dominated by the snobbery and racism of "Bridge and Tunnel" (the derogatory term used for kids from Brooklyn and Queens who must travel over bridge and down tunnel to reach the forbidding red ropes of Manhattan's glittering clubs). British rave films took the notion of the peripheral nightclub scene and made it the whole reason for the movie. Instead of the timeless naff of Basic Instinct, the Po-Mo kitsch of Austin Powers or the muffled punches of Mean Streets, rave films tried to be down wit' da kidz. Rave films are essentially the same as 50s monster B-movies, selling themselves as "Most Realistic Scenes Yet Seen!!!" Attempting to portray a club as chemical assault has proved, however, as futile as attempting to make a rubber monster scarier by issuing the audience with a pair of 3-D specs. Jason Donovan's comeback film, Sorted, is unintentionally as camp as Austin Powers. But while it's easy to laugh at the casting, Donovan is undoubtedly the Dennis Hopper of rave - with a permanent 1,000-yard stare induced by over-exposure to Joseph's multi-coloured dreamcoat no doubt. Rave films have turned into our latest form of costume drama, trading on the club scene in the same way that the English tourist board trade on Jane Austen. Sorted is a fine addition to this body of work, and as such will surely be savoured on video for years to come. webTitle: Jeremy Rifkin, Jeramiah of the global economy

fields.headline: This leading American business guru claims these trainers could spell the end of capitalism. Can he be serious?
fields.standfirst: Julian Borger  on Jeremy Rifkin, Jeramiah of the global economy
fields.trailText: Julian Borger on Jeremy Rifkin, Jeramiah of the global economy.
fields.body:
Not many people look at the recent rise in car-leasing or fusion music and see a threat to civilisation, but Jeremy Rifkin does. Then again, he also believes that the 21st century - this apparently booming era - will witness the decline and fall of market-based capitalism.

These are the sort of jeremiads normally voiced by shaggy, wild-eyed men touting hand-painted omens of doom. But Rifkin, America's best-known techno-sceptic, is speaking from the very heart of the capitalist system.

He does not look like a seer. He is a bald middle-aged man in a suit and tie. The only remaining hint of his days as a Vietnam-era peace activist is a greying moustache. Rifkin is now a fellow at Wharton, the most prestigious business school in the US, probably the world - a temple, bar none, to the power of market forces. And he spends much of his working life counselling the chief executives of corporate America.

Yet the 55-year-old academic and professional visionary has emerged as a lonely voice on the US intellectual stage, cautioning the west against its eager embrace of bio-technology. His single-minded struggle against powerful biotech giants such as Monsanto has made him some powerful enemies, and he has been dismissed as a publicity-conscious Luddite. But many of his early warnings now appear prophetic.

He campaigned successfully for better hygiene laws governing the handling of meat and poultry in the US, long before food safety became a international front-page issue. And 13 years ago, he raised the alarm over an obscure decision by the US patent office to grant corporate proprietary rights over certain human genes, paving the way for the current ethical dilemmas swirling around the biotech industry. He has appeared regularly before Congress, and flew to France last year to bolster the French government's resistance to the import of genetically modified (GM) foods.

Now Rifkin is raising a new spectre. His latest book, The Age of Access, (published in Britain this week), examines current trends in the way we live and do business, and extrapolates from them into the future. He comes up with some surprising conclusions.

This is Rifkin's theory: With the spread of the internet and e-commerce, markets and lifestyles in the western world are accelerating to such an extent that they are triggering a fundamental change in our economic system. The ownership of physical property, which was once the bulwark of capitalism has become a burden to businesses and individuals alike, a liability rather than an asset.

Consumers increasingly prefer to lease rather than buy big items such as cars, so they can continually upgrade them and avoid the pitfalls and responsibilities of ownership.

Businesses meanwhile are finding there is less and less of a profit margin in selling things. Rather than a one-off transaction lasting minutes or seconds, they want to establish a life-long relationship with you, providing the car (or the lawnmower, the computer, the telephone or even the house) on a lease basis as an introductory transaction in a long stream of related goods and services.

"Ford would rather never sell you a car again," Rifkin argues. "It would rather put you in its network, so that you continually buy the experience of driving rather than buying the vehicle. And the proof is in the pudding. The renewal rate on leasing is 54%. The renewal rate in market-based transactions is 25%."

Eighty per cent of US companies are now leasing some or all equipment rather than investing in ownership. Whereas old-style companies, such as General Motors, owned a lot of solid assets, the new industrial icons, such as Nike, own hardly anything in physical terms, yet Nike is priced much higher on the New York stock exchange. Its production is "outsourced" - carried out by "partners" in the developing world. Rifkin describes it as a "virtual company". Its assets are almost entirely cerebral - it is selling a concept and a lifestyle, and in this new economy those are valued far above factories and headquarters.

In capitalist markets, buyers and sellers come together to exchange property, but in this new system ownership does not change hands. Instead, users pay for access to experiences from suppliers. In place of markets, there are networks - arrays of companies supplying any experience you could wish for and supplying access to it in the form of subscriptions, leases, or membership schemes.

From his suite of offices in downtown Washington, the prophet of the Age of Access is forecasting nothingless than the demise of the market as we know it

"What I'm suggesting in this book is eventually the nature of this technological revolution is leading us into an era where, by the mid part of the 21st century, market capitalism will have virtually disappeared," Rifkin argued in an interview. "It will be there, but it will be only an appendage to a new network-based economy with access relations replacing property relations."

The problem with this brave new world is that with all this packaging of lifestyles and experiences, pretty soon every part of our daily existence, once rooted in family or community, becomes a commodity that is sold back to us.

Imagine, Rifkin says: "You find virtually every activity you engage inside the family and outside the family is a paid-for commercial activity. We are commodified. We're moving from commodifying goods and services to comodifying culture."

This is where the "fusion" music comes in. Just as the multinational giants of the 19th and 20th centuries scoured the planet for mineral wealth and cash crops, today's mega-corporations - AOL-Time Warner, Disney and the like - go searching for culture to mine and turn into easily digestible experiences for their users to access. Thus "ethnic" music from around the world is sampled and fused with rock and pop and turned into "fusion", making it accessible while tearing it from the roots from its culture.

"One of the messages here is that it's just as possible to deplete cultural diversity as it is biological diversity and physical resources. When you take a culture and homogenise it, transform it, package it and sell it back to people as a paid-for experience, then it is just as possible to deplete cultural diversity as biodiversity," Rifkin argues. "And when you lose a culture to extinction it's just as final, you cannot get it back."

In the cultural vacuum which results, fundamentalism blooms. In Rifkin's view, Blair and his fellow travellers along the third way have failed to see the threat because of their materialist outlook on life.

"Third way politics thinks that if you can build a healthy economy which is compassionate, you'll build a healthy society. My position in this book is that they are wrong from the get-go, because commerce never precedes culture, culture always precedes commerce."

Rifkin's remedy is to pay more attention to fostering culture, particularly local culture, by promoting community-based education in an attempt to provide children with a deeper understanding of the world than computer screens alone can provide.

The arguments are taut and provocative, but are they sane? Is our way of life really under threat because we decide to lease rather than buy. The book has received some harsh criticism at the hands of US journalists, who portray Rifkin as an overblown Cassandra, predicting the end of the world as we know it at every half-opportunity.

His last book but one was called The End of Work, in which Rifkin, in characteristic apocalyptic style, predicted that manufacturing would become "near-workerless" in the near future, with the explosive growth in automation. Since the book was published in 1995, however, US unemployment has fallen significantly.

Rifkin insists he did not get it wrong. In a somewhat defensive revised introduction to The End of Work, he points out that the US labour department has massaged the figures, that 2% of the adult male workforce is currently in prison and that the US has been able to keep its boom going artificially through the use of cheap credit.

He has also come under fire from the left for focusing on the dilemmas of the wealthy world, for talking about the Age of Access when, as Rifkin himself points out, 62% of the world's population have never even made a telephone call. Rifkin points out, however, that he is simply examining the markets which matter to big business. Would it have been wrong to study the first stirrings of the industrial revolution in the English Midlands because it was not a worldwide phenomenon?

Rifkin does seem to ignore or at least play down trends which con flict with his central theory - like the growth in ownership of homes and securities among the burgeoning middle classes. In some ways the desire to own is clearly deepening rather than eroding.

However, he is pointing to significant changes in the way our economic system operates.

A quick glance at prices on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq index will demonstrate the increasing importance of intangible, cerebral assets over physical capital. When Steven Spielberg's company, DreamWorks SKG opened for business it owned practically nothing other than the talent of its founders but its stock was valued instantly at $2bn.

Meanwhile on the land, US farmers are no longer buying seeds but effectively leasing them from "life-science" companies which own the patent on the crops' very DNA. Once the first harvest is in, the farmers have no ownership rights over the seeds, which remain the intellectual property of the biotech firm and its commercial network which will typically supply the farmers with pesticide, weedkiller and fertiliser. It is arguably the most radical change to hit agriculture since the stone age.

With the use of patents, commercial networks in Rifkin's Age of Access can potentially exercise far more control than old-fashioned monopolies in the age of production, and the current anti-trust laws - drawn up in a bygone era - are ill-equipped to regulate them.

In the end the threat of that scale of economic dominance - wielded by biotech companies such as Monsanto, or entertainment conglomerates like AOL-Time Warner - may turn out to be far more potent than Rifkin's warnings about vehicle-leasing and "fusion" music.

You can order a copy of The Age of Access by Jeremy Rifkin (Penguin, £20) at the discounted price of £17 plus 99p p&p by calling the Guardian Culture Shop on 0800 316 6102.

webTitle: The best creative process scene: Hollow Man

fields.headline: The best creative process scene: Hollow Man
fields.trailText: A bedroom. Night. Illuminated by the glow from his monitor, Sebastian Caine (Kevin Bacon) sits before his computer. On screen is an image of a string of DNA. He taps a few keys; the DNA begins to fall apart. Sebastian unwraps a Twinkie, takes a bite, hits some more keys. Once again, the DNA unravels.
fields.body:
A bedroom. Night. Illuminated by the glow from his monitor, Sebastian Caine (Kevin Bacon) sits before his computer. On screen is an image of a string of DNA. He taps a few keys; the DNA begins to fall apart. Sebastian unwraps a Twinkie, takes a bite, hits some more keys. Once again, the DNA unravels.

"Dammit."

He leans back in his chair, rubbing his eyes. As he stares at the ceiling we see a message painted on it in red capital letters:

YOU SHOULD BE WORKING.

He peers blearily at his computer, then continues to type. Panning to his alarm clock we see what time it is - 4 am. Sebastian paces the room, then returns to the computer. He hits yet more keys. The DNA reforms on his screen. Sebastian's brow furrows as he gazes at the screen. More typing. He stands, watching the screen. A smile spreads across his face.

"I am a goddamn genius!"

Striking the keyboard again, a telephone keypad appears on screen. He dials a number.

Cut to another bedroom. A digital phone attached to a computer starts to ring. Linda Foster (Elisabeth Shue) struggles out of bed. She reaches the computer, then clicks on her keyboard. The ringing stops. Her monitor comes to life, and Sebastian's face appears on screen. Her voice is weary.

"Sebastian, do you know what time it is?"

He leans back in his chair again, this time grinning triumphantly.

"You know Da Vinci never slept. Said it was a waste of time."

See also: Barton Fink, Lust For Life, The Rebel, The Shining.

Don't see also: The Muse.

Pointless trivia: Hollow Man director Paul Verhoeven holds a university degree in maths and physics.

As he stares at the ceiling we see a message painted on it in red capital letters: YOU SHOULD BE WORKING. He peers blearily at his computer, then continues to type. Panning to his alarm clock we see what time it is - 4 am. Sebastian paces the room, then returns to the computer. He hits yet more keys. The DNA reforms on his screen. Sebastian's brow furrows as he gazes at the screen. More typing. He stands, watching the screen. A smile spreads across his face. "I am a goddamn genius!" Striking the keyboard again, a telephone keypad appears on screen. He dials a number. Cut to another bedroom. A digital phone attached to a computer starts to ring. Linda Foster (Elisabeth Shue) struggles out of bed. She reaches the computer, then clicks on her keyboard. The ringing stops. Her monitor comes to life, and Sebastian's face appears on screen. Her voice is weary. "Sebastian, do you know what time it is?" He leans back in his chair again, this time grinning triumphantly. "You know Da Vinci never slept. Said it was a waste of time." See also: Barton Fink, Lust For Life, The Rebel, The Shining. Don't see also: The Muse. Pointless trivia: Hollow Man director Paul Verhoeven holds a university degree in maths and physics.

fields.headline: Stuck in reverse
fields.standfirst: Jan Michael Vincent: Hollywood's most indefatigable drunk | Bankrupt Anna hits back | King's grief for van driver | Sweet smell gone sour

fields.body:
What year is it anyway? 2000 or 1973? It was a little hard to tell from last weekend's box office receipts. The two most successful movies - The Exorcist and Almost Famous - were originally released and retrospectively set in the year that Opec fuel price rises put a sudden end to the longest economic boom in history (hey, wait a minute...), a year characterised by global political unrest and a sense that our elected leaders were either totally clueless or totally corrupt.

Turned out they were both. So, give or take the intervening invention of the VCR, the DVD, the microchip and all its satanic progeny, the bottomless depths of public cynicism that currently afflict the political process and the absence of the Vietnam war, and it's easy to understand how those of us with longer memories - those of us who only watched the Nixon funeral to make absolutely sure he was dead - might start getting confused.

The Exorcist - which made $165m on its original release - was wheeled out in a slightly doctored form and hoovered up a very tasty $12m, with a per-screen average that spelled packed house. The posters and the ad campaign both refer breathlessly to "the version you've never seen" because director William Friedkin - or perhaps Warner Bros - has finally agreed to incorporate scenes, removed from the release version, that Catholic writer William Peter Blatty insisted lent the story a more spiritual, humanising tone, but which the Jewish Friedkin felt slowed things down in dramatic terms.

So this is not so much the director's cut as the writer's version, although Friedkin supervised the new assembly. With his own career currently in a holding pattern that suggests the perils of being married to the head of the studio (in his case, glammy Paramount chief Sherry Lansing), Friedkin has decided to back down over matters he didn't seem interested in at the time of 1998's 25th anniversary restoration. One wonders if the addition of the Blatty scenes - the best of which is a shot of Linda Blair doing a bent-spine backwards crabwalk down a flight of stairs - isn't just a matter of the studio gilding the re-released lily for all it's worth.

I have problems with the whole notion of the "director's cut". Apart from its sense of a totally coherent, fully realised future environment, I never much liked Blade Runner, no matter what Ridley Scott did to improve it. The original was both clarified and muddied by Harrison Ford's lugubrious film noir voiceover. Yet the narration did clarify things and when it was removed for the reissue, parts of the movie became incoherent unless you'd already seen the original - now, as part of the resale process, downgraded to "flawed masterpiece ", the better to convince us we were getting more bang for our now twice-spent dollar.

Similarly with Sam Peckinpah's Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid, which was butchered by the head of MGM in an undisguised act of animosity toward the famously truculent director. The re-release also removed moments that were among the best in the original version, leading critic Paul Seydor to suggest that whatever it was, it wasn't "Peckinpah's version", not least because the director himself was now six feet under.

Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid was also released in 1973, which tends to inhibit nostalgia for the studios of the period. That's not something likely to deter Cameron Crowe, whose semi-autobiographical Almost Famous recreates the summer of that year, when the 15-year-old Crowe did his first assignments for Rolling Stone magazine, which had no idea of his tender age. As with all of Crowe's movies, it's not until after you've left the movie house that you begin to realise all the emotional manipulations you've been subjected to, and how Crowe's slickness - and, I think, emotional dishonesty - have managed to trick you.

Almost Famous is less culpable in this regard than Jerry Maguire, but thinking of 1973 and witnessing the Exorcist's renewed success, one starts wishing they'd just suspend the entire studio production schedule and re-release all the great lost movies of that period, like Monte Hellman's Cockfighter, Arthur Penn's Night Moves, Ivan Passer's Cutter's Way and Karel Reisz's Who'll Stop The Rain. And if the writers' actors' and directors' strikes all kick in over the next year and production does dry up and lead to blank screens then, God knows, we might see it happen yet.

Jan Michael Vincent: Hollywood's most indefatigable drunk

That list of celebrity party-boys who become celebrity jailbirds just keeps growing. We've had poor, blitzed Robert Downey Jr, who celebrated his recent release by taking a job on Ally McBeal. Then there was Christian Slater, who bit a cop who was trying to arrest the errant actor for drunkenly hitting his wife. Charlie Sheen is infamous for his hop-headed, bed-hopping shenanigans (his probation is administered by the same exasperated Malibu judge who jailed Downey) and ageing pretty boy Rick Springfield was recently charged with knocking his missus about. None of them however, can hold a candle to Hollywood's most indefatigable drunk, Jan Michael Vincent, whose 25-year-old battle with the hop and the grape has, perhaps inevitably, now landed the gin-blossomed former Airwolf star in chokey.

One can see Vincent's entire decline mapped out in John Milius's Nietzschean 1978 surfer movie Big Wednesday, in which Vincent - already a major booze ghoul - played a legendary surfer who's an alcoholic before he leaves his teens.

His incarceration stems from repeated violations of his probation on previous charges of public drunkenness and domestic violence. Having been found rolling around incoherently on a sidewalk in Santa Monica in January, Vincent was faced with six months inside; he was then arrested for pulling his long-suffering wife's hair and pushing her about, making his 60-day sentence inevitable.

Vincent broke his neck in a drunken 1996 car wreck and then sued the paramedics who'd saved his life but damaged his vocal cords (his voice is now just a rasp).

He'd also faced charges of kicking one girlfriend in the stomach when she was pregnant. He'll go directly from his live-in detox mansion to the Big House, where his now hideously addled looks will no doubt prove a useful deterrent to predators in the showers.

Bankrupt Anna hits back

"This is not about a gold-digger sucking money. This is about a relationship that was very profound." Pardon me for smirking at these words from the attorney who is helping bankrupt Playboy centrefold Anna Nicole Smith to contest the will of her late oil billionaire husband Howard Marshall. Smith was a 26-year-old stripper when she was courted by the octogenarian. She claims she lived in wedded bliss for 14 months before his death, aged 90, in August 1995, and that he promised her half of his fortune, estimated at between $60m and $1.6bn. She got nothing. Smith is broke after losing $850,000 in a sexual harassment case brought by a former female assistant.

King's grief for van driver

Stephen King expressed sadness this week about the death of the man who accidentally ran him over last year and nearly killed the writer - in a scenario that eerily resembled the opening of his novel Misery. King had been gently critical of the decision not to jail Smith or revoke his licence after the accident, but later contented himself with buying Smith's wrecked van and promptly destroying it with a sledge-hammer once he was fit. An autopsy was unable to determine the cause of death.

Sweet smell gone sour

And a tiny titbit for fans of the classic 1958 Burt Lancaster-Tony Curtis movie Sweet Smell of Success, in which Lancaster plays a powerful Broadway columnist who has a semi-incestuous relationship with his sister, played by the otherwise unknown actress Susan Harrison. Harrison turns out to be the mother of Darva Conger, who helped the Fox network plumb new depths of tastelessness when she won a husband on the special Who Wants To Marry A Millionaire? She divorced him almost immediately after he was accused of beating up an ex-girlfriend. Conger then stripped for Hef, and is now said to be dating TV scandal-monger and possible NYC mayoral candidate Geraldo Rivera. Maybe John Cusack will put her in his Sweet Smell remake.

fields.headline: julien donkey-boy
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a clever, agile, provocative movie in which the director displays his crisply refrigerated connoisseurship of human dysfunction and pain
fields.body:
One of Harmony Korine's most compelling works has been as a segment director on a recent David Blaine TV special capturing the great close-up magician as he freaks out a succession of trailer-park denizens, New York cops, South American tribesmen, and Port-au-Prince voodoo enthuasiasts. Korine's flair for assembling miscellaneous moments of disorientation and astonishment is apparent in julien donkey-boy, his follow-up to the controversial Gummo. This is a clever, agile, provocative movie in which the director displays his crisply refrigerated connoisseurship of human dysfunction and pain.

Conceived in accordance with the Dogme 95 rules, this is about a bizarre family living in Queens, New York, of whom the most egregiously weird is the father, memorably played by Werner Herzog. He is a widower and psychopathic tyrant who reviles his son Chris (Evan Neuman) for not being "man" enough. Chloë Sevigny is Chris's listless, heavily pregnant sister and Ewen Bremner is Julien himself, a schizophrenic who has nevertheless somehow been entrusted with the job of looking after blind people. Korine directs his ostentatiously grotesque ensemble with panache, but it is never clear if they are plausible human beings or an elaborate series of images of the sort Diane Arbus or Joel-Peter Witkin might photograph - and the stomach-turning moments of violence and horror that top and tail the film cannot by themselves endow what happens in between with meaning or dramatic depth.

What gives the film real substance, however, is the wonderfully fastidious, imperious presence of Werner Herzog himself, growling at his shrugging, slack-jawed offspring at the dinner-table, and regaling them with his anecdotes about Clint Eastwood and Leonid Brezhnev. It's Herzog who shores up this movie's implicit claims to tragicomedy.

fields.headline: Billy Elliot
fields.standfirst: Stephen Daldry's switch to the screen brings us an invigorating and surprising tale about a ballet-dancing boy, writes  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a film with a lot of charm, a lot of humour and a lot of heart
fields.body:
From somewhere on a spectrum between Kes and How Green Was My Valley, the British stage director Stephen Daldry brings us Billy Elliot, his screen debut. This is a bold, attractive and emotionally generous film about a young boy growing up in the north-east during the miners' strike of 1984-85, who discovers in himself a talent for dance. And - to the horror of his striking miner father, played by the perennially excellent Gary Lewis - this is not even the virile and masculine dance of Gene Kelly. It is ballet: mincing, prancing, flouncing tutu-wearing ballet, and young Billy (Jamie Bell) has to work on his pliés along with all the girlies in a church hall where Dad sends him every week with his 50p sub in his hot little hand on the understanding that he is learning how to box.

This is a film with a lot of charm, a lot of humour and a lot of heart. Daldry's direction and the screenplay by Lee Hall (who wrote the radio drama hit Spoonface Steinberg) distinguish themselves further in the discreet, intelligent way they deal with the question of Billy's nascent sexuality, avoiding vulgarity and prurience. The young male ballet dancer is not a stereotype, and yet the film certainly does not feel it necessary to reassure the audience that Billy is straight; for my money, that's part of this picture's liberal humanity.

Billy finds himself in his embarrassing predicament when he is perpetually having the living daylights knocked out of him in the ring, unhappily wearing the seedy old boxing gloves that were once the property of his grandfather. Something in him responds to the sight of the ballet class in the opposite corner. He joins in, coming under the wing of the teacher, Mrs Wilkinson, played by Julie Walters, who in some ways is playing a version of the Michael Caine role in Educating Rita. She sees that dance, with its soaring language of the human spirit, might be Billy's ticket out of here.

In Billy Elliot, dance is at once an expression of yearning, and a symptom of frustration; Mrs Wilkinson is described as "unfulfilled - that's why she does dancing!" Julie Walters could so easily have given an over-egged and gamey performance as the gutsy mentor, and it is a measure of her intelligence as a performer and Daldry's assurance as a director, that her approach is kept within bounds. There is a very good sequence where she and Billy do a dance routine that she has devised for him to I Love to Boogie by T Rex: and this scene nicely complements a later moment where Billy does his own dance of rage in the street when his Dad forbids him to dance again.

It is a spontaneous choreography of frustration, which hovers between the world of realistic drama and the stylised world of the musical. But the action of Billy Elliot deepens as his father, at first infuriated, comes to accept his son's talent, and that some money must be found to enable him to audition for the Royal Ballet School. With a terrible clarity, it dawns on him that this means breaking the strike, and joining the cowering blacklegs who are bussed in through the picket lines every morning.

So from questioning his ballet-loving son's masculinity, Billy's dad arrives at his own male crisis. The use of the strike is very studied: the period of Billy's first timid dance steps to his fateful audition covers the strike period almost exactly. By casting this momentous and traumatic event in British history as a backdrop to a young boy's growing pains, Daldry is, arguably, open to the charge of sentimentalising intractable political issues - and from a feminist perspective, there is not much to cheer about in the story of a boy who turns out to be much better than all the girls, and entirely monopolises his teacher's attention.

Occasionally, the background furniture is pedantic, and a little baffling. Along with T Rex, we have a Ker-Plunk under Billy's bed and the inevitable Spacehopper - all shorthand for the 70s, rather than the 80s. But the incidental details are sketched in with flair and wit: there's a nice moment when Mrs Wilkinson's daughter Debbie is sauntering with Billy down the street and idly bangs a stick along the row of policemen's perspex riot shields, like railings. It couldn't happen in real life - but it's such a funny and surreal moment, of a piece with Daldry's amiable and buoyant direction. Billy Elliot has a freshness that makes it a pleasure to watch; it's a very emphatic success.

fields.headline: Angry islanders bury their dead
fields.standfirst: Grief turns to fury on Paros as rumours fly over cause of ferry sinking that killed 65
fields.trailText: They wanted to focus on the living but the islanders of Paros could not forget the dead yesterday, as helicopters shuttled corpses from the morgue and divers searched the ferry that has become a tomb.
fields.body:
They wanted to focus on the living but the islanders of Paros could not forget the dead yesterday, as helicopters shuttled corpses from the morgue and divers searched the ferry that has become a tomb.

Church bells tolled for the first funerals - all but one of the 65 dead were thought to be Greek - while queues formed to donate clothes and food to survivors. In Athens the prime minister, Costas Simitis, held an emergency cabinet meeting to review the disaster but for some families in Paros it was too late.

Grief hardened to rage as crew members of the Express Samina, which sank after smashing into a rocky islet on Tuesday night, emerged from local hotels. Around 20 survivors, who had gathered at the port authority to sift through personal effects recovered after the accident, stiffened when a sailor joined them.

Seizing an orange life-jacket, a man rammed it over the sailor's head and tied the cords. "This is how you put on a life jacket," he shouted. Only the crashing of Aegean waves broke the ensuing silence.

The crew members have been accused of abandoning the Express Samina's estimated 530 passengers to panic and chaos after rocks sliced through the underside of the vessel, virtually cutting it in half.

At least 10 locals are thought to be among the dead and 2,000 islanders gathered for the funeral of two of their own yesterday, a father and his five-year-old son. The mother survived.

Another service was held on the island for its coastguard Dimitris Malamas, 43, who died of a heart attack when he heard news of the sinking. Hundreds gathered in the main cathedral as ships in the harbour blew their horns.

Women in black dresses and men wearing black armbands clustered in whitewashed lanes to comfort the bereaved and exchange rumours about the captain of the stricken ferry, Vassilis Yannakis.

His failure to avoid the rocks, two miles offshore, remained a mystery. Had a rookie helmsman been left alone on the bridge so the officers could watch a football match? No one knew for sure.

A vigil was kept on the authority office, as islanders waited for the captain, who was sequestered in the port authority, and four colleagues to be moved to the nearby island of Syros to be formally charged with manslaughter. One was later released. Witnesses later saw the other four being moved in a patrol boat.

A prosecutor said Captain Yiannakis, who banged his head in the accident, claimed to be unable to remember anything, though he denied the charges. "He curls up and insists on sleeping all the time," said the prosecutor.

A crewman said the 53-year-old captain, denounced in the Greek media, had been traduced. "I've sailed with him for 20 years. He's one of the oldest captains in the Aegean and he's one of the best. He knows these seas like the back of his hand. The map is in his head."

Louis van Wyk, a 26-year-old South African with a bandaged head, was less forgiving. "No one helped us. We were left to fend for ourselves. The captain must think of all the people that didn't make it. I hope he can bear his conscience."

As he spoke a media scrum formed around Lisa Torrance, 28, of Glasgow, as she began to weep. "It was hell on earth. There were dead bodies floating past us, it was awful."

Gale-force winds have cut ferry services and left most survivors stranded until the weekend. Some of them held a sombre meeting at the Argonauta restaurant to exchange experiences. Sigrid Kindt, a local volunteer, said they appeared less traumatised than on Wednesday. "Some are psychologically very distressed but most seem in better shape."

There are thought to have been 14 Britons among the 72 non-Greeks on the boat. The others were from Albania, Australia, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Norway, South Africa, Ukraine, and theUS.

Two Australians and 12 Greeks are missing but that number may rise as not all the passengers were registered.

Divers have been searching the wreck for victims trapped in cabins or on the ferry's car deck. They have also been trying to protect the area from any pollution from escaping fuel.

Fishermen, Greek army heli copters and navy vessels, and helicopters from the British aircraft carrier HMS Invincible were involved in the search, which was hampered by high winds and strong waves.

Much of the help given to survivors was donated privately, not by the state. Free hotel rooms, restaurant meals and clothes were available, and a soup kitchen was set up in the Byzantine church. An elderly woman roamed the hospital pressing medals of the Virgin Mary into palms.

Ann Bennett, an American who lives on Paros, said that the community was devastated. "Everyone knows someone who has died. This is the biggest disaster it has endured in living memory."

Around 20 survivors, who had gathered at the port authority to sift through personal effects recovered after the accident, stiffened when a sailor joined them. Seizing an orange life-jacket, a man rammed it over the sailor's head and tied the cords. "This is how you put on a life jacket," he shouted.
